I would give this game a 5 star however, since playing it for a while now reduced it to 3 stars and not recommend it.  WHY?  Maybe I should start with the positives. 1.  ACTION packed 2. Myriad of things to do (purchases and missions etc) 3. Ability to play on or off line. (online/story mode) 4. Play together with friends.  Let's go with the negatives and my first big one is.  1. When you die, you're dead right?  Well, it seems some pansy queers get their panties tied in a knot and don't want to lose.  SHAME on RockStar which do things in 24 hour modes like getting through a bounty or breaking into the "stash houses", but this one thing gets to me.   When these people get shot at, or lose against you, they tend to chase you down to prove a point.  THEY ARE SORE LOSERS and refuse to lose.  So, they come after you and within the session MURDER you on and on and one.  There was one time I could not even get out of my session to go into another.    Another time this play was so close I could touch him, and I KNOW I eliminated them and low an behold, they didn't even fall and shot me once again.  Yeah, I would say 5 to 10 hits from the same person during that session/24 hour period would be more than enough.  SHAME on RockStar.  Maybe there should be a limit on how much you can be killed my ONE person during a session?  I mean enough is enough and when is too much enough?  It's like beating a dead horse at that point.  Move on losers and play on.  For Christ sake its only a GAME and that's how I look at it.  A GAME!  2. In the middle of a great win or lose battle, you get a "network error".  REALLY?  RockStar has a multi gazillion dollar enterprise...and it happens frequently.  I'm sure they'll blame that crap on my system...Pity on them.  3.  Little player "clicks" kick you out because your winning or you're not playing they way they want....cry babies.   Actually I don't mind going into other sessions....  Yeah, these are the negatives and overall will outnumber the positives if you really want to play this game.  I'm sure you got "hackers" in there as well.  Phantom players re-coding etc.    You wold think this company's been around a million years and would clean up some of these issues.  I mean, I know it's a cut throat game but I counted 51 kills on me and I was not even able to change my session but had to ALT/CONTROL/DELETE to shut the game down?  Yeah, it's like I said, it's beating a dead horse.  Are you dead enough yet?  The multi player section is cool if you can find other players.    Yeah, play at your own risk.  Could be a fun game though.

The Grand Theft Auto series is fun. Rockstar makes really good games (RDR2 being the greatest game of all time). However, GTA5 Online is riddled with cheaters/modders that they have completely destroyed the game play experience. To the point that I'm honestly surprised there hasn't been a class-action lawsuit against Rockstar for refusing to fix the issues. They have pretty much put patches on the back burner to focus solely on GTA6. They should be sued into oblivion for allowing this to go on. If they can't put anything into GTA Online that doesn't generate money, they wont do it. This includes security patches. It should be a criminal offense what they are doing; Selling a product without fixing major game breaking issues.  Don't waste your time with it.

Title: "Los Santos' Sinful Playground: A Review of GTA 5's Vanilla Unicorn Strip Club"  Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐ (4/5)  Welcome to the provocative world of the Vanilla Unicorn, Los Santos' premier strip club and nightlife destination in Grand Theft Auto 5. Brace yourself for a rollercoaster ride of neon lights, seductive dancers, and an atmosphere that's both tantalizing and controversial.  Ambiance: The Vanilla Unicorn boasts a lively and vibrant atmosphere, complete with pulsating music, colorful lighting, and an eclectic mix of patrons. The club exudes a sense of decadence, capturing the essence of a high-end adult entertainment venue. The attention to detail is commendable, from the smoky ambiance to the realistically rendered pole-dancing routines.  Entertainment: The main attraction, of course, is the talented lineup of exotic dancers. Each performer showcases unique moves and choreography, adding variety to the visual spectacle. The club also features private dance rooms for a more intimate experience, providing players with a taste of the risqué side of Los Santos nightlife. While the explicit content is clearly intended for a mature audience, the animations and performances are well-executed within the context of the game.  Interactivity: Players can engage in various activities within the club, such as enjoying a drink at the bar, playing a game of darts, or even partaking in a private dance. The interactive elements add depth to the overall experience, allowing players to immerse themselves in the virtual nightlife of Los Santos.  Controversy: It's essential to acknowledge the controversial nature of the strip club in the game. While it serves as a virtual space for adult-oriented entertainment, some players may find the explicit content uncomfortable or offensive. Rockstar Games, the developers, have aimed to create an authentic depiction of a certain aspect of city life, but individual sensitivities may vary.  Conclusion: The Vanilla Unicorn is a well-crafted and immersive addition to GTA 5's open-world experience. It successfully captures the allure of a high-end strip club, providing players with a taste of the glitzy and risqué side of Los Santos nightlife. Whether you're there for the mesmerizing dance performances or to explore the interactive elements, the Vanilla Unicorn offers a unique slice of digital decadence that contributes to the diverse tapestry of activities in the game. Just be mindful of the explicit content if you're easily offended, as the club doesn't shy away from its adult-oriented theme. So, step into the neon-lit world of the Vanilla Unicorn and let the virtual decadence unfold. 🌟💃🍸

Would be a great game without that Rockstar social login cancer. You buy the game on steam, you pay for it, then if whatever happens to your rockstar social login (that you did not ask for and did not know prior to buying the game), you cannot play the game anymore as your steam profile gets linked to that particular rockstar social login (that you did not want or paid for, you as a retard thought you were paying for the game, but Rockstar does not care). Anyway, one day you reinstall the game thinking you can replay it, well your steam profile got linked to that initial rockstar login, so if you can't access it then bad luck, you can't play the game!!! Can you unlink that rockstar login cancer from steam? No you can't. Did rockstar get your money? It sure did. Just do yourself a favor and don't buy it anymore. If the social login cancer returns in GTA6, just don't buy that either.

[b]GTA Online Beginner Guide:[/b]  1) Do [b]Dax missions(Los Santos Drug-lord Series)[/b] for free Super Car(Ocelot Virtue) , Bricade 6x6 which you can convert to Acid Lab business from your [b]first time complete bonuses[/b] for the Dax missions for $750k  2) a) Do [b]Stash Houses[/b](restocks Acid Lab), [b]G's Cache[/b](Restocks ammo and Snacks) & [b]Daily Time trials[/b](gives $101k for beating par time) everyday . b) keep selling the acid lab product and grind [b]Dax's Fooligan missions[/b](call him on phone and request work) in the side to make way for [b]acid lab upgrade[/b] later. c) Also do the [b]10 junk energy skydives[/b] and [b]get gold medal in every dive[/b] for another stream of basically free income for jumping off a plane 10 times.  3) Using [b](Step 2)[/b] Accumulate about [b]2.2 Million[/b] to be able to buy [b]Kosatka Submarine[/b](Speak with a guy in Music Locker near Diamond Casino to be able to buy submarine)  4) Submarine gives access to [b]Cayo Perico Heist[/b](best heist in the game), follow a tutorial or play through from YouTube to complete Cayo Perico Heist the easiest way possible. This should get you on average [b]1.5 Million[/b] every time you do Cayo Perico Heist (more payout possible if you loot more)  5) Repeat (Step 4) till you are able to do (Step 4) more easily and/or you have enough money for something you want to buy  6) You have access to the best money making heist in GTA Online now, so now u have fun and buy whatever,   Bonus: - Get [b]Nightclub Business[/b] for best passive money (If you are too lazy to do full heist, this gives the best passive income for doing basically nothing)

I don't recommend this game after 1,000 hours because of Rockstar's insistence on lowering the quality of their product. GTA 5 is a great game, no real complaints there. GTA Online was great as of 2020. Since then they've done everything they can to time-gate progression thru lower payouts and by removal of roughly 180 vehicles. Said vehicles can still be accessed with GTA +, their new premium service. Two problems with this being, one it costs a monthly fee and two it's not out for PC. Also trying to play in a public session without modders is almost impossible. Rockstar knows about these cheaters, they've been in the game since release and little has been done about it. However, if there is a money exploit, they're quick to patch it out. If you encounter an issue online and need help good luck getting a hold of customer service, they've ripped their phones from the wall. Now you can message them and hope you get someone competent. Honestly with their recent performance I expect GTA 6 to be more of the same.  TLDR This game gets a 4/10 for quality control issues. Rockstar prioritizes monetization of the community.

Very buggy on pc and Rockstar glazes the console version of this game. Heists bug out and kicks everyone youre playing with out of the lobby. For example on The Cayo Perico heist when youre trying to use the key cards on doors, your character will just stand there and do nothing. Other times guards will catch you even though you havent killed anybody and youre out of sight. Sometimes when you take the primary target it wont count and it wont be added to your payout.   If youre two people playing the Diamond Casino heist and you reach the tunnel before the vault, the game will kick both you and the other player out of the session. These are issues theyve had for a while but theyve never bothered to fix it. Theyre a half assed staff who dont care as much for pc compared to Playstation and Xbox. Some people experience different bugs than what my friends and i have, but it still bothers me that these are common issues and they dont care to fix it. I understand they are working on gta 6 but still.  Mind you ive played over 300 hours on the ps4 and ps5 version of the game and ive never experienced a bug whatsoever.

Grand Theft Auto V is an extraordinary open-world action-adventure game that offers an immersive and thrilling experience. From the moment you step into the fictional city of Los Santos, you're greeted with a living, breathing world filled with endless possibilities.  The game's storyline follows three protagonists, each with their own unique backgrounds and personalities, which adds depth and variety to the gameplay. You'll get to know Michael, a retired bank robber trying to live a peaceful life, Franklin, a young hustler looking for his big break, and Trevor, a volatile and unpredictable character.  One of the standout features of GTA 5 is its vast and dynamic open world. Los Santos feels alive, teeming with pedestrians, bustling traffic, and a variety of activities to engage in. Whether you want to participate in high-speed police chases, engage in thrilling heists, or simply explore the city's stunning landscapes, there's always something to keep you entertained.  The game's attention to detail is remarkable. The graphics are stunning, with incredibly realistic visuals that bring the city and its inhabitants to life. The level of immersion is further enhanced by a phenomenal soundtrack, which features a wide range of genres and perfectly complements the fast-paced gameplay.  GTA 5 also introduces an online multiplayer mode called GTA Online, where you can team up with friends or other players from around the world to tackle missions, participate in races, or just wreak havoc together in the city. This adds a whole new dimension to the game, providing endless hours of fun and excitement.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a masterpiece in the gaming world. It combines a gripping storyline, a massive open world, stunning visuals, and an online multiplayer mode that keeps you engaged for hours on end. Whether you're a fan of the series or new to the franchise, GTA 5 is a must-play for any gamer seeking an adrenaline-pumping experience.

Grand Theft Auto 5 (stylized as Grand Theft Auto V) is the 15th overall installment and 5th installment of the main series of games known as Grand Theft Auto, a third-person shooter game set in the fictional version of Los Angeles known as Los Santos dveloped by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games. The game follows 3 main protagonists Michael De Santa a film buff and former bank robber in witness protection who following a series of events must come out of retirement, Trevor Philips an old friend and crew member of Michael's who must finds out his old friend never actually died during their final heist which went wrong, and Franklin Clinton a small-time street gangster whom Michael takes under his wing and mentors into being a better criminal.  Grand Theft Auto V's story is full of great characters, a great story itself, and very memorable moments. Aside from that is the aptly titled Grand Theft Auto: Online which offers an experience great for friends and parties, just don't hang around freemode or expect a rocket to the face.

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

GTA V is nothing short of a masterpiece in the world of open-world gaming. Rockstar has created an immersive, sprawling landscape that captivates players from the very beginning. From the intricate storyline to the stunningly detailed Los Santos, every aspect of the game is a testament to the developers' dedication and craftsmanship.  Despite my laptop's modest specs, the game runs surprisingly well, providing a smooth and enjoyable experience. The optimization is commendable, allowing me to delve into the rich narrative and explore the vast cityscape without sacrificing performance.  The characters are brilliantly crafted, each with their unique personalities and story arcs that kept me engaged throughout my 12-hour gaming session. The missions are diverse, offering a perfect blend of action, strategy, and humor. The attention to detail is astounding, making Los Santos feel like a living, breathing city.  Whether you're a fan of intense heists, adrenaline-pumping car chases, or simply want to roam a meticulously designed open world, GTA V has it all. The multiplayer mode adds another layer of excitement, providing endless opportunities for collaboration and competition.  In summary, GTA V is not just a game; it's an experience. It's a testament to Rockstar's commitment to delivering top-notch gaming adventures. If you haven't played it yet, you're missing out on one of the greatest gaming experiences of our time.  Pros:  Incredible open-world design Engaging storyline and characters Optimized for a variety of hardware Diverse and exciting missions Multiplayer adds extensive replay value Cons:  None worth mentioning Conclusion: GTA V stands tall as a must-play title for any gaming enthusiast. Rockstar has set the bar high, and this game continues to shine as a beacon of excellence in the gaming industry. The game is too good and the online gta is fantastic!!

There's a reason this game has held up for 10 years; it's because Rockstar knows how to craft a world and story like no other. The story mode is fantastic, it may not be the best story in the franchise, but the introduction of multiple protagonists to explore this, at the time, massive map, it was truly an awesome experience. The online is another beast entirely, going strong for almost 10 years is impressive. The online community is fairly toxic unless you have a friend group. That being said, it is still pretty fun to load an invite only server and raise your own mayhem.

I can say with 564% certainty this game is no longer worth playing. My reasons include, but are not limited to: ● Instead of focusing on removing hackers and improving the Online experience, Rockstar seems more keen on inflating costs and deflating profits (and, of course, their insatiable lust for selling Shark Cards). The amount of work that needs to be put in to getting the latest business or vehicle is extremely absurd and overinflated. You spend millions of in game dollars on a business that demands irl days worth of time dumped into it to turn a profit (and why does a mid SUV cost more than a literal super car?) ● Content disparity between current gen consoles and PC baffles me. It's one thing to have a game exclusively on one platform or console, but when the same game is missing features that you can only get on another platform? I am curious to their reasoning, but so far my money's on incompetence of their own code. One of my friends recently had to stop playing the game due to it bluescreening after about an hour of play since the Christmas update. He figured it was due to some sort of graphical overload due to the snow, but after the snow left the bluescreening stayed.  ● The constant disappointment that comes from features being added and never failing to come up short is a thing to behold. First-person GTA is something most-all players of the series have wanted for a very long time! Rockstar adds it, and the FOV is abyssal. Of course, mods can fix this glaring issue, but you have a very good chance of triggering their anti-cheat and getting your account nuked. Tow-trucks have been in the game since launch, and after 10 years they FINALLY added them! Buuuuut, it's locked behind a business and it can only be used on mission specific vehicles.  ● While it's nice the interaction menu got a face-lift recently, it's still clunky to navigate through. That, and while the controls felt good back when the game launched, are in desperate need of an overhaul. Mapping the functions of running, interacting, and answering your phone has lead to many instances of death, failure, and general annoyance (God forbid it's not an unskippable phone call). I don't care if you need your shoes or want a pizza, I'm in the middle of a literal war right now. Text me.  ● Lastly there is no Michael content for GTA Online, making it highly likely the Kill Michael option is the canon ending to GTA 5's story. There are plenty of places where Michael could have been "the guy" instead of this deluge of one-dimensional, quippy, tropey, uninspired characters that feel tacked on instead of interwoven. Instead of collaborating with Ned Luke (Michael's actor) for the 10th Anniversary of GTA 5, they just added a business. Meanwhile Ned is doing a play through of GTA 5 on his YT channel, I highly recommend checking it out sometime! TL;DR: Rockstar is greedy, incompetent, disappointing, lazy, Justice for Michael. Modders ruined the game, but at this point I hope they win. Fuck you Rockstar, see you in Vice City.

The single-player is a wonderful story that really makes you feel for these folks. However, the fact we never got single-player DLCs is criminal... eh? Hah! He he. But seriously, beat the missions and do the side stuff. You'll not regret it!   As for multiplayer, it's best to play it with friends and that is made far easier now that private lobbies have full progression now. Go to Invite Only and go nuts. There is a LOT in multiplayer. Missions, heists, businesses (legal and illegal), and a whole lot more. There's plenty to do in multiplayer that unfortunately completely overshadows single-player to an obscene degree. That aside, it's definitely worth playing now that you don't have to play public.

After 10 years, the only problems that get fixed are things that are fun or profitable for people. The minor QoL changes and recent updates that just use the same tired formula are just indicative of a corporation trying to extract as much cash for this cow as possible. Trash mechanics. You may argue that its a 10 year old game.. but Halo CE original is 15 years old and the game has superb aiming and vehicle mechanics. GTA has slow, sloppy and has relativity unresponsive controls. understanding the basic physics of GTA you'll find that most things don't even follow those simple game physics. some tree you can run over no problem, some are invincible. the invincible trees have an unrealistic hit box and making the smallest branch or a leaf an indestructible monster. genuinely makes no sense how a triple A game company makes so many contradictions in their own game. the movement is trash as wall. trying to turn your character 90 degrees will make them run in a circle 5 times while running into every wall possible. seems the controls are purposefully delayed and sporadic for a worse experience.  its easier to talk to a special needs kid than it is to play this game.

Honestly, I was in love with GTA Vice City. Back around 2004 it was my favorite game and I still retain warm memories of playing it. Vice City seemed to have been bustling with activities and you could always find something to do.  GTA5? A whole 'nother story for me. Don't get me wrong, the story itself is rather good... But it offers nothing else besides it. It doesn't give you -- or does a very poor job of pointing at -- interesting and meaningful side activities. I found nothing interested to do apart from doing the main story. I'm not interested in yoga and tennis, I want to explore the city, find interesting stuff while I'm doing it and experience interesting game mechanics. Most of it seem to be in the story. I personally didn't find the same enjoyment and diversity I saw in Vice City. In fact, it seems like a lot of features from Vice City were either not present in GTA V or rearranged, turning them into optional and utterly boring side activity.   Another gripe for me was Online. I'm not interested in GTA Online, but it's still included with the main game. I guess no point complaining about this, since removing it is unlikely to massively change the disk size.  All in all, if you liked GTA only for the story, then feel free to buy it with a discount. If you want something more for your experience, then you'd rather play the Witcher 3 or Red Dead Redemption 2. Especially the latter. It has all the vibes of GTA but with more diversity, more gameplay, more fun, more side activities, it's just much much better.   Hopefully Rockstar takes RDR2 experience into consideration for GTA6

The game is quite interesting as a concept (free world), but badly executed and is example of how world should not look like. Let me give you examples: - There is too much unnecessery cursing. It is just annoying to say the least. Yes there could be some from time to time, but this is just too much.  - Crime is glorified and really it should not be. It would be better for main characters to fight crime not cause it.  - There is no point for Russian language and culture to be part of the game as the game is made in America.  - Too less legal activities (opening business and managing it, be part of striving for success)  I don't think this game is suitable for anyone, because it makes you do innapropriote things in worst way possible.  And it is not suitable for younger people especially not to make impression that world consists only of crime.  Yes - you may say - well this is game and in game you should do something that you would not do in real life, but this is too much violence. There are also legal and interesting things to explore that you would not do in real life. Like building a software company or something.   I hope that GTA 6 would be at least a bit better, because this is dissapointment to be honest.

honestly disappointing, generally a fun game but completely ruined by cheaters and modders online. Rockstar truly does not give a shit about their games and only care about money clearly because any sort of money cheats they immediately catch on to protect their profit margins but any other kind of cheating or modding is completely overlooked because it doesn't affect profit. These modders basically have admin powers that you would see on gmod servers in gta online. They can spawn anything, kill anyone, trap you, and boot you from the game. They basically have god powers on any server and rockstar does jack shit. They let their game rot because its still pumping out money. And thats just the game side. Rockstar themselves makes this game an endless grind through repetitive missions, missions that are literally the same as the story mode missions with even the same animations or models used. And you have to do those missions over and over to grind through level after level and slowly gain minuscule amounts of cash compared to the cost of literally anything in this game. I know this is an old game, but it doesn't matter. This issue is timeless. The menu controls like a sloppy, drunk, wet cow that you're trying to control with your mind. It's absolutely abysmal.  Furthermore, let's say that you don't want to use WASD keybinds from 1990 and instead you want to use ESDF keybinds that actually make sense... well, good luck. You'll find yourself constantly running into conflicts.  Worse, if you decide like me, that I don't care about online and I just want to play the story mode, well, I'll just unbind some useless "online only" keybinds, right? No, no you won't. The garbage game will complain that you have keybinds unbound. You say "yes, I know, still save." Does it save your keybinds? No. You have to go back into the keybinds and bind every single useless keybind that you will never use because the developers are lazy and useless.  Even simple things like clicking on a graphics setting and trying to change it. It feels like I need to use telepathy to change or do anything. It runs and operates so incredibly poorly.  I hope this garbage isn't a sign of things to come for GTA VI.

GTA is honestly iconic and although Rockstar has been milking Online for money over the past couple of years, the content that was available at launch and the content that was added over the years alone makes this game worth the $30 price point. Although I got bored of online after about 100 something hours, I still need to go back and fully complete the story mode because the progression and the missions never seem to bore me. The fact that you can switch between Micheal, Trevor, and Franklin throughout the story make it all the more interesting as their personalities are very different from one another and playing different missions with each character feels more memorable rather than if you were confined to a single character. Although I am not the biggest GTA fan to this day, I have to admit that it was one of the most impressive games released in the 2010s, and the fact that they continue to have a stable player base to this day means that they have made something incredible. Not sure how I feel about GTA VI yet, but GTA V will always stick with me as I grew up playing it.

I'm voting this down because I have no space on my laptop to install another big game and that's partly due to GTA Online hijacking 55.9 GB of precious SSD space for no reason whatsoever. Simply deleting the dlcpacks folder will cause certain issues in story mode, so I'm not keen to do that. I guess it was beyond your knowledge and resources to make GTA Online a separate download like so many games on Steam. It puts me off replaying the game, so after installing it and not playing it for months I'm just going to uninstall it, again. I hear that's really good for the environment.  This might come as a shock to you, Rockstar Games, but not everyone is interested in GTA Online. I mean, it's a possibility that they're not even remotely curious about it. When I look at the Hardware & Software Survey for Free Hard Drive Space, I'm shocked by the amount of free space most people have, so in that sense you're in the right, but you're also not the only 100+ GB pony out there. People are making guides to trim down oversized installs on Steam, be it unnecessary language files, online content or whatever. You're probably going to repeat this with GTA VI and nothing I say or do will change that because you don't care. Why should you, right? You've made $8.5 billion off this game. Writing this is about as useful as telling Bezos to stop being a greedy inhumane asshole.

As a real life pilot, GTAV can be used as a great tool to practice, real world procedures, navigation, and communications. While the base game may not come with the best models for airliners, and will require you to purchase 3rd party addons to enjoy a realistic airline world, the popular Cessna 172 comes very close to what I fly in the real world. Combining the realistic Cessna with the beautiful scenery GTAV provides, and a 3rd party addon for ATC communications, like PilotEdge or VATSIM, I can create a very realistic feeling with the simulator. If I every fly an unfamiliar route in the real world, I can practice it in the sim first to get familiar with the sights I will see when I really fly, I can practice real world approaches, as well as other instrument procedures. Because the actual feeling of flying is hard to replicate, I strictly do not use the simulator to practice technique as it could create bad habbits for the real world, however while this may be true, I can still practice working procedures, and task management which sets a great foundation for myself when I return to the real cockpit!

*Choosing to mod/cheat an online game with PvP = tiny pp energy* TL;DR: For the price, the single player alone is makes the purchase worth it. If you wish to play online you'll have an great time as long as you're careful in public sessions and keep your grinding in private sessions. If you're a car fan and enjoy shooters like me, this game is awesome. The online DLC has been consistently awesome however Rockstar cannot be bothered to implement anti-cheat. Console players enjoy a cheater-free experience as well as a few more features simply because they're more profitable. Pro-tip for NVIDIA owners at the end of this review :)  I decided to purchase this game in 2021 because I never actually played the single player and ended up spending close to 200 hours in it. The story of Michael, Franklin, and Trevor is second to none. This story and its game play is so good that it secured quite the profits for R* in the beginning: this game is the single most profitable piece of entertainment in human history. I'm personally very glad that the death wish ending is the canon ending, as evidenced by the events of GTA online. I absolutely love the default controls and how this game can seamlessly switch between my keyboard & mouse to my Dualsense controller. As an aviation nerd, the attention to detail when it comes to flying is incredible!!   While the single player helped R* make record-breaking profits in the beginning, it is the online component that kept this game profitable month after month and year after year to the tune of millions of dollars per month on average. Shark cards have been selling like hot cakes for the better part of an entire decade. Personally, I've never bought any shark cards and despise online cheating so 1,800 hours later my character has EARNED well over $665mil and over 6mil RP all while maintaining a K/D of 2.1. I have mastered the grind of consistently earning money and RP with most sessions netting me over 2mil. Out of principle, I refused to buy shark cards because R* REFUSES to do anything to remedy the cheater epidemic that is present in this game. The modding scene has gotten so profitable that it has been estimated to be worth millions of dollars. PC players get f*ed over because we are statistically less likely to buy shark cards compared to our console peers (follow the money) and to add insult to injury, those of us who solo Cayo Perico have been getting our primary takes significantly nerfed. By all means, make the heist more difficult, but the primary takes should pay more. R* also decided to take away the ability to fast travel via Kosatka during bike/bunker sell missions. Console players enjoy a cheater-free experience because not only do they account for a much higher profit margin for R*, but because their pay-to-play online providers do not allow for cheating on their platforms; they essentially pay a monthly protection fee. Is there fun to be had in public lobbies? Absolutely. However, one must exercise caution as modders are able to crash your game on purpose, give themselves god mode, as well as exposing your IP address which means you should use a VPN. Do all of your grinding in a private lobby and you'll be fine, but be sure to switch to a single player character once a modder starts to "have his way" with you!  NVIDIA users: there is an anti-aliasing method that everyone should be using in order sharpen the lines of the game. Go to your NVIDIA control panel > manage 3D settings > program settings > select GTA V on the drop down menu > multi-frame sampled AA (MFAA) set to "on". I have personally seen this option improve the visual clarity on lower-spec'd mobile cards as well as high-end desktop cards :)

[h1] I've spent over 5000+ hours here, don't have much to say. [/h1]  Here's an amazing brownie recipe!   [b] Ingredients: [/b] 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar* 3/4 cup all-purpose flour 2/3 cup cocoa powder, sifted if lumpy 1/2 cup powdered sugar, sifted if lumpy 1/2 cup dark chocolate chips 3/4 teaspoons sea salt 2 large eggs 1/2 cup canola oil or extra-virgin olive oil** 2 tablespoons water 1/2 teaspoon vanilla  [b] Instructions: [/b] Preheat the oven to 325°F. Lightly spray an 8x8 baking dish (not a 9x9 dish or your brownies will overcook) with cooking spray and line it with parchment paper. Spray the parchment paper. In a medium bowl, combine the sugar, flour, cocoa powder, powdered sugar, chocolate chips, and salt. In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, olive oil, water, and vanilla. Sprinkle the dry mix over the wet mix and stir until just combined. Pour the batter into the prepared pan and use a spatula to smooth the top. Bake for 40 to 48 minutes, or until a toothpick comes out with only a few crumbs attached. Cool completely before slicing. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days. These also freeze well!!!!!

The most restrictive open-world to come out of a AAA developer. It picks and chooses when to be realistic, almost always to the detriment of fun. You’re basically playing a tech demo, that tries as hard as it can to make an open-world game linear.   For a game named after a crime, and known for glorifying gangsters, it sure is tame AF. Check out these verbatim reasons for failing in-game missions:  - There was a disturbance at the showroom - You notified the neighborhood (if you make too much noise, literally seconds before a scripted event that notifies the neighborhood). - You abandoned Lamar (by getting out of a burning car?) - Tracey fled in fear - Franklin spooked a rival racer  Are you fucking kidding me?! I was half expecting “emotional damage” to pop up at some point.   Throw in telepathic, teleporting cops who materialize out of thin air in seconds, any time you fire a gun, anywhere on the map, and you’ve got a case study in wasted potential.   The gaming equivalent of paying for a fancy dinner, only to find out it’s made of wax.

Traditional cannoli cream uses a sheep’s milk ricotta which I prefer - if I can get my hands on it. Any other high fat unpasteurized milk will work. Or if you want to cut some corners or are tight on time you can start off with any decent premade ricotta. Skip the low fat stuff, you’re making cannoli.  3 cups of drained ricotta  1.3 cups of confectioner’s sugar  1.5 tsp vanilla  Orange Zest  Using a hand or stand mixer, whip together these ingredients for a few minutes until well incorporated. Transfer from a bowl to a piping bag and keep in the refrigerator until ready to use.  The Shells  This is part that can easily go wrong and where you need to have a zen mindset. This recipe makes about 45 small to medium sized shells.  1.5 cups of all purpose Flour  .5 tsp cinnamon powder  1.5 tsp cocoa powder  2 tbsp white sugar  .5 tsp salt  3 tbsp cubed and chilled butter  2 tbsp Marsala  .5 tsp white vinegar  .25 cup of water  1 egg (for the wash)  Heat a neutral, high heat oil to 350F in a deep pot or fryer.  In stand mixer, combine all of the dry ingredients and mix well. Add in wet ingredients (except the egg) and continue to blend for a few minutes. Mixture will be somewhat crumbly. Remove from the bowl and pour out onto a large working surface.  Knead with your hands for 5 - 10 minutes until you have a mostly smooth and homogeneous ball of dough. Wrap in plastic wrap and let rest at room temperature for 1 hour.  Remove the dough from the plastic and cut into about 5 smaller pieces. Flour the dough balls gently. Pass each ball through the pasta maker, going from the widest setting down about 6 settings. Be slow and methodical, and don’t skip any steps.  Lay each sheet of dough out on your work surface and gently flour again. Using your circular punch out form, cut circles and save all of the excess dough which you’ll use for one final pass through the pasta maker.  Carefully and tightly wrap/roll each cut circle around the cannoli tube, and seal the edge with your egg wash. Be extremely careful not to let egg get all over the place. Avoid getting the egg on the cannoli tube or the dough will end up sticking to the tube while frying. Clean up any egg that gets on your work surface.  When the oil temperature has reached 350F, drop each tube into the oil and fry until golden. Using tongs, turn the cannoli in the oil so they cook evenly. This should take only about 1 minute.  Transfer to a rack lined with paper towels and carefully slide the shells off of the tubes while it’s still hot. You’ll want to use more paper towels so you don’t burn your fingers.  The tubes should be wiped down, and chilled in the refrigerator for just 1 - 2 minutes before starting the next round of shells. This avoids a lot of mess ups.  The finishing touches  Once the shells have completely cooled you can start filling the cannoli. This is made easier as a two person task and makes for a fun family activity, but is manageable by one person if necessary. Using the piping bag, fill each shell starting with the center and working outwards. Nothing worse than a cannoli with a big empty pocket of air in the middle. Once completely filled, you can garnish with whatever you like. Traditional toppings include candied fruit, crushed pistachio, or chocolate chips. When the cannoli are all dressed up and ready to go, you can give them all a final dusting of confectioner’s sugar. They should be eaten fresh as they start to lose their textural appeal if they sit around too long and get soggy.

What can be said about Grand Theft Auto V that hasn't already been said a million times? This game is a masterpiece and I am blown away by how modern it feels, even 10 years after it's release. Sure, the controls can be a bit janky and the story gets messy towards the end, but as an all around experience it still holds up incredibly well. Every time I play this game I feel like I went on vacation to California. The world feels so alive and its full of many activities. The attention to detail is absolutely mind-boggling. The "mini-games" actually have plenty of depth to them. You can spend hours playing golf and tennis, or cruising around and taking in the sights at various beaches, mountains, and forests. Car customization is very deep and rivals every racing game out there that was out in 2013. Also a special shout out to the soundtrack which is full of every genre you can think of and ranges from old school throwbacks, to modern (for 2013) music, to even some updated recent songs that released long after GTA V came out. Although the story may not please everyone, this game has some of the most memorable characters in all of gaming. Franklin, Trevor, Michael, Lamar, even the yoga instructor, are all unforgettable characters. There is constantly something fun going on in this game and there's never a dull moment.

After almost 500 hours of game-play inside and outside of Steam, I can confidently tell you that Rockstar treats it's player base horribly. So many parts of the Online experience are forced to be done solo, as they have no benefit to doing them with friends. Payouts for almost every single activity is minimal and feels like a spit in the face after you realize grinding for 100 hours will only net you disappointment. Every part of the Online experience is there to punch you in the dick and then hand you a single ice cube to make it sting a little less, but Rockstar are still the ones who did the kicking in the first place.  If you want to play this game for it's online, be prepared to ditch all public lobbies since they have at least one hacker in them at all times. All things worth doing will be done in a Crew only lobby, or in a closed mission where you can typically only bring in 3 friends. Rockstar may keep pushing horrible content updates that give you new ways to waste time, but they're never going to be worth investing your time. Do not buy this game, do not buy their next GTA, just don't waste your time with these disrespectful developers.

Positive: GTA 5 is a powerful continuation of a legendary gaming series that has captured my heart since its early days. The game's strength lies in its extensive and captivating story, which can be experienced from three different character perspectives, providing the game with incredible replayability and depth. Each character is uniquely designed and contributes to a rich and engaging world full of life and adventure. The multiplayer aspect also shines with a variety of missions and activities that can be undertaken solo or with friends, creating dynamic and unpredictable gaming scenarios.  Negative: Despite the many positive aspects, the multiplayer part receives criticism for going overboard with certain elements, especially when it comes to the introduction of overly futuristic vehicles like flying motorcycles. For me, this has disrupted the realistic and down-to-earth feel that the GTA series has traditionally aimed for, creating an imbalance in the game's dynamics.  Summary: GTA 5 stands as a titan in the gaming world with a rich and dynamic narrative, memorable characters, and a fun and extensive multiplayer mode. While some elements in multiplayer may feel exaggerated, the game's overall offering is still of an exceptional caliber that few other games can match. For long-time fans and new players alike, GTA 5 offers a world filled with adventure, laughter, and excitement

ATTENTION: Enable dual factor authentication to protect your account! I have over 500 hours in this game and someone was able to switch the email I was using. I have sent multiple tickets to Rockstar's support with help regarding this issue and have been blown off. Look it up on Google. Many people have lost their accounts to this issue for YEARS and it's STILL occurring.   Let's say that you want to try a different Rockstar account when you start the game through steam-because of the way GTA is linked to your steam and Rockstar account, you will not be able to play the game through a different Rockstar account. Also, due to this issue, I have lost other Rockstar games associated with my account. I spent my hard earned money on multiple Rockstar products, now they are permanently lost, and there is nothing I can do about it. Shame on Rockstar for not even remotely trying to fix this issue.

Grand Theft Auto V (GTA 5) is an exhilarating and immersive gaming experience that offers a compelling blend of action, adventure, and open-world exploration. Released to critical acclaim, this title from Rockstar Games boasts a meticulously crafted virtual rendition of Los Santos, a sprawling metropolis teeming with life and opportunities. The game's narrative intricately weaves together the lives of three diverse protagonists, each with their own compelling storylines, creating a rich tapestry of crime, intrigue, and unexpected twists. Beyond the captivating storyline, GTA 5 provides an expansive sandbox environment that encourages player agency, allowing you to shape your own criminal empire, engage in thrilling heists, and indulge in a plethora of side activities, from high-speed chases to leisurely pastimes like golf and tennis. With stunning visuals, a dynamic soundtrack, and an online multiplayer component that ensures endless entertainment, GTA 5 remains a timeless and must-have addition to any gaming library, promising countless hours of excitement and exploration.

If your expecting a masterpiece based on how many people know this game and the hype that is following gta 6 then I don't recommend this game. If your looking for interesting and engaging story I don't recommend, if you want to just drive around city, stealing stuff and killing cops then I recommend the game. The characters you meet in the game are interesting and the banter is enjoyable to witness but as far as their own character progression goes there is none. Entertaining moment are sandwiched in between long travel times. The travelling does get very boring to the point where you just end up taking the taxi everywhere as it is more efficient. The open world while very lively and believable is pretty shallow and lacks content. Minus the travel times the missions are fine but each mission lacks a strong tie to the story to the point where a lot of the missions feel like filler stuff just so the gang can do interesting things. This leads to moments where there isn't something to keep you looking forward to the next thing. There is stat upgrades like better stamina or better shooting which you upgrade by using that actual stat. If you run a lot then your stamina will upgrade. Overall the upgrades are minimal and don't end up changing your play style.

Abysmal loading times, constant crashes, full to the brim with pointless mechanics and busy work that make even the simplest gameplay convention into a chore.  The online mode is fun, but completely broken. Constant glitches, from missions that become unbeatable to expensive ammo and resources just disappearing out of my inventory for no reason every now and then.  Many official online missions clearly had little to no play testing done, and some of them are truly miserable experiences (even before you take the griefers into account). It's also grindy as Hell, but we all know that's intentional to tempt you into buying CRIMINALLY EXPENSIVE microtransactions. And let's not forget the complete lack of moderation, so hackers just run rampant to a frankly astonishing degree. I usually stick to "invite only" sessions because public online is just unplayable at this point.  Of course, if anything bad happens, like you get hacked or lose access to your account, Rockstar doesn't give a damn. You just can't play or even make a new account anymore, sucks to be you.  The story mode is pretty good, all things considered.

My friend who I play CS 2 with said if I post a review on GTA 5, and it gets 75 likes and 30 Awards that he will buy me a RTX 3060 and 1 Kilo of Lemon . So im just gonna leave this here. Help a brotha  GTA 6 IS COMING BABY!!!!!  I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son. Grand Theft Auto V isn't just a game; it's a memory, its broken the barrier past nostalgia and become something entirely different. Every moment in the fictional city of Los Santos is a testament to the care and detail the developers have poured into this creation. It's not just the stunning visuals or the dynamic soundtrack that make this game a masterpiece, but the way it makes you feel part of an expansive, living world. The story, woven through the lives of Michael, Trevor, and Franklin, is more than just a series of missions; it's a journey through their wild lives and achieves a level of immersion that I have yet to replicate in other games today.  The heart of GTA 5 lies in its ability to offer something for everyone. Whether you're tearing through the streets in a high-speed chase, enjoying a quiet moment watching the sunset over the Vinewood hills, or teaming up with friends in GTA Online, the game seamlessly blends adrenaline-pumping action with quiet, moments. It's this balance that makes the experience so memorable. GTAV will always keep its position as top 5 games i've ever played, I remember being 11 years old with my PS3 going to that gamestop with my mom and getting the game, bringing it home launching the game and hearing that echo of the siren in the loading screen. Nothing beats this feeling and I don't think anything will come close to this for any other generation.  10/10

To start, I'll say this: my whole life, I've always wanted to play this. For real, that is. After all, nearly every person I knew had played it. We had it on the Xbox 360 when I was younger, and I remember I used to sneak on it, before hearing a parent coming close to the room... so I quickly exited and booted up Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga. They knew something was up, as every time they came in, I was on the title screen.  Anyway, several years later, and I've finally played through the entire story. It went by about as quick as a breeze, not because it's short--if anything, it's a decently long story--but because it was so fun. Usually every game has at least one mission that is extremely annoying, just because it's no fun to do - but this game was a gem. And if there's anything Grand Theft Auto has taught me about gems... ...it's a steal.

Well, what can I say about GTA V, if not GTA V Online, which is the one I've played the most and will mention. Well, it's riddled with issues in various ways, to the point where the game is flooded with hackers everywhere. You really feel absolutely nothing when conquering a yacht or a mansion; the game is so saturated with hackers that everyone has everything, and public sessions are complete chaos. And seriously, it's no joke how many hackers there are. The other day, they put me inside a container, and I had to leave the session because I couldn't escape; the hacker kept forcing me into that container. So, reconsider spending your money on this game if you're only going to play online; it's really not worth it. Now, the story mode, on the other hand, is worth it. It doesn't have the limitations of online and even features animals and a whole living universe, unlike online. So, that's it; grab it on sale, have fun, and please, don't use hack in this game.

Update: GTA Online on PC is absolute trash and full of hackers. If you report them the report is actually sent from their PC, which their mod menu detects, blocks it and makes everyone in the session unable to do anything ("You invited you to your own apartment" screen and so ow or they just make you unable to move and blow everyone up)  And then they make you a target and keep messing up the following sessions you join.  What a poop show Rockstar.   Good game, but clearly designed as controller first, the aircraft controls are horrible on PC compared to other games. There should have been fast travel to properties player owns around the map (apart from changing spawn location and restarting session as work around). Driving to properties on other side of the map simply to check supplies/start a mission is a huge waste of  collective human hours. The session management also wastes a lot of time in loading screen/sending people from crew/friends sessions to public sessions after each mission. Rockstar must've done it to increase active game time to show for stats $. Hope this changes in GTA VI.

Red lentil, chickpea & chilli soup  if you're looking for review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Red lentil, chickpea & chilli soup recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients  2 tsp cumin seeds large pinch chilli flakes 1 tbsp olive oil 1 red onion, chopped 140g red split lentils 850ml vegetable stock or water 400g can tomatoes, whole or chopped 4 tbsp 0% Greek yogurt, to serve  200g can chickpeas or ½ a can, drained and rinsed (freeze leftovers)  small bunch coriander, roughly chopped (save a few leaves, to serve)  Directions  STEP 1 Heat a large saucepan and dry-fry 2 tsp cumin seeds and a large pinch of chilli flakes for 1 min, or until they start to jump around the pan and release their aromas.  STEP 2 Add 1 tbsp olive oil and 1 chopped red onion, and cook for 5 mins.  STEP 3 Stir in 140g red split lentils, 850ml vegetable stock or water and a 400g can tomatoes, then bring to the boil. Simmer for 15 mins until the lentils have softened.  STEP 4 Whizz the soup with a stick blender or in a food processor until it is a rough purée, pour back into the pan and add a 200g can drained and rinsed chickpeas.  STEP 5 Heat gently, season well and stir in a small bunch of chopped coriander, reserving a few leaves to serve. Finish with 4 tbsp 0% Greek yogurt and extra coriander leaves

Story: Compelling and intricate. A blessing to experience with lessons from a gritty, grim depiction of the West of Western culture.  Online: Was once a great game to play with friends and charade with randoms... but this is the PC port. Total cash-grab pricing of in-game multiplayer content turned it into 1930s German economy simulator where they prompt you to ask your wallet for permission to buy the most overrated possessions known to man -- *Virtual vehicles*  A curse no doubt conjured by the Rockstar North corporate bean-counters that analyzed the profit of holiday and birthday gift revenue coming from these aforementioned dream vehicles back in 2014. It was when missions paid a Nth of any purchasable in-game content. The grind was not worth it even when the prices mirrored the real world's retail prices of cars and weapons. Punks with dough to spend and hackers were swift to drop in and find ways to accumulate in-game currency without grindy gameplay. The well was poisoned before the water had time to collect at the bottom.

Grand Theft Auto V (GTA 5) is an absolute masterpiece that continues to captivate players with its unparalleled open-world experience, dynamic characters, and immersive gameplay. Released in 2013, the game has stood the test of time and remains a shining example of what an open-world action-adventure game can achieve.  One of the most impressive aspects of GTA 5 is its vast and meticulously crafted open world, the fictional state of San Andreas. The attention to detail is extraordinary, with a diverse range of landscapes, from bustling urban environments to serene countryside and picturesque coastal areas. The level of detail in the game world is staggering, and it creates an incredibly immersive experience for players.  The game features three playable protagonists—Michael, Trevor, and Franklin—each with their own distinct personality, background, and set of skills. This innovative approach to storytelling adds depth to the narrative and allows players to experience the storyline from multiple perspectives. The character development is exceptional, and the writing is top-notch, making each protagonist memorable in their own right.  GTA 5 excels in offering a wide variety of activities beyond the main storyline. From adrenaline-pumping heists and thrilling car chases to golf, tennis, and base jumping, the game provides an extensive range of diversions to keep players engaged for hours on end. The attention to detail extends to the side missions and activities, making them just as enjoyable as the main storyline.  The game's graphics and attention to realism are outstanding, even years after its initial release. The level of detail in the character models, vehicles, and environments is remarkable, and the game's lighting effects contribute to a visually stunning experience.  Furthermore, GTA Online, the multiplayer component of GTA 5, adds another layer of longevity to the game. With a vast open world to explore, cooperative and competitive missions, and a constant stream of updates and new content, GTA Online provides endless hours of entertainment for players.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a landmark achievement in the gaming industry. Its combination of a richly detailed open world, compelling characters, engaging storyline, and diverse gameplay options make it a must-play for any fan of the action-adventure genre. Even years after its release, GTA 5 continues to be a shining example of the incredible potential of video games as an art form and entertainment medium.

Not only has this game resulted in the life-long arrest of an autistic person that has never hurt anybody or intended to hurt anybody, but it also locked me out because you need a rockstar account and can't login with your steam account. I forgot the password and no longer have access to the gmail account linked to it. There's also the fact that Rockstar has absolutely RUINED GTA online by implementing pay to win aspects with overpowered vehicles that are obtained by, you guessed it, in-game money that can be bought with real life money. The only reason they never do anything about it is because having these overpowered vehicles create incentive for people to purchase those vehicles to fight against people who already have those vehicles, but what do you know, these vehicles are fucking expensive so you can either grind for these vehicles or purchase money for these vehicles. This is only made worse by the fact most of the content in GTA online costs a metric fuck ton of in-game money so you can't really have fun without investing into rockstar's most disliked industry or by spending litteral days just to afford to purchase a random fucking building to start the content chain. The grinding is made worse only by the fact that while you grind, you get called and texted by in game characters advertising the content you can't afford and the devs will constantly create more content that you can't afford.

Rockstar requires that Social club is linked to Steam which seems like it shouldn't be an issue, unless like me, the Rockstar launcher is saying that an account with an email I've never made nor seen in my life is linked to the account. They won't let a new social club account sign in because it is not linked to Steam. I assume they did this to ensure I paid for the game, but the fact that I can launch from Steam should be proof enough. This is highly unethical. I've played tons of other games with their own launchers and they all let you switch to a different/new account you created after launching through Steam. I'm essentially out of my money or stuck playing offline which is not part of the original purchase agreement.   You pay for a game believing the multiplayer will work seamlessly and when it doesn't it feels like you've been scammed because you have been. Just pirate this game. I shouldn't have to look up guides, read Reddit posts, or talk to support just to get a product I purchased working. The process to recover this account is highly convoluted and the Rockstar website won't even allow me to sign in under the new account I made to contact support even though I verified my account and everything. Why even spend the money for a headache just take to the seas.  Edit  I was wrong I can't even play offline since that requires you to sign in too. Instead of launching offline it just gives an error since the Rockstar launcher doesn't work without wifi. I've literally been scammed by a AAA game company insane.

I've had problems with this game, I didn't like it very much at launch: gameplay felt weird, I didn't like the characters, etc. Now that I've been playing all 3D GTA games in order, I can better appreciate the evolution of the series. This is the best GTA has played and looked ever, so much so I'd be tempted to play it all again if it weren't for GTA Online...  I'm gonna be honest, at first I was so frustrated with the GTA Online I left a negative review. I felt the game was constantly fucking me over and wasting my time. It's a rough start, but if you can survive that the game starts to feel rewarding. It's grindy though, be prepared to do the same things over and over again. Story is mainly locked behind end-game content: businesses costing millions and so on. But there are some pretty nice returns of characters from the main game here and there. GTA Online is like crack: you know it's bad for you, but you can't stop taking it.

Yes, for the $10 I paid for it, but it's a very flawed game, and a sign of the low standards of gaming today.  This one is by far the best GTA yet, and also still shows their failings in knowing how to advance the series. This game, like all GTA games is a fun chaos simulator. When the game tries to be serious, the flawed mechanics are obvious. It's clear Rockstar has no intention of improving them much.  The first thing I noticed is Rockstar doesn't respect their players. This was a single player series that now focuses on multi-player, and the single player game is hurt for it. The fact that different gen consoles got more/less content is also an insult to customers.   The city is by far the best they've done yet. It's vast, and beautiful, and very well realized. I love driving around in it. It's added by the fact that you can put your own music in the radio. That's something that should be a standard today. The commercials they add really make it better.   The story, and three protag concept is cool, and it works very well. I can't say I care for it, or the characters. These have never been why I played GTA in the first place. The constant bickering just wears thin far too fast.  I like the arcade feeling of the driving in this over the fish tailing of GTA 4's cars. Motorcycles are actually usable again.   Sadly, there's just so many problems with this game.  First, the game is not optimized well. On a 3070 running 1080p at 60 fps, I had to turn MXAA off to get over 30fps. It held a solid 60 until I went underwater. It would sit around 15fps underwater. This is just terrible. The standards of poor games people accept today just makes me sad.  The whole structure of the game is poor. If you want any chance of making money, you have to do the story first. What little reward there is to having all that money, is just planes and helicopters that can't really be used as all the meaningful gameplay is gone. Businesses have such a poor Return Of Investment, you'll be waiting forever for them to pay off. Cars are absolutely worthless except to look at in story mode. If you buy them, they can disappear in seconds. you can't use them in most missions because Rockstar has once again failed to innovate on their lazy programming. You go out of your way to grind money for a car, take it to a mission...and once again they stick you with the shittiest car because they don't understand how to make a game difficult. Therefore, there's no point to going after money or vehicles. In multi-player, your cars get saved. Not in story mode, because they don't care about it. They specifically devalue their own product. This is the same thing they do in Max Payne 3, where he constantly throws away machine guns to pull out a pistol. That shit's just amateur hour.  The mission structure often fails as they stick you in a position where Michael drives, and Franklin shoots. They put the characters in positions where their abilities aren't useful. This makes meaningful gameplay hard, as the game is catered against it's strengths. When I picked ending C, they disable sprint in the firefight...yep. They're that desperate to fake difficulty.  Collision physics are inconsistent. You don't know what will stop you dead, or get knocked over. This wasn't as big of a problem  in past games.  The hidden packages don't appear unless you save and reload the game. They don't tell you this, and they actually patched this is in.    The AI is dumb, and often drives right into you.  The police come when you punch someone out in the middle of nowhere....because birds call them (not a joke.) Artificial difficulty is lazy work. Yes, it's easy to lose them...but it becomes tedious time consumption for no reason. The police are very inconsistent. Sometimes a one star level takes minutes, while a two star level takes seconds to lose. They're not difficult, just annoying.

here is something for everyone in GTA Online. Whether you want to race cars, fly planes, rob banks, or just explore the vast world of Los Santos, there is something to keep you entertained. The game is also constantly being updated with new content, including new missions, vehicles, weapons, and clothing.  One of the best things about GTA Online is the sense of community. There are millions of players from all over the world who are always looking for new people to play with. You can join crews, create your own custom jobs, or just hop into a random session and meet new people.  If you are looking for a fun, challenging, and rewarding online experience, then GTA Online is the game for you. It is a game that you can keep coming back to for years to come.  Here are some of the things that make GTA Online so great:  Massive world to explore: Los Santos is a sprawling city with a lot to see and do. There are mountains to climb, beaches to swim at, and plenty of hidden secrets to discover. Variety of activities: There are a ton of different things to do in GTA Online. You can race cars, fly planes, rob banks, play golf, or just explore the world. Constantly evolving: Rockstar Games is constantly adding new content to GTA Online. This includes new missions, vehicles, weapons, and clothing. Sense of community: There is a large and active community of players in GTA Online. You can join crews, create your own custom jobs, or just hop into a random session and meet new people. If you are looking for a fun, challenging, and rewarding online experience, then GTA Online is the game for you. It is a game that you can keep coming back to for years to come.  Here are some of the continuing downloadable content that has been released for GTA Online:  Heists: Heists are some of the most challenging and rewarding activities in GTA Online. They require teamwork and coordination to complete, and they can be a lot of fun. Special Events: Rockstar Games often hosts special events in GTA Online. These events can include new modes, vehicles, or clothing. Updates: Rockstar Games releases regular updates for GTA Online. These updates add new content, fix bugs, and improve the game. The continuing downloadable content for GTA Online is one of the things that makes the game so great. It keeps the game fresh and exciting, and it gives players a reason to keep coming back.

The game offers a vast and detailed virtual world to explore, allowing players to engage in thrilling missions, car chases, and heists. The pros of GTA 5 include its immersive and visually stunning graphics, diverse range of playable characters, and the freedom it grants players to navigate the virtual environment. The multiplayer component, GTA Online, offers an expansive multiplayer experience with numerous activities and missions. However, the game does have some cons to consider. It contains mature content and explicit violence, which may not be suitable for all players or age groups. Additionally, the game's size and complexity can be overwhelming for some, and it may require a significant time investment to fully explore and appreciate all its features. GTA Online is the worst online multiplayer experience ever. It almost feels like a game such as GTA should never have online features. Half the time I feel like I was in a boring dream. Missions, heists, and what not take too long with redundant driving from one point to another and lack of vehicle spawn. If your chopper blows up in the middle of the desert, you're d o n e, fucked.   Yes, some deathmatches, races, and all that events can be fun, but if I wanted to play those game modes, I'd rather play other games. As for the heists, the thing that gets you a lot of money quicker, it's like being tortured more painful than when Trevor tortured that dude. For one, connection errors are more common to encounter than the actual players who are willing to join the heist. What worse is that once you've got some players ready, and you finally get to hear the mission instructions, your fellow crew mates would grief the fuck out of you with all that hack, trainer, or some shit. Sure, that sure sounds like fun. The heists/mission are very long with the long drive and thousands of npcs to be killed, so it makes sense if you need other players as they might help you travel faster and kill npcs faster. Truth is, you can't rely on other players for helping you because most likely they'd rather be trolls. I know I can play with friends and family, but they are smart enough to avoid this shit.  Money is important. So important that you need money to have fun in the game. Some missions/heists requires you to buy some properties. To earn money you should do contract mission or events. these contract missions/events don't even get you loads of cash. Meanwhile, the properties you need to buy are way too expensive. Luckily, these contract missions/event can be done in solo; however, even so, the missions are made for multiplayer so it takes so long. Wait, whats this? oh, you can buy money with money! That's right! You want to buy these in-game properties to enjoy the additional missions, but you don't like grinding for money because it's boring? Just give Rockstar your cash!  Seriously, I would prefer Rockstar to make dlc(s) to the main game for additional gameplay, stories, and in-game stuff than this online bullshit.

GTA V Story Mode: 5/5 Stars  - Story is epic; each character has a lot of in-depth individual stories, about who are they? | Gameplay, from gunplay to driving a vehicle, is enjoyable | Map size is okay | Game graphics, beautiful from 2013 until this day.  - But they should make your bought car not disappear when you leave it. Instead, it just returns to your garage.  GTA Online: 3/5 Stars  - uhhhh.. Grindy... and a mess  - When I joined the public session mostly, I was bombarded with people in chat advertising their mod menu, or sometimes moderators jailing your character so it could not move, ruining lobby sessions and business missions. There were some friendly moderators that helped me with business missions. (Invite only session is better.)  - So back in the summer update, when they gave GTA 5 free on Epic I grind "business mission" just selling cars and leveling up and character stats to profit. ;)  ;)   - Mainly playing online just to have fun with friends playing Heist. Or doing an online race,stunt race, and the new one a drift race...

Very low expectations for GTA 6 after spending less than a month with this lightly-polished turd.   Offline/Story mode is way too short, and there's not enough story for each character. They all just feel like side-characters with a little extra screen time. What little of them is added to Online doesn't make up for this at all, nor does all the extra side crap in story mode.   Online is the real dumpster fire. A lazy, even more buggy, stupid excuse for a cash grab built around a bunch of badly-implemented good and bad ideas and designed to spread and induce toxicity and punish people for trying to get away from that crap. Rockstar are abusing every mental manipulation they can to try to keep people playing, but anyone who does so must just be desperate for something to do because it is boring AF playing the same crap for disproportionate effort vs payout in so many different forms, getting grief'ed constantly in public lobbies no matter how peaceful you are, and etc.   Between this and the GTA Trilogy Definitive Edition BS, Rockstar has officially justified pirating their games, but in reality everyone is better off just avoiding this bloated, corporation-focused shadow of what was once a good game studio entirely. Long live III, VC, SA, IV; because V killed GTA.

-={ 9 / 10 }=- Grand Theft Auto V is a masterpiece of open-world design, storytelling, and sandbox freedom. Its immersive world, complex characters, and darkly humorous narrative provide an unparalleled playground for virtual crime sprees. While its mature themes and occasional mission hiccups might deter some, for those willing to dive into the gritty underbelly of Los Santos, GTA V is an unforgettable experience that leaves a lasting mark long after the final credits roll. Just remember, with great power comes great responsibility... and a healthy dose of explosives for when things inevitably get chaotic.  -={ GAMEPLAY }=- Living, breathing sandbox: Los Santos and Blaine County overflow with vibrant detail, from bustling city streets to sun-baked deserts, offering endless opportunities for exploration and mayhem. Three unforgettable protagonists: Michael, Franklin, and Trevor are more than just playable characters; they're flawed, complex individuals with motivations that twist and turn as the story unfolds. Cinematic storytelling: From pulse-pounding action sequences to darkly comedic exchanges, GTA V delivers a rollercoaster ride of a narrative that rivals Hollywood blockbusters. Unparalleled online playground: GTA Online extends the experience with a constantly evolving world of cooperative heists, competitive showdowns, and player-created chaos.  Mature, often offensive content: Violence, nudity, and strong language are abundant, making GTA V unsuitable for younger audiences. Mission design can be uneven: Some missions feel repetitive or frustrating, occasionally breaking the narrative flow. Microtransactions in GTA Online: While not pay-to-win, some may find the optional in-game purchases for faster progression intrusive.  -={ PRICE }=-

Grand Theft Auto V stands as a towering achievement in the world of gaming, offering an open-world experience that's as exhilarating as it is expansive. Set in the sprawling, fictional city of Los Santos, this game seamlessly blends action, narrative depth, and boundless exploration.  From the moment you step foot into this virtual metropolis, the attention to detail is staggering. The city feels alive, teeming with a diverse population, bustling streets, and a vibrant ecosystem that reacts to your every move. The level of immersion is unmatched as you navigate a world that feels as dynamic and unpredictable as our own.  But beyond its stunning visuals and vast open world, it's the intertwining stories of three distinct protagonists that elevate this game to greatness. Michael, Franklin, and Trevor each bring their own flavor to the narrative, offering a multifaceted perspective on the criminal underworld and their intertwining lives. Their stories intertwine seamlessly, providing a rich and engaging storyline that keeps you on the edge of your seat.  The freedom this game affords is unparalleled. Whether you're causing mayhem in the city streets, engaging in high-speed pursuits, or simply soaking in the details of a sun-soaked skyline, there's always something to do. The breadth of activities, from adrenaline-fueled heists to leisurely rounds of golf, ensures that boredom is never an option.  Furthermore, GTA Online extends the experience far beyond the single-player campaign, allowing you to dive into a persistent multiplayer world. Collaborate with friends in heists, compete in races, or simply revel in the chaos of the open-world sandbox with countless other players.  In summary, Grand Theft Auto V isn't just a game; it's a living, breathing universe of its own. Its blend of immersive storytelling, boundless exploration, and unparalleled freedom cements its place as a titan in the gaming industry, offering an experience that continues to captivate and enthrall players worldwide.
