Grand Theft Auto Online, the multiplayer counterpart to the iconic GTA series, has unfortunately become a prime example of a game suffering due to profit-driven decisions by its publisher, Take-Two Interactive. The experience in GTA Online feels less like a player-focused venture and more like a relentless pursuit of monetization at the expense of player enjoyment.  One of the glaring issues is the inordinate focus on microtransactions. Take-Two seems more interested in squeezing every last dollar out of players than delivering a balanced and enjoyable gaming experience. The exorbitant prices for in-game items, coupled with the grind-heavy nature of the game, make it clear that the primary concern is the virtual wallet rather than player satisfaction.  Updates and new content often prioritize expensive in-game purchases rather than addressing core issues and improving the overall gameplay experience. It feels like Take-Two is pushing players toward spending real money to stay relevant in the game, creating a sense of frustration and exclusion for those who may not be willing or able to invest additional funds.  The rampant presence of hackers and modders further compounds the problem, creating an environment where legitimate players are left to fend for themselves against unfair advantages. Instead of addressing these concerns, Take-Two's focus appears to be on releasing new, money-making content, neglecting the need for a fair and secure gaming environment.  In conclusion, the current state of GTA Online reflects a disheartening prioritization of profit over player satisfaction by Take-Two Interactive. The game has devolved into a grind-heavy, microtransaction-laden experience that often leaves players feeling frustrated and alienated. It's a stark reminder that a game's success should be measured by more than just its financial gains.

In the city of Los Santos, a young hustler falls under the wing of a former criminal living a difficult retirement. Circumstances lead to the pair to have to do a job to pay off a debt – a job which gets national coverage and draws unwanted attention from a former partner, corrupt cops, ruthless movie moguls, rival gangs, aggressive fitness fanatics and many others.  I have played this game series on and off over the years but (criminally) did not play the former one based in Los Santos but instead rejoined with GTA4, a game I enjoyed but not one without its flaws. The good news with V is that the game keeps the strengths of the fourth game but makes many improvements which produce a much more fun and enjoyable experience across many aspects. The first thing to say is that the world of LS is technically amazing in terms of its attention to detail and beauty – it is hard to describe to people who decide they do not like these games, but to see a glorious sunset from a hillside, with perfect shadow effects and vegetation movement and know that someone designed and made this, not just filmed it, is something that hit me over and over throughout the game. The map is enjoyably large with diverse landscapes and character and I still find great pleasure in just going around in it even if I have nothing specific to do.  The story is solid enough for the game even if it is rather generic and overblown. The characters are quite clichéd in some regards. Michael's story for instance is not so imaginative and generally I found him the least of the characters. Franklin is similar but covered by him being the "intro" character, so I stayed close to him throughout. Trevor is a wonderfully violent and funny character and his entrance is memorable and really shakes the game up. The events of the story are necessarily overblown but this is part of the fun and generally I liked the flow to it. The many supporting characters are great fun and the energy and color of it all does cover up for the fact that the story is not really that complex or engaging at times. As it is though, it is about events and set-pieces and the game provides plenty of fun memorable missions (admittedly as well as a handful of awful ones), and in this way there are loads of missions to replay and enjoy and, most importantly, this game actually allows you to load them to do just that.  Side missions add color and fun and, although I do miss ongoing missions like the vigilante ones from IV, there is still plenty to do. The range of vehicles adds to this and I also enjoyed how much easier they are to drive than in the previous game. Weapon customization and the range of them provide fun destruction, although the police are a lot more aggressive in this game than in IV, so it is harder to go on a rampage and make it last. In theory the Online world offers endless gaming – I tried it for one evening and it was fun despite all the issues, but the community seemed messed up and very reliant on having an existing group of players – it looks fun but I'm just more of an offline player these days.  Grand Theft Auto V is a great game, even if you "only" play the days and days of content in the single player game. Technically the game is astounding with its attention to detail and just the sheer beauty of the audio and visual design of the whole world. The plot is solid enough to do the job while the characters (main and supporting) are colorful enough to engage while playing through missions which are mostly enjoyable and offer plenty of big set-pieces that are overblown and fun.

The online is an absolute joke, Riddled with modding trolls who crash your game, lock you in cages, run around with god mode teleporting you around. For every maybe 50 modders you'll find one that isn't nefarious. Every single online lobby has modding trolls in it and if you're lucky to find one without them, it will only be a matter of time before one joins. Rockstars solution? Invite only sessions which turn online mode into just a buggy extension of the story mode.  On top of that the latest chop shop update is riddled with soft locking bugs that require you to restart the game and start missions over again just to be able to complete them. For one of the most profitable games in gaming history you would think they would hire some professional game developers but apparently there's not many competent coders in the gaming industry anymore. I could write code at 13 years old more stable than this embarrassment.   Tldr: If you want to play online just find an RP server to play in, those server owners care about their private servers more than Rockstar does their own game.

"Grand Theft Auto V: A Timeless Triumph in Gaming Excellence"  Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐  Grand Theft Auto V stands as a towering achievement in the world of gaming, a testament to Rockstar Games' unrivaled ability to craft a virtual experience that transcends entertainment. Even years after its initial release, GTA V remains an absolute masterpiece, continually drawing players into the vibrant and chaotic world of Los Santos.  From the moment you step into the meticulously crafted city, the level of detail is staggering. Los Santos is a living, breathing entity, pulsating with energy and realism. The game's visuals are a feast for the eyes, showcasing Rockstar's commitment to pushing the boundaries of what is possible in an open-world setting. The attention to detail, from the bustling city streets to the serene countryside, is nothing short of awe-inspiring.  But what truly elevates GTA V to legendary status is its narrative brilliance. The intertwining stories of Michael, Franklin, and Trevor create a narrative tapestry that is as compelling as any Hollywood blockbuster. The characters are richly developed, each with their own motivations and quirks, making them more than just protagonists – they're complex, flawed individuals you can't help but invest in.  The heist missions, a hallmark of the GTA series, are the epitome of gaming excellence. The level of strategic planning, coupled with the freedom to execute plans in various ways, provides a sense of agency rarely seen in other games. Whether you're orchestrating a daring bank heist or engaging in high-speed pursuits, the gameplay is a perfect blend of challenge and sheer fun.  GTA V's soundtrack is a work of art in itself. The radio stations boast an eclectic mix of music, catering to diverse tastes, and the original score seamlessly complements the on-screen action. The attention to audio detail, from the roar of engines to the ambient sounds of the city, further immerses players in the game's world.  The longevity of GTA V is also owed to its dynamic online multiplayer mode, GTA Online. This ever-expanding world offers limitless opportunities for cooperative and competitive play, ensuring that the Grand Theft Auto experience extends far beyond the confines of the single-player campaign.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V isn't just a game; it's a cultural phenomenon that has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. Rockstar Games has crafted an experience that transcends its medium, delivering a perfect blend of narrative depth, visual splendor, and engaging gameplay. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the series, GTA V is an absolute must-play – a timeless triumph that continues to redefine the possibilities of interactive entertainment.

Ive played GTA ever since it was a thing. My favorites were San Andreas and Vice City. This game is utterly fantastic! Rockstar really went all out when they developed this masterpiece. You can do whatever you like in this game, consequences included of course! My 18 year old ask me to reinstall the game and in doing so I noticed that I had yet to review the game.  We have at the time of this review over 320 hours play time on the PC, with nearly double that on the PS4.   Funny thing is that we have never even completed the story campaign or played on the online portion.   The vast majority of the time was just my daughter and I making tons and tons of mayhem.   Well more me making the mayhem and her going on joy rides.  For years now she has asked me when GTVA 6 was coming out and she was so glad to hear that it was finally coming out in a couple more years.  I don't care what people say I am glad for her that she will finally have a female anti-hero to play as.  In the past we have always modded the game just so she could play as a female character.   I tire of people saying a game is "woke" just because it has a female lead.  Grow up and get with the current century is what I have to say and I am in my fifties so it isn't like I am a Millennial or Gen Z saying this.   If you don't like the character being female, do the opposite of what we did and mod the character to a male.  Anyway, it is amazing how much fun this game is just driving around and sightseeing even after all these years the game still holds up as a decent looking game.  Rockstar put heart and soul into the game and it shows.  By the way if you ever get a chance to meet Steven Ogg (voice of Trevor) in real life, do it.  The dude is hundred kinds of funny and a cool dude all around.

I had to request a refund because I couldn't even get to the game.   Trying to launch the game starts a launcher where you have to create an account and give personal information. That alone is very annoying, but I went through the process and thought that was that but I was sorely mistaken. After setting up an account and verifying my email, the launcher asked for an activation code and it provided no information on where to get it. I looked up online and apparently you can see this code if you log in with the created account on the rockstar website. I tried logging in and I was met with the worst captcha I have ever seen.  The captcha is very difficult, you need to match randomly generated rooms with several objects to a black-and-white map of the correct room layout. That is already challenging by itself, but the kicker is you have to do it 10 times. So I did my best and submitted their captcha 10 times. At the end it gave me the message "That was not quite right" and I had to start over.  I tried a couple more times but in the end I gave up and asked for a refund.  I don't understand why game publishers put these hoops to play their games, I already paid you so just let me access your game ffs.

At a discount, I totally recommend this game. It can be a fun bit. Unfortunately it didn't quite hit the mark for me, it becomes too repetitive. I feel like I spent most of my time in the game driving around the city.   The characters lack depth, appearing rather one-dimensional. Although they're intended as satirical figures, I found the critique of society lacking due to a lack of insightful storytelling. The excessive violence and torture felt out of place, lacking context and purpose, devoid of any impactful consequences. Some side missions were entertaining, yet others felt mundane and offered little reward, contributing to an overall weak storyline. Despite moments of entertaining banter between characters, there was a notable absence of character progression, leaving them seemingly unchanged from the game's start to near completion (I stopped right before the final heist).  Investing in properties within the game felt pointless; the money spent never returns, requiring an extensive grind to acquire them all, which didn't appeal to me.  Although there were enjoyable moments in the game, there were also instances where playing it left me with a sense of discomfort or unease. I won't delve into the portrayal of women in the game as objects or unable to exhibit ruthlessness. However, I found the inclusion of the therapist character puzzling. Was it intended as satire? Therapy remains taboo in many societies, so why not explore that notion? Why not play with society's perceptions of therapy? Instead, it seemed evident that the therapy sessions in the game were not genuine therapy but rather another aimless story arc, leaving me questioning its purpose and significance.   As for the online mode, it could potentially be enjoyable with friends. However, the high cost of items and the grind required were significant deterrents. While the concept of owning businesses seemed promising, the execution made it more of a chore than a pleasure. The delivery missions were time-consuming, the process of checking supplies at businesses in person felt tedious, and the excessive hours needed to play repetitive missions for incremental progress towards a new and improved business felt unreasonable.

Rockstar hates it's fanbase.  No singleplayer content updates in a decade. In multiplayer its so tedious and lengthy to grind money for vehicles businesses, and they do this on purpose so you will bend and buy Shark Cards for real money. So naturally, everyone just cheats and hacks for money or vehicles that they want. Rockstar responded by adding the MK2 oppressor, which made it so griefers can kill you freely time and time again.  The game also has no anticheat, so expect to be trapped in cages, teleported, and having your whole ass game bugged and crashed for making the mistake of joining a public lobby.   Game takes forever to load, which makes it even more painful because 7/10 times you will error out, be sent back to singleplayer, then have to rejoin multiplayer. whole process to launch the game 5-10 mins on good PCs.  Cayo Perico is the only really valid option for earning good money, which is a pretty cool heist but gets old grinding it time and time again. I dont have a problem with grinding in games, but when it revolves around driving 3.8 miles across the map to the same spots time and time again its just boring.  at least they brought back beloved features from GTA 4 and Vice City, like Vigilante missions!! oh wait... actually nope it took them 11 years to even add cop cars you can own, and still no vigilante missions.  Will Rockstar learn from these mistakes in GTA 6? doubtful, they make $2.5 million per day off Shark Cards. why change a winning formula?

Saw the GTA6 trailer, was very impressed, found out this was on sale for all of $10 including GTA Online. Scooped it. And I couldn't be happier.  The game is over 10 years old as of this commentary and I never got to play GTA4 yet, so it's been an enormous gap since I played GTA:SA on the PS2 (for reference, I've played since the very first GTA on the PS1, along with GTA2, GTA3, and GTA:VC as well).  The level of depth and immersion blew me away and would have had my teenage self floored because I played the older titles for their immersion. The story was so much fun to unravel, and I especially loved the Trevor character. The sheer amount of things to do were so many that I probably won't be able to 100% this game any time soon. But what really struck me was how faithful they were to referencing their older titles, including a car from GTA2 which is like the bastard child of the franchise it seems.  It's all the fun and frantic open-world destroy-everything GTA was always known for, with a massive city and a more rural county, chock full of weapons to play with, a load of cars of all different types that don't look repetitive after a while, new minigames and RPG elements,  The only sad thing is that, unlike GTA:SA, they had to remove the cities of San Fierro and Las Venturas, because that would have just made the world map so immense that this game would probably be so much bigger to install than it already is now. Still, with how deep they have been going, plus what I saw with the GTA6 trailer, who knows if they'll make some kind of alt-USA travel system to do this sort of thing and interconnect them along with Liberty City and Vice City (I'm looking at you, GTA Online).  100% recommend. It's the 5th major installment of a beloved franchise and it really delivers its entertainment, especially if you're into open-world immersion.

From a singleplayer perspective, the game is nothing short of an excellent experience, the story isn't the best in the series but is a great parody of modern america. Each of the three characters have their own narrative that collides with each other to feel unique and relevant to the main plot. The choice of endings are obvious and not necessarily compelling which leaves a half baked finish to the game. But the first 2/3 of the game have excellent character development and writing. The open world is great but feels empty. Its more or less a travel hub to go from point A to point B, but has a good level of detail and almost every part is used productively. The online portion of the game sucks and is boring, using the same open world as single player with very few things different or interesting to see and do. Unless you have a small army of people to play with, multiplayer is a cash grabbing joke. The whole of the single player is what holds up to this day. 9.0/10

EDIT: After playing all this time on GTA online ive come to the conclusion that this game is absolutely killed by hackers and mod menus, GTA online does not feel like a safe game to play and for that reason I cannot recommend paying for this product. I personally like playing in closed sessions enough for it to be playable but if I had known how bad this hacking issue was I probably never would have paid 14 bucks for the game. Any time I am in a public PC session I have distortion effects on my screen, am being teleported all over the map or am being bothered in some other way by a hacker. They will make you randomly explode when walking, invert your screen and basically play god while rockstar only bans those who abuse the in game currency and have no care for the well being of their players or the experience they have online. Great single player game, absolutely horrible online experience and it has made me realize that I need to see this fixed when GTA 6 comes out or i will not be purchasing it.   Been a few years since ive played GTA V and last time it was on a ps4, coming back now in 2023 its almost like a new game online in some ways. Very good game overall and honestly its still worth 60 bucks even after 10 years of its original release date. Fun solo, fun with others and lots to do either way with what is still one of the most immersive cities in gaming even after a decade.

Grand Theft Auto V (GTA 5) stands as a true masterpiece in the gaming world, combining a sprawling open world, gripping storytelling, and an unparalleled level of detail. From the bustling streets of Los Santos to the vast countryside and beyond, the game's world is a vibrant playground filled with limitless possibilities.  What sets GTA 5 apart is its seamless blend of action, exploration, and narrative. The game's three protagonists offer unique perspectives, each with their own compelling stories and motivations, creating a rich and engaging experience. Whether embarking on adrenaline-fueled heists, exploring the diverse landscapes, or simply causing chaos in the sandbox world, the game ensures there's always something exciting to do.  The attention to detail in GTA 5 is staggering, from the lifelike NPC behavior to the meticulously designed environments. The game's multiplayer component, GTA Online, further extends the experience, offering a dynamic and evolving online world where players can engage in various activities, missions, and challenges with friends or other players worldwide.  GTA 5's longevity and continued popularity stem from its constant updates, extensive modding community, and the dedication of the developers to refine and expand the game. It remains a benchmark in open-world gaming, delivering an unforgettable experience that keeps players coming back for more.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!  So not so recently Rockstar are slowing down and probably going to stop handing updates out to PC version of this game so if you really want to play go and play on a console while they still get updates.  Now why you shouldn't buy it really at all. Imagine this game is what we think of when we recycle a bottle, it get crushed down, a few bits of extra glass gets mixed in from somewhere and then turned into a new bottle. But at the core it's basically the same bottle. This is every single GTA update. Every one is recycled content. Ooo new mission added? It's basically drive, shoot a few people, look for a tiny thing not marked on the map drive miles back rinse and repeat. Want to earn good money? Either cayo or agency is your best bet, which would be fine but every damn mission is the exact same. All you're doing is the same thing over and over. It doesn't even feel like grinding it just feels like soul sucking stuff,  Rockstar are the worst. This game places first for most popular and most profitable game in the world. Breaking most records ever set. What do they do in return? Add subscription services, nerf money making methods, like cayo, prioritise consoles over pc, because Rockstar earn more from consoles than from PC, and increase the prices of everything while also nerfing vehicles and other things. I didn't even mention the fact they removed over 100 vehicles from the store only to make it so that GTA+ subscribers can get them. The worst part? It almost feels like a cult. You mention Rockstar is bad and have no shortage of evidence of this and then you get all these Rockstar supporters coming out of the woodwork telling you how you're wrong and Rockstar is better than god.  Yes I have nearly 1000 hours in this game and yes I still play from time to time but this is me telling you do not waste your money on this game on PC. Probably don't waste money on this game at all  Also Rockstar don't care. The game is full of modders and racist people and they don't do anything about it. Honestly one of the worst gaming companies going  TL/DR: Don't buy on PC - Rockstar bad - Everything sucks

Yah know, its your classic rouge like dungeon crawler. Uhhhhhh, I really like longsword paladin build, but I've heard that people do well with a rogue type build. The Steve Carrell cameo was really cool, he came on all like "im the joker baby" and then blowded up some buildings. I've never played GTA San Andreas. Shoutout Full Throttle energy drink. After enjoying some playtime everyone should take a brief moment to step outside to your nearest 7/11 or whatever boonk ass gas station you have around you and grab a nice cold delicious Full Throttle. It's the perfect thing to quench your thirst on a steamy hot day as well as give you that nice boost of energy. I find that it pairs well with a 6 milly upper decky zinneas and ferb and a brand new pack of newport golds to create the most delicious and palatable meal. Enjoy space coyboys!

People always say how the remastered is barely different from the old ps3, but I have played on a ps3, and let me tell you, theres a drastic difference, specifically the graphics, which people say (at least, the people I know) are barely changed. I see many differences in shapes, many differences in contrast.   My 2 gripes: Modders are a big thing in this game, expect to run into one or two a day. Also, some cutscenes have little to no work put into them, meaing that they are still good, but Rockstar apparently forgot to remaster certain parts. But don't worry, you won't see it often. Probably at most once or twice throughout your entier playthrough of the game.

This game sucks. Utterly. I thought this was Triple-A? 100 GB of garbage.  First of all, why the hell do I need a Rockstar account to launch the game? I'm not playing online, this shit should be opt out.  Second of all, to even log in to my Rockstar account, I have to go through multiple captchas (that will fail if you get even one answer wrong) that consist of 16-18 rounds of advanced spatial matching or 10 seconds of audio that you have to categorize.  Third of all, it won't even launch without 5 minutes of loading on a R symbol just to tell me that the game has already been launched, before quitting. Useless.  Fourth of all, get rid of the dog shit launcher. No game has EVER benefited from a launcher, save for perhaps MInecraft, where you need multiple profiles for different versions and mods.  I expect an AAA game to launch and work out of the box. What did I get? Half an hour of absolutely nothing. This game has been out for 10 years, and yet, somehow, it still needs work.

THE ONLINE IS TOO FRUSTRATING AND A MONEYGRAB  The singleplayer is an ok a regular gta game (story 8 to 10 hours of play maybe a bit more) where its ok till you have mission to earn money but when you finish them its a problem to earn (unless u go trought all the trouble of doing the investments in shares in the ingame interenet before the heists which is a PITA you need to do with a youtube guide)...(there are singleplayer cheats but not the money cheat like if the developers wanted you to feel poor and frustrated....)  online its just a nightmare it feels like a work but sorry im here to play not to work or i would have stayed extra hours at a real job, you start with nothing and you are going to get killed by other players a thousand times untill you get in private game to advance with some online missions and earn something so u can buy the basic weapons, but some missions cant be done without players in the game so you are forced to play with griefers (people that will purposelly ruin your mission because you cant literally do nothing against them when you start for lack of equipement) and cheaters which has filled the game and makes planes rain over u or just crashes the game spawning too much stuff or run around in godmode fucking everything up) and not only that it takes u soo much time to earn with missions that is as frustrting as a real job you dont like, and when you buy one of the basic things that you need to protect yourself from other players you are back to zero, unless u buy the in game money... with real money... -.- or u are lucky enough to find a hacker that drops money on you but guess what? [b]"[i]Why did I move here? Guess it's because Steam. You see.. screenshots, artwork, review, discussions, and guides. So, I bought it this year and I'll upload everything I have in mind.[/i]"[/b]  I rarely play the story mode, so I just go directly to Online mode to play with friends, doing heist and stuff. But after I bought it on Steam, I decided to play the story mode. Though I didn't finish all the random events / Strangers & Freaks, GTA V's story amazed me. Each mission, Each dialogue, Each moment is abso-fucking-lutely Grade-A. 3 protagonists with their life-stuff-problems to tell; A gangbanger, a father formely bank robber, and a fucking psychopath yet loyal become involved in a series of dangerous missions and heists, all while dealing with a dangerous group. [list] [*]Franklin with his desire to become something more & make something of himself which now he become a successful entrepreneur & multi-millionaire in GTA Online: The Contract. It's funny to see Franklin & Lamar doing their chit-chat. His best lines is always, [b]"[i]What?[/i]"[/b]  [*]Michael is a successfully retired & wealthy criminal that wanted to live a peaceful life with his family in Los Santos but slowly turns into a living nightmare. His best lines, [b]"[i]You forget a thousand things every day, pal. Make sure this is one of 'em.[/i]"[/b]  [*]Trevor. I don't know what to say but he's the fucking aggressive one. But I gotta say, he's very loyal & respects all those close to him. Trevor's first introduction include Johnny from GTA IV: TLAD and the moment where Johnny is beaten up till dead by Trevor. One of Trevor's best and funniest lines for me is when he is with Michael and tells him that he kidnapped Madrazo's wife, [b]"[i]What kind of fucking animal do you take me for? No, I didn't kill him. But I did kidnap his wife.[/i]"[/b] [/list] GTA IV also had 3 protagonists, but they were separated yet had one connected plot, while GTA V all in one standalone game and what's new is each protagonist has their own colours.   It's cool that GTA V has many awesome features. The main story now has playable heist missions, convertible cars can retract and deploy their top covers, weapons remain in the inventory after player died or busted, all the weapons are stored in inventory instead of replacing them, random events appeared randomly throughout San Andreas, and 3 protagonists in the same mission allowing you to switch characters during the mission.  Above all, giving me a Grade-A experience, a place with many activities, Online mode to have fun with friends and is still getting new content to this day (this year is Chop Shop), and [spoiler]it gives you patient report after finishing the story.[/spoiler]

The story/singleplayer mode is one of the best games in the genre and while it's difficult to mod there are some fun mods like LSPD for singleplayer that let you play as cops or SWAT.    The official online gets a lot of hate but honestly it's not that bad these days. I only learned this when I started playing again recently, but last year they made some major changes that have reduced the frequency of griefers in public lobbies, as well as made some MASSIVE changes to the grind. You can now run just about any mission and heist prep on a private lobby, meaning you are effectively 100% safe from cheaters or random griefers when running these missions. This has effectively nullified most of the grinding as the only thing preventing you from farming gun running missions before was griefers, and you can easily get millions in a day for doing practically nothing through gun running missions, uninterrupted by players trying to kill you with jets.

I have loved every GTA game; I bought it on release for PS1, GTA3, Vice, San Andreas on PS2.  Single player is excellent and worth buying if you haven't already experienced it.  However, GTA online for PC is absolutey f*cked and a fentanol-filled dumpster fire rolling down Vinewood Hills.  So much so that R* has already abandoned GTA6 2 years before its release on PC.  If you're buying GTA5 online then its probably so you can play it modded anyway or want to RP.   "If you're not cheatin', you're not tryin'." -Eddie Guerrero.  GTA5 on console may only be on life-support, (with GTA6 around the corner sucking up most of the development team,) but at least it's actually still getting support. Come join me on PS5 for a [strike]good[/strike] much better experience.

[h1]I'm not a criminal, I'm a entrepreneur[/h1] [i]See you in GTA 6, if i'm alive then...[/i]  Grand Theft Auto V, the latest instalment in the controversial yet wildly popular franchise, delivers just that. First released in 2013, the game has since been remastered and optimised for PC, offering players a chance to experience this sprawling crime epic in stunning 4K resolution and 60fps.   Set in the fictional city of Los Santos, GTA 5 provides a vivid recreation of Southern California and all the seedy underbelly it encapsulates. The game offers a scathing and satirical take on the American Dream through its interweaving story of three criminals from very different walks of life.  [h2]Storyline[/h2] As you progress through the game, you are confronted with moral dilemmas and complex relationships in a world filled with crime, corruption, and the constant pursuit of power.  What sets GTA 5 apart is its unparalleled attention to detail and the sheer scope of its open-world environment. Los Santos evokes the feeling that it is a living, breathing city bustling with pedestrians, traffic, and countless activities to engage in. You could participate in street races, play a round of golf, enjoy a bike ride along the coastline, or visit a strip club.  GTA 5's story mode is a mammoth task, with any one of the characters - Michael, Franklin, or Trevor - providing enough narrative for an entire game. Combined, they offer an intricate plotline with the highest standard of writing. Once introduced, you can freely switch between these characters, each with personality traits and strengths.  Franklin, a streetwise hustler with a good heart, can drive in slow motion. Michael, in witness protection, tries to leave his criminal past behind. Trevor is an unpredictable and volatile character who thrives on chaos.  [h2]Gameplay[/h2] players can engage in various forms of gameplay, such as completing missions, participating in heists, and exploring the open world.  [h3]Shooting Mechanics[/h3] While the base shooting mechanics have held up reasonably well since 2013, there are now third-person cover shooters that feel more fluid. However, GTA 5's shooting is still immensely enjoyable.  [h3]Missions[/h3] With multiple approaches to complete objectives, you can tailor missions to your preferred playstyle. Whether employing stealth, direct confrontation, or strategic planning, the diversity of options ensures that gameplay never feels repetitive or monotonous.  The variety of missions and mechanics guarantees that players remain engaged and excited. You may enact a meticulously planned heist, engage in intense gang warfare, or embark on an adrenaline-fueled chase sequence.  [h3]Customisation[/h3] Players can shape unique experiences by changing outfits, customising vehicles, or exploring the open-world environment. The plethora of choices for players adds replayability even after completing the main story.  [h3]Open World[/h3] Players are granted almost total freedom to explore the vast metropolis of Los Santos and the surrounding countryside.  Driving through the city evokes a palpable sense of place, with responsive vehicle handling and collision physics creating an authentic experience, whether navigating dense traffic in a sports car or off-roading in a 4x4. Piloting aircraft opens up new vistas, from scenic coastal flights to heart-pounding aerial stunts. The open waters surrounding the city are equally inviting to explore by boat or submarine.  An astonishing array of side activities are scattered worldwide, from recreational pursuits like golf, tennis, and cycling to more illicit diversions. Stranger encounters introduce memorably eccentric characters and side missions with compelling self-contained stories. Collectibles like letter scraps and spaceship parts encourage exploration while revealing more about the world and characters, but no one knows this.  [h3]Driving Mechanics[/h3] The driving mechanics of GTA 5 are unrivalled, and constantly comparing other open-world driving games to GTA games like Just Cause, Watch_Dogs and Saints Row, just to name a few, doesn't even come close to the pure satisfaction I get from the multitude of vehicles I have at my disposal and how vastly differing they all feel to navigate through the streets of Los Santos.  [h2]Stunning Visuals for 2013[/h2] Everything from the character models to the buildings and terrain is meticulously detailed3. The lighting and particle effects are also remarkably realistic, showcasing beautiful sunrises and sunsets and how dust kicks up from off-road driving. These visuals, combined with the seamless transition between the city and the open countryside, make exploring the world a visually arresting experience.  [h3]Cinematic Soundtrack[/h3] The original score for GTA 5 was composed to create tension during action sequences and a sense of ambience while free roaming or completing mundane tasks. The game also features licensed music spread across 15 radio stations, including hip-hop, rock, and country genres. Players can simply cruise down the freeway and enjoy the scenery while listening to their favourite tunes.  [h2]Online[/h2] After nearly a decade on the market, GTA 5 Online remains a polarising experience. For all its ambition and scale, the game struggles to balance engaging open-world gameplay with an incentive structure that pushes players toward griefing and other toxic behaviour. Though recent updates have aimed to curb the worst excesses of the community, the problems run deeper in the very framework of how GTA 5 Online functions.   If you can find a group of like-minded players, there are glimpses of the promised fun and hijinks. But for most, GTA 5 Online is a cautionary tale of how even the most sprawling virtual worlds can feel empty when not built with community in mind. You may enter with an open mind, ready for adventure, but leave with a sobering reminder of the darker impulses that emerge when there are no consequences. For a game that holds up a mirror to society, it's a reflection we may not wish to see.  [h2]Conclusion[/h2] Overall, Grand Theft Auto V is an impressively ambitious and complex game that pushes the envelope of open-world gaming and storytelling. The massive scope of its gameplay and intricate story should satisfy even the most hardcore GTA fans. While not without its flaws and controversies, GTA V is a technical and creative marvel that provides hours of entertainment and escapism.   Suppose you want to immerse yourself in a satirical take on modern culture with engaging characters and non-stop action. In that case, you'll find it hard to beat this sprawling crime epic. With so much to see and do in the world of Los Santos, GTA V stands out as one of the most compelling open-world experiences in gaming.

Game requires admin rights.  Launcher requires admin rights.  Game requires Steam to run with admin rights.  Even with all rights granted the game is perpetually stuck in a loop where Steam launches Rockstar launcher, windows flags that as suspicious, asks if I want to allow it to make changes to my device, I reluctantly click "yes" and am greeted with the Rockstar launcher window where I have to click "launch from Steam" (uhh, I literally just launched from Steam).  This brings up an error window that says it failed to launch.  Verifying game files does not solve this problem.  I've owned the game for 9 days and have had this issue 3 times already.  I don't play online; I'm only trying to play story mode but the game no longer launches.  Steam refused my refund since I'm over 2hrs but save yourself the trouble...if you don't already own this old game, don't buy it here.  Or maybe even at all.

Grand Theft Auto V: A Tale of Two Realities – A Stellar Campaign Overshadowed by Online Chaos  My experience with Grand Theft Auto V has been a rollercoaster of emotions, swinging between awe and frustration. While the single-player campaign is undeniably cool and engaging, the online portion of the game has left a bitter taste in my mouth due to the rampant hacking issues that plague the experience.  Let's start with the positive aspect: the campaign. Rockstar Games has crafted a narrative masterpiece with an engaging storyline, diverse characters, and a sprawling open-world that begs to be explored. The single-player experience is a testament to the studio's prowess in storytelling and game design, providing players with a captivating journey through the criminal underworld of Los Santos.  However, the real allure of Grand Theft Auto V lies in its online mode. It's a shame that Rockstar Games seems to turn a blind eye to the overwhelming hack scene that has infested the online realm. Hackers run rampant, and their presence transforms what should be a thrilling multiplayer experience into a chaotic and frustrating mess. From money hacks to invincibility cheats, the online portion of the game feels like a lawless Wild West where legitimate players are left to fend for themselves against the onslaught of malicious exploits.  The sad truth is that Rockstar Games, despite their immense resources and player community feedback, has not done enough to rein in the hack scene across all their games. This negligence not only undermines the integrity of the online experience in Grand Theft Auto V but also casts a shadow over the multiplayer aspects of their other titles. It's disheartening to see a company of such stature failing to address a persistent issue that has been affecting their player base for far too long.  As much as the campaign showcases Rockstar's brilliance, the allure of the online world is where the real fun is at. The fact that this experience is marred by the unchecked proliferation of hackers is a major letdown. Until Rockstar Games takes decisive action to curb the hack scene and create a more secure online environment, Grand Theft Auto V's online mode will remain a frustrating and unfulfilling playground for those seeking genuine multiplayer enjoyment.

I have not really played any video games for thirty years.  A friend shared a few games with me recently and well, here we are...   WOW!!!   GTA V has my mind blown. I'm certain that most people are used to the speed, aggressive action, and the controllers with dozens of buttons and vibration features, but beyond all that is an insanely entertaining way to spend some time.  I'm so impressed with the story line and the game play that I've barely been able to appreciate the hard work and talent expressed by the graphics(which are otherworldly when compared to Metroid, Shinobi, Contra, etc.  In short, I cracked open a door and baby-stepped back into an awesome world that all started with GTA V.  Highly recommended, thanks for taking the time.

Gameplay - 8/10 Whilst some people may dislike the Rockstar gameplay formula as it certainly isn't for everyone, I like it and it has made me come back to the story missions of this game about 3 times across all the platforms that I have played it on now. The gun play in this game is satisfying for me as the guns really feel like they have power behind them. Driving mechanics are fun and easy.  Story - 6/10 I wasn't too interested for most of the story and, whilst there were some cool mission based around the story and some funny moments in the cut scenes, it was mainly the gameplay that kept me playing.  Graphics - 7/10 The graphics of this game still hold up quite well today and I'm sure they will for a while. There are little details in some models that make the game world feel real and like there are many moving parts to each object. Explosion and fire effects still look good and are satisfying to watch.  Performance - 9/10 I had some performance issues when I first started playing this game on PC but I have put that down to driver issues as they have disappeared since.  Online - 6/10 Personally, the online never really interested me much but I think that it is mainly down to the fact that I don't have a group of friends that I can play it with to properly get into it and that would keep me coming back. There is plenty to do in the online for people who like that sort of stuff though. I just personally prefer single player games.  Overall - 9/10 If you haven't played this game yet then I would recommend that you do so before GTA 6 releases within the next 583.29 years.

A Modern Gaming Masterpiece: GTA V Review Rating: ★★★★★ After investing a staggering 793 hours into Grand Theft Auto V, I can confidently say that it is an absolute gaming masterpiece. Rockstar Games has once again delivered an unparalleled open-world experience that surpasses all expectations. The level of detail in Los Santos is mind-blowing. Every street corner, building, and NPC feels alive and vibrant, creating an immersive environment that constantly begs to be explored. The attention to detail is remarkable, showcasing a level of craftsmanship seldom seen in gaming. The storyline is gripping, filled with unexpected twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. Each character has a distinct personality, and their intertwining narratives provide a deep and engaging experience that is both humorous and emotionally charged. The gameplay, too, is exceptional. The controls are smooth and intuitive, allowing for seamless transitions between driving, shooting, and participating in various activities. From high-speed police chases to intense heists and exhilarating stunt jumps, there is always something to do and a sense of freedom that is unparalleled. GTA V boasts an expansive multiplayer mode that further amplifies the game's longevity. Whether it's joining a crew and engaging in epic battles or simply exploring the vast open world with friends, the multiplayer component provides endless hours of entertainment and camaraderie. Furthermore, the constant updates and DLCs released by Rockstar Games have kept the game fresh and exciting. From new vehicles and weapons to challenging missions and events, the developers' commitment to the game's ongoing support is commendable. However, it's worth mentioning that the game does contain mature content and violence, which may not be suitable for all audiences. While it successfully explores darker themes, it's important for players to approach it with maturity and awareness. All in all, Grand Theft Auto V is an exceptional game that has undoubtedly become a cultural phenomenon. With its stunning visuals, captivating narrative, and an expansive open world that begs to be explored, it is a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. Despite the countless hours invested, the game continues to surprise and captivate me, making it a definite contender for the title of the greatest game of all time. I cannot recommend GTA V enough. Whether you're a fan of the series or new to the world of GTA, this game is a true masterpiece that should not be missed. Happy gaming! If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients:  1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie  Directions:  1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

NB: I haven't been a fan of the series (though I enjoyed RDR2 a lot), so if you are or want to try it out, maybe this review isn't for you. Also, as I understand, the overwhelming majority of people now buy it for Online, which I also don't care about, this is about the single-player mode.  So, I've played quite a few huge sandbox games. I've even 100% (or close to 100%) completed quite a few. Why does GTA V not work for me in that regard?  Well, really, the answer is quite simple: despite being a huge open world with many, many activities you [b]could[/b] do, I don't particularly care to actually do any of them. It is honestly quite baffling as to how much work the game developers have put into things that just seem... completely out of place and pointless. You can do parachute jumps! You can play tennis! You can do plane stunts! You can do a triathlon! You can buy property! You can participate in car races! You can do yoga! You can play golf! You can buy and sell stock on the stock market! You can use your inconvenient phone camera which makes you stand completely still while you use it to take pictures of wildlife that kills you in one hit!  But is that really why I'd play a Grand Theft Auto game?  Sure, there are still the main missions, and a few side ones, but completing ALL of them took me less than 40 hours, and that included some messing around, which is quite a feat for a large sandbox.  But here's the thing: I didn't [b]actually[/b] complete all of the side missions. Why? Well, because I have no way to know how to do that.  One issue is that some side missions seem to be locked behind buying particular properties, which is not only completely not-obvious (especially since not all of them do that), but also requires you to either finish the game (to get any money to spare), or abuse the stock market system, which, due to its own quirks, can be quite hard to do without a guide. Others are "random", as in, while they have specific points where they can trigger, you wouldn't know what these points are (without a guide), and they might [b]not[/b] trigger there even if you're nearby purely by chance. Yet others require even more obscure ways of starting them.  Lastly, there are several collect-a-thon missions in the game, but, seriously, screw them. No markers, no clues, no nothing. Apparently, one of the protagonist trio can use his dog to search for [b]some[/b] of the collectibles, but the game never explained it or that it's even possible, so good luck figuring that without a guide. And even then, you'd need to run around the huge map to do this.  It's a good thing that I didn't even try to get 100%, though, because, apparently, one of the completion marks requires the use of a separate mobile app... which has been, at this point, removed from stores. Womp-womp.  Gameplay-wise, GTA V feels smoother than GTA IV, though that's not saying much. The flight controls are as horrendous as ever, going for completely misplaced realism. The police are cheating bastards who know what your location is at any point in time, can spawn out of thin air, and have cars that rubberband to you no matter what, making upgrading cars for speed pretty much pointless. Your health regenerates only up to half, and there are rarely any health pick ups (and no armor pick ups), forcing you to stay in cover most of the time in a shootout.  The story is not very gripping either, mostly concerning not particularly likable people doing things for extremely petty reasons. The best part of the game are heist missions, purely because of how you get to choose how they go, even if in reality there aren't that many ways your choices affect them, bar the one major one on the selected approach method. Unfortunately, there are only a few of those throughout the entire game, and I honestly don't know why else would I recommend it.

Great game especially with friends. The graphics are really good and the game is very well optimized as well (even an entry level computer of today could run it well). There are also lots of things to do in this game. Stuff like messing around, missions, heists, mini games, story mode, etc. Like seriously, theres an insane amount of stuff to do. The game has so much play value.   What I like most in the game was the heists, the challenging content of the game (doomsday heist), playing with friends, collecting cars and weapons, messing around, and the environment.   The game is worth every penny, I highly recommend it!

I kept playing to see why so many people love the online side of this game and I eventually came to the realisation that it is just a bit shi.t and people must be complete morons to actually enjoy it.  Like it's GTA, it was fun to go back to something I've not played in nearly ten years, it's nice to revisit the map and having some new characters, campaigns, vehicles and things to do but that's it. The game has not improved, combat and character movement is still awful, driving gets boring quickly and all the new jobs, missions, heists and vehicles feel tacked on, nothing actually feels new or very interesting.  The worst thing is the actual online side, everyone is there just to prevent regular players attempting missions or trying to start missions. I understand people messing about with new vehicles they've bought but it's just so lame that that's what some people do every night of their lives, it's almost as douche as buying hacks or even worse buying in game money from Rockstar. My worst personal experience was a multiplayer mission where at the end everyone was spawned together so one players killed everyone else and stole everyone's money. Good Game design.   You can get away from all the other online players by selecting a new session and invite only, but this only really helps if you want to play solo. My main interest in the game was to play coop with a buddy, it's doable but it's a total ball ache as you will spend almost half your time in loading screens, you can't just play together as you constantly have to invite the other player to do something and if you finish a mission together then you are both put back into separate lobbies.  I wish I hadn't bothered with the online, the only thing that it's taught me is that Rockstar seriously needs to pull some magic off for GTA6 to be good, I'm sure it's going to look incredible and be an insanely detailed world, just like RDR2, but they need to reassess their gameplay unless the only people they are catering for are twelve year old boys with ADHD.

Logged 888 hours into GTA V – a 2013 gem that's aged like virtual cheese (in a good way). Graphics are surprisingly solid, and my character's dance moves are... well, they're a work in progress that's not being worked on.  The plot? It's not Pulitzer material, but it's like that B-movie you secretly love. Unlocked every achievement after countless hours, so you can trust my expertise. If you haven't debated life's mysteries with NPCs or turned Los Santos into your own chaotic playground, you're missing out. And seriously, if you haven't tried flying a jet onto the Maze Bank Tower, you're not living your best GTA life.

Because of Rockstar's over-restrictive DRM, I am unable to play a singleplayer game I paid money for.  To be able to play the game at all (even "offline" play), you need to sign into a Rockstar Social Club account.   Having first launched the game years ago I used a Rockstar account I no longer have access to. No big deal I thought, I'd just make a new one and sign in.  Nope. You are not allowed to use a different Rockstar account than the one you first used with the Steam account. I opened a support ticket with Rockstar and they told me tough cookies.   So I am unable to play a game I own, despite having bought it on this very Steam account. Never buy from Rockstar I suppose.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Brawnys recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients:  1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter 2 cups granulated sugar 1 cup all-purpose flour 1 cup unsweetened cocoa powder 1/2 teaspoon baking powder 1/2 teaspoon salt 4 large eggs 2 teaspoons vanilla extract 1 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips (optional) 1 cup chopped nuts (optional) Instructions:  Preheat Oven: 1. Preheat your oven to 175°C. Grease the baking pan or line it with parchment paper. 2. In a medium-sized saucepan, melt the butter over low heat. Remove from heat once melted. 3. In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the sugar, flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt. 4. Add the melted butter to the dry ingredients and stir until well combined. 5. Beat in the eggs one at a time, ensuring each egg is fully incorporated before adding the next one. Stir in the vanilla extract. 6. If desired, fold in chocolate chips and chopped nuts to add extra texture and flavor. 7. Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan and spread it evenly. Bake in the preheated oven for about 25-30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out with a few moist crumbs (not wet batter). 8. Allow the brownies to cool in the pan for about 10-15 minutes, then transfer them to a wire rack to cool completely before cutting. 9. Once the brownies are completely cooled, cut them into squares or rectangles. Enjoy!  Feel free to customize this recipe to suit your preferences. You can add ingredients like caramel swirls, different types of nuts, or even a sprinkle of sea salt on top for an extra special touch. Enjoy your delicious homemade brownies!

"Grand Theft Auto V" (GTA V), developed by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games, stands as a magnum opus in the gaming industry, redefining open-world experiences and narrative-driven gameplay. Originally released in 2013 and continually updated, GTA V remains an enduring masterpiece that seamlessly blends a vast, immersive world with compelling storytelling, unparalleled attention to detail, and a plethora of activities that captivate players for hours on end.  The visual spectacle of Los Santos, the game's fictional representation of Los Angeles, is nothing short of breathtaking. The meticulously crafted cityscape, diverse landscapes, and dynamic weather effects contribute to an ever-evolving and living environment. Character animations, facial expressions, and the sheer scale of the game world showcase Rockstar's commitment to pushing the boundaries of gaming visuals.  At the narrative core of GTA V are three protagonists—Michael, Franklin, and Trevor—each with a unique personality, background, and skill set. The intersecting storylines provide a rich and multifaceted narrative that explores themes of crime, ambition, and the pursuit of the American Dream. The character development is masterful, creating a compelling emotional connection with each protagonist, even as players navigate the morally ambiguous world they inhabit.  The open-world design of GTA V is a triumph in player freedom. The sprawling city and surrounding areas offer an abundance of activities, from high-stakes heists and adrenaline-fueled car chases to more leisurely pursuits like golf and yoga. The attention to detail extends to the dynamic ecosystem of the city, with pedestrians going about their lives, engaging in conversations, and reacting realistically to the player's actions.  The game's driving and combat mechanics are refined and responsive, offering a satisfying blend of realism and accessibility. The vast array of vehicles, weapons, and customization options provides players with the tools to approach missions and free-roaming in their unique style.  GTA Online, the multiplayer component of the game, further expands the experience. It allows players to engage in various cooperative and competitive activities, build criminal enterprises, and explore Los Santos with friends. The ongoing support from Rockstar with regular updates, new content, and events ensures that the online experience remains dynamic and engaging.  The soundtrack of GTA V deserves special mention, featuring an eclectic mix of genres and a curated radio station lineup that adds depth to the game's atmosphere. The voice acting, led by stellar performances from the main cast, enhances the overall cinematic quality of the experience.  While the game has received criticism for its mature content and occasionally controversial themes, it undeniably represents a pinnacle in interactive storytelling, offering players an unprecedented level of agency in a virtual world.  In conclusion, "Grand Theft Auto V" stands as a titan in the gaming industry, seamlessly blending an expansive open-world environment with a gripping narrative, exceptional character development, and an array of activities that keep players enthralled. Its enduring popularity and ongoing relevance speak to its status as a benchmark for what a video game can achieve. GTA V is not just a game; it's a cultural phenomenon that continues to shape the landscape of interactive entertainment.

Title: A Decade-Long Journey through Los Santos: GTA V's Lasting Impact  Grand Theft Auto V, a virtual playground that has been a cornerstone of my gaming existence since I first stepped into the sun-soaked streets of Los Santos at the age of 12, continues to be a defining and integral part of my gaming life. As I reflect on an immersive 11-year journey, it's clear that GTA V isn't merely a game; it's a dynamic and enduring chapter in the story of my digital adventures.  Released in 2013, GTA V's Los Santos immediately captivated me with its breathtaking scale and attention to detail. The city was a living, breathing entity, teeming with diverse neighborhoods, iconic landmarks, and a vast, open landscape that begged to be explored. From the sunsets over Mount Chiliad to the vibrant lights of the Vinewood strip, each corner of the map became a familiar, yet endlessly captivating, part of my virtual world.  The narrative brilliance, which has become a trademark of the Grand Theft Auto series, found new heights in GTA V. The trio of protagonists – Michael, Franklin, and Trevor – brought unique perspectives to a sprawling tale of crime, camaraderie, and the pursuit of the American Dream. The heist missions, a standout feature, were not just adrenaline-pumping escapades but also strategic challenges that required meticulous planning and execution.  GTA V's success didn't stop at its single-player narrative; the introduction of Grand Theft Auto Online (GTAO) added an entirely new dimension to the experience. For the past six years, my friends and I have embarked on countless adventures in Los Santos, from coordinated heists to wild races and impromptu free-roam shenanigans. The ever-expanding world of GTA Online, with its regular updates and new content, has kept the virtual landscape fresh and dynamic.  The game's attention to detail extends beyond the narrative and into its satirical take on modern society. The radio stations, television shows, and in-game internet provided a sharp commentary on everything from politics to pop culture, enhancing the game's immersion and creating a world that felt eerily reflective of our own.  The gameplay mechanics, refined over the years, offered a perfect blend of action, exploration, and a sandbox for creativity. The character-switching feature, improved driving physics, and an extensive range of activities ensured that Los Santos never felt stale, even after countless hours of play.  While GTA V garnered widespread acclaim, it wasn't without its controversies and critiques, particularly in relation to the microtransaction model in GTA Online. Yet, these issues did little to diminish the overall impact of a game that has been a constant companion throughout my adolescence and early adulthood.  As I reminisce about the countless hours spent in Los Santos, the friendships forged in chaotic online sessions, and the enduring allure of the game's open world, it's clear that GTA V is more than just a form of entertainment. It's a nostalgic time capsule, a digital diary chronicling my growth as a gamer and the evolving landscape of the gaming industry over the past 11 years.  In the grand tapestry of my gaming life, GTA V stands tall as a masterpiece that transcends the medium. It's not just a game; it's a virtual home, a canvas for endless adventures, and a testament to the lasting impact that video games can have on the fabric of our lives.

Everything was familiar and vivid.I have traveled to this hometown through video countless times.I finished the offline story again, no, I don't know how many times I relived their story, but this time I witnessed it myself.After many years, it still gave me a shock, about the stories of the protagonists, about my second hometown, Los Angeles.Driving in the street car in Los Angeles, playing Sleeping Walk.My childhood has drifted away, but it won't, forever the capital of Los Angeles, a generation of classics.After many years, I remember when the teacher asked me how to describe the heavy snow, and now I have the answer. Simply the best game in the entire series, and holds up nearly a decade after its release. I have no idea why I never got around to playing this sooner, but I'm glad I finally did. Every main character is likable and hilarious in their own way; even the d@mn dog, Chop, had me at hello.  Don't worry about how messy the online experience is. This is not a game you should be playing for the PVP. This very busy slice of San Andreas is more than detailed and vivid enough to keep you busy for a very long time. I've never met a GTA game that wasn't worth booting up just to go for a cruise and get absolutely nothing done and still feel like a satisfying time was had. Five does this best - I daresay better than my previous favorite entry in the franchise, Vice City. There is plenty to keep you busy until 6 comes out in a few years - and no doubt, that announcement is gonna drive a lot of people, even a whole new generation of  gamers, back here to 5 while they wait with baited breath. At the prices it usually goes on sale for - $10-15 - it's still money well spent. There's no better way to get your fix until the next installment hits.  There's a lot of wasted time still in my future with this game, I have foreseen it.

The game is poorly optimized and will run at low fps while GPU usage stays low.  Inflation on nearly everything which means you have to replay the same boring heist a hundred times to actually afford anything decent. Overall the game has become the parody in which it once used to make fun of which is quite sad when you think about it. A shame as the game has alot of potential. Honestly I love this game. I have played it on many accounts in the past. The reason I wouldn't recommend this game to other people is because GTA Online is overrun by people with virtual powers to freeze your game. So lets say you see an easy kill inside a store or you want to run over a group of people fighting, it really doesnt matter the scenario - you can bet one out of the many players, who may or may not be there, has a tool on his machine which can log your IP (which honestly doesnt do anything - especially with a VPN), and they can do things like freeze your character, spawn hundreds of vehicles on top of you, and even edit your stats and money in-game. The bottom line is this: people in GTA Online are emotionally challenged. They get angry too easily and when you anger the wrong person they unleash glitches from the nether onto your GTA character faster than you can blink. This will disrupt your gameplay and might even frustrate the sh*taki out of you, but if you show them they got to you then they've won. So I do not recommend this game for anyone who is an emotional basketcase. Rockstar and Steam really ought to start making gamers take psychological tests before selling them games like this. The entire GTA Online community is toxic when it comes to in-game mechanics and dealing with getting your character hurt. I mean that is the point of the game, but they take it so seriously that they react like you've just taken a leak in their cheerios.

There is something for everyone in GTA Online. Whether you want to race cars, fly planes, rob banks, or just explore the vast world of Los Santos, there is something to keep you entertained. The game is also constantly being updated with new content, including new missions, vehicles, weapons, and clothing.  One of the best things about GTA Online is the sense of community. There are millions of players from all over the world who are always looking for new people to play with. You can join crews, create your own custom jobs, or just hop into a random session and meet new people.  If you are looking for a fun, challenging, and rewarding online experience, then GTA Online is the game for you. It is a game that you can keep coming back to for years to come.  Here are some of the things that make GTA Online so great:  Massive world to explore: Los Santos is a sprawling city with a lot to see and do. There are mountains to climb, beaches to swim at, and plenty of hidden secrets to discover. Variety of activities: There are a ton of different things to do in GTA Online. You can race cars, fly planes, rob banks, play golf, or just explore the world. Constantly evolving: Rockstar Games is constantly adding new content to GTA Online. This includes new missions, vehicles, weapons, and clothing. Sense of community: There is a large and active community of players in GTA Online. You can join crews, create your own custom jobs, or just hop into a random session and meet new people. If you are looking for a fun, challenging, and rewarding online experience, then GTA Online is the game for you. It is a game that you can keep coming back to for years to come.  Here are some of the continuing downloadable content that has been released for GTA Online:  Heists: Heists are some of the most challenging and rewarding activities in GTA Online. They require teamwork and coordination to complete, and they can be a lot of fun. Special Events: Rockstar Games often hosts special events in GTA Online. These events can include new modes, vehicles, or clothing. Updates: Rockstar Games releases regular updates for GTA Online. These updates add new content, fix bugs, and improve the game. The continuing downloadable content for GTA Online is one of the things that makes the game so great. It keeps the game fresh and exciting, and it gives players a reason to keep coming back.

I wanted to hit recommend because both single-player and online have some great moments and I do think it's worth playing (maybe on sale though), BUT (and this is a BIG but) there are just WAY too many cheaters with mod-menus that grief you and are invincible. Like I get that Online is SUPER grindy to get to the good stuff, and I totally understand people using these cheat menus to give themselves ranks and or cash (Who actually buys Shark Cards? lol), but there is absolutely no reason to take out a low rank level 10 doing a job when you are an invincible rank level 420+ cheating with a mod menu. Too many hacking griefers in this game that Rockstar doesn't ban. So I just can't recommend currently.  It's good. (When it isn't grindy and you aren't being griefed by modmenu cheaters)

This game has been around for almost a decade. It gets a lot of love that is well deserved and its even better on PC then it was on console when I originally played it at launch. I don't think I need to elaborate on the story or the game mechanics, it is your typical GTA style open world sandbox affair and no one in the business does it better then Rockstar Games. It'll be interesting to see if their next release is as interesting seeing as this style of game has started to feel stale, at least that's how I felt about RDR2. I know that people loved that title, however, it was a little bit drawn out for my tastes. I will be replaying that one too just to give it another shake a few years later. I can't say that this is a bad game, and tbh, it is my second fav in the franchise behind Vice City.

Today, I want to introduce you to a highly anticipated game, Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V). The game is an action-adventure game developed by Rockstar Games and first released in 2013.  First, let's talk about the graphics of the game. Grand Theft Auto V uses advanced graphics technology to make the scenes and characters in the game very realistic. Whether it is the architecture of the city, the natural scenery or the facial expressions of the characters, every detail is carefully designed to make people feel like they are in it. At the same time, the animation effects of the game are very smooth, making people feel like watching a Hollywood blockbuster.  Next, let's talk about the plot of the game. Grand Theft Auto V takes place in the fictional city of Los Angeles and allows players to take on the roles of three different characters: Mike, Trevor and Franklin. Each of these three characters has its own story arc, and players need to complete missions to advance the story. The whole story is tight, gripping and irresistible.  Finally, let's talk about how the game is played. Grand Theft Auto V is an action adventure game in which players are required to drive, shoot, sneak and more. At the same time, there are a variety of tasks for the player to complete, these tasks not only test the player's operating skills, but also make the game more interesting.  Overall, Grand Theft Auto V is a very good game. Its beautiful picture, compact plot, diverse gameplay, people can not extricate themselves. If you love action adventure games, then this game must not be missed!

"Who’s joe?" a distant voice asks.  Instantly everyone nearby hears the sound of 1,000s of bricks rapidly shuffling towards his location.  The earth itself seemed to cry out in agony, until finally the ground itself split open and a horrific creature crawled from the ground, covered in mucus and tar.  ”Joe Momma…” the creature whispered.  The man cried out in pain as he disintegrated into dust, and the whole world fell silent in fear.  "I did a little trolling." the wretched creature remarked before burrowing back into the earth.

I must admit that I had high hopes for Grand Theft Auto 5, but my experience left me incredibly disappointed. While the game offers an open-world environment with plenty of opportunities for chaos and mayhem, it falls far short in terms of diversity and inclusion, and this issue significantly tarnished my overall enjoyment.  The primary problem I encountered was with the game's three main characters: Michael, Franklin, and Trevor. It's 2023, and the gaming industry should be moving towards better representation and inclusivity. Unfortunately, GTA 5 missed the mark entirely.

TLDR; GTA Online does not feel like GTA and is Pay2Win.  You can buy with real money weapons and super-charged weaponized vehicles. This allows you to dominate all other players. Regular players will never have those if they don't make this game their full-time job for extended period of time.  The super charged weapons and vehicles make this game have zero GTA vibe. I'm trying to blast someone with a shotgun, but they perish me with some alien looking, alien sounding weapon that I do not even know what it is. Laser weapons? What about learn how to make a consistent game experience.  Also, game experiences so many issues when trying to play with friends, I will join a session, but not be with them in a session, or I would get kicked for no reason, etc...  I am not even gonna mention anything about cheaters/modders as it doesn't matter. What's the difference between a cheater one-shoot killing me and a kid who poured ton of money into the game and can chase me around a map in a flying motorbike that's capable of shooting rookets?   GTA? No. This game does not feel like a GTA.

For a 10+ year old game it still manages to impress me. Been playing it (off and on) since it first dropped on PS3 and even now, on PC in the end of 2023, this is still an amazing game. Even with GTA6 on the horizon (at long last) I'd still recommend picking this game up (if somehow you've managed not too) and giving it a go. Sure it has aged quite abit now, there are prettier games out there for sure, but the detail R* put in this game is unreal and the expansive open world is still alot of fun to explore. Online is playable solo if you really not interested in playing with randoms (or don't have friends who play) but is best experienced with others if possible.

Note to myself to stop playing Rockstar games.  I was trying to finish RDR2 recently and I never felt so dumb during that time.  Yes, it is rather beautiful game with nice acting and ugly looking characters, but the worst problem is like when there is a mission there can be shooting and massacre all around and no one cares but on the instant when mission ends, dare to loot a remaining character because dreaded "15 second attention bubble code" is instantly spawning a witness on a horse or riding a cart to report Your crime to the authorities.  When You are hunting there will be no animals for hours, but as soon as You are riding a horse they will be spawning because they are acting as a "decoration".  These kind of games are like the yarn string that we, people use to entertain the cat - they put something stupid in our sight and we run to catch a that red string.  But is this really what we want and need?  Well may be some, but I do not.  I want to heave meaningful experiences in the open world game where I can feel as a creator myself instead of a dumb idiot chasing random number generator creating spawns to find and catch a three star animal for a crafting blueprint that will add +5 stats on my inventory capacity or something like that.  It's dumb, it's nonsense.  I can't put this review on RDR2 on steam since I bought it on Microsoft Store I believe so I put it here since, according to my own memories - GTAV was pretty much the same kind of design:  Much of the world is persistent only as long as it is within Your cone of view. Like if You watch a traffic in the industrial complex You will see a lot of heavy trailers driving and they stay on road if You follow them further outside that industrial complex, but the very next moment, when You pan Your view to something else, outside their "spawn area", they are lost - "despawned".  Think of it as if You were trying to play a chess but You are limited to see only the half of the chess board and every time You move Your sight, the chess pieces reappear randomly, to create an illusion of playing a chess game: that is what it means to play these kind of games.
