I won't say anything new that wasn't said millions times before. GTA V is a must own and play for almost anyone who enjoys perfect games. You have like literally and open world in which you can do anything, and everything is done so good, so great. I beat this game on PS4, and to be honest the control at the beginning felt awkward, but its just like for 5,6 hours - then you will get use to them and it will be just awesome. And there couple more minuses (story mode) - i didn't find any purpose for your crews skill levels - there aren't many heists in the story itself (or maybe i missed something). And other thing is sometimes very frustrating controls of the characters when you there is action is some very closed space, thankfully there weren't many of those. And the last thing is a targeting system when you are in a car flying on some 120 km/h - good luck in to shooting some specific targets.  That said, GTA 5 is almost perfect. The story narrative, screenplay, acting, voice acting, directing and whole craftsmanship is the best there can be. And i even just started to scratch the surface of GTA Online. Overall - one of the very best ever.

Look at my game time. This is just what I have on PC, not including the last two generations of consoles dating back to launch. This game was good at first but quickly fell into the MTX pit of doom where the entire game is based around leeching as much money as they can from you to fuel overpriced in game content that relies on an absurd amount of game time to achieve. They spent literally zero effort whatsoever on combatting the modding issue and never will fix it; that much is apparent. You will never be able to enter a server with or without friends and actually get anything done without being griefed into another dimension by modders and hackers.  It's a true shame because the core gameplay is good. Unfortunately because of the pricing of items, forced game time, MTX and modders this game isn't worth your time. Again, look at my hours spent. I've been trying to play for the last 2 weeks to just run some basic missions for businesses and get absolutely nowhere. When you get attacked by god mode modders and can't even rely on skill to overcome a challenge it's just lame and boring.   Do better, Rockstar. If GTA6 is anywhere near as bad in these regards, you will destroy your audience's faith in you.

"Warum GTA V auf dem PC das Nonplusultra ist – Eine Ode an die PC-Meisterrennen!"  Liebe Konsolenfreunde,  wir müssen mal ernsthaft reden. Ja, wir wissen, dass Konsolen ihre Vorzüge haben – die Bequemlichkeit, die in euren Wohnzimmern eingebaut ist, der einfache Plug-and-Play-Modus und natürlich das allumfassende Gefühl, euren Controller fest in den Händen zu halten. Aber wenn es um GTA V geht, müssen wir uns ein paar Dinge von der Leber schreiben. PC-Spieler, lehnt euch zurück und genießt, warum eure Version einfach unschlagbar ist!  1. **FPS-Flaute auf Konsolen:** Auf Konsolen gibt es dieses merkwürdige Phänomen namens "Frames-per-Second-Fasten" – oder kurz FPSF. Eure Konsole ist manchmal so langsam, dass selbst Schnecken darüber lachen würden. Auf dem PC dagegen fliegt man förmlich durch Los Santos, während Konsolenfreunde noch ihre Figuren in Zeitlupe steuern. 60 FPS? Pah! Wir reden von 144 FPS und mehr – als würden wir in einem Zeitstrudel durch die Straßen rauschen.  2. **Grafikpracht der Extraklasse:** Schaut euch mal die Grafik auf Konsolen an. Es ist, als würde man durch eine Brille aus Milch schauen. Auf dem PC hingegen baden wir förmlich in einem Meer aus High-Definition-Details. Die Sonnenuntergänge sind so atemberaubend, dass sie Picasso zu Tränen gerührt hätten – vorausgesetzt, er hätte GTA V gespielt.  3. **Modding-Manie:** Oh, arme Konsolenfreunde, könnt ihr Mods haben? Auf dem PC haben wir eine Armada an Mods, die das Spiel in alles Mögliche verwandeln. Von Superhelden, die Los Santos unsicher machen, bis hin zu realistischen Grafik-Overhauls – wir haben die Freiheit, unser Spiel zu gestalten, wie wir es wollen. Eure Konsolen dürfen höchstens von einem Bug träumen, der durch einen Zaubertrick behoben wird.  4. **Multitasking-Meister:** Während Konsolenfreunde GTA V spielen, müssen sie für jede Kleinigkeit das Spiel verlassen. Auf dem PC hingegen können wir während einer Verfolgungsjagd noch schnell unsere E-Mails checken, eine Pizza bestellen und das Weltfriedensproblem lösen – alles gleichzeitig!  Also, liebe Konsolenfreunde, wir lieben euch, aber wenn es um GTA V geht, müsst ihr zugeben: Der PC ist einfach das ultimative Spielparadies. Gebt zu, dass es ein kleines bisschen wahr ist – zumindest bis eure nächste Konsole herauskommt und wir alle von vorne anfangen!

Disastrous Experience with Rockstar's Customer "Service"  I wish I could base this review solely on the merits of Grand Theft Auto V, a game that has captivated players worldwide with its immersive open world and engaging storyline. Unfortunately, my experience with Rockstar Games' customer service and Rockstar Games social club has been so abysmal that it significantly overshadows any positive aspects of the game.  Firstly, attempting to contact Rockstar's support is like navigating a maze designed to frustrate and exhaust customers. In my case, I encountered an issue due to the inability to log in to the Social Club using an outdated email address that is no longer in existence. After submitting a support ticket, I waited for days and received only preformatted administrative responses, to which I promptly replied with diligence. The support team then repeatedly requested the same information without taking into consideration the responses and content I provided to them. It's incredibly disheartening to invest time and money into a game only to have any potential enjoyment stripped away by lack of support. Even if by some miracle you manage to receive a response, the quality of assistance is subpar at best.   Rockstar Games' dismissive attitude toward its player base is unacceptable. When users encounter issues, they deserve timely and effective support, not a runaround that leaves them feeling ignored and frustrated. As a result, I cannot recommend Grand Theft Auto V or any other Rockstar title until the company addresses and improves its abysmal customer service.

Even 9 years later, this game is easily one of the best that you can buy.  Whilst GTA Online has gone in a direction I don't like - and wouldn't really recommend in engaging very much with to complete newcomers by this stage - I can't ignore that it still has thousands of hours to offer players across a variety of different activities - there's something for everyone in GTA Online and it will also make them money whilst they're at it.  Single Player is also undeniably a brilliant experience. Even though it will take you a while to get through to the end of the story, there's really no excuse for not playing it through at least once.  A lot of us have got a bit tired of this game in the many years since it's original release, but from an objective point of view, even if this game released for the very first time this year, it would still be one of the best video games ever made and blow us all away.  The driving is much easier than GTA 4, literally anyone can be a decent driver in GTA 5 unless you have brain damage, but I guess it makes it more accessible, lol. Shooting is also much improved and is high quality, and those two elements combined with many others, including but not limited to the excellent map, make this game a perfect sandbox.
Even after all these years, still a wonderful game.

Grand Theft Auto VI: A Breathtaking Leap Forward, But Not Without Its Flaws Grand Theft Auto VI has finally arrived, and it's safe to say it's been worth the wait. Rockstar Games has once again delivered a sprawling, immersive, and often hilarious experience that pushes the boundaries of open-world gaming. But is it perfect? No, but it's still a must-play for any fan of the franchise.  The Good:  Stunning visuals: GTA VI boasts some of the best graphics ever seen in a video game. The world is incredibly detailed, from the bustling city streets to the lush countryside. Massive and diverse world: The game world is absolutely massive, and there's always something new to discover. You can explore sprawling cities, quaint towns, and everything in between. Engaging story: The story is well-written and full of twists and turns. It's also incredibly funny, with some of the best satire in the series. Improved gameplay: The gameplay has been refined and improved, making it more responsive and enjoyable than ever before. The new driving mechanics are particularly impressive. Online experience: GTA Online returns with a fresh coat of paint. There are new activities to try, new vehicles to drive, and new properties to purchase.  The Bad:  Technical issues: The game isn't without its bugs and glitches. While not game-breaking, they can be frustrating at times. Long loading times: Loading times can be quite long, especially when transitioning between different areas of the map. Microtransactions: GTA Online is once again filled with microtransactions, which can be a turn-off for some players.  The Verdict:  Grand Theft Auto VI is a phenomenal game that sets a new standard for open-world gaming. It's not without its flaws, but the good far outweighs the bad. If you're a fan of the series, or even just open-world games in general, then you owe it to yourself to check out GTA VI.  Overall Score: 9/10

Bought and played this game a few years ago and loved playing the single player game. Game play was so much fun and the story is awesome, but....  Rockstar now requires you to have and log into a social club account and you must be on-line the entire time...even if you are only playing single player.   I have not played in over a year and when I try to play the single player game it will not let me. Rockstar is not letting me log into my social club account and it seems there is some issue with the linking of my Steam account with Rockstar. On Rockstars webpage I am able to log into my account, but anything about linking does not apply to Steam and only mentions PS, Xbox, ...... ,which all had links for fixes.  I would not buy any Rockstar games through Steam, as you will not have any easy fix if there is any issue with the linking of your Steam account to Rockstar.  I would not recommend this, or any other Rockstar game and unfortunately I will not be purchasing any more games from them as long as they continue to have this requirement to play single player games.

there was a little guy named guy. was an adventurous and curious guy who always had a million questions in his mind. One day, guy came across a wise old man guy sitting under a tree.  Excitedly, guy approached the old man guy and said, "guy, I've heard that you know the answer to every question in the world. Is that true?"  The wise old man guy smiled and replied, "Indeed, my young friend guy. I possess the knowledge to answer any question you might have. What would you like to know?"  guy eyes lit up with excitement as he thought of a challenging question. "Okay," he said, "Tell me, what is the meaning of life?"  The old man guy chuckled and said, "Ah, that's a question that has puzzled humanity for ages. The meaning of life is like a vast ocean with countless depths, and each person must embark on their own journey to discover it."  guy frowned, feeling a bit disappointed with the answer. "But, guy," he persisted, "Can you give me a more specific answer? Something more concrete?"  The old man guy nodded and replied, "Very well, my young friend guy. Let me tell you a story."  "Long ago, there was a powerful guy who ruled over a vast guydom. One day, the guy summoned three of his bravest guys and gave them each a quest. The first guy was sent on a mission to find the most precious gemstone in the world. The second guy was tasked with finding the rarest flower that only bloomed once every hundred years. And the third guy was commanded to find the secret to eternal happiness."  "So, each guy embarked on their respective journeys, determined to fulfill the guy's wishes. The first guy traveled far and wide, searching through treacherous mountains, vast deserts, and deep oceans. After years of relentless pursuit, he finally found the most precious gemstone hidden within a mystical cave."  "The second guy ventured into enchanted forests, climbing towering peaks, and crossing dangerous swamps. It took him decades, but eventually, he discovered the rarest flower blossoming in a secluded meadow."  "As for the third guy he wandered through bustling cities, remote villages, and explored the deepest corners of the human heart. He spoke with wise sages, studied ancient scriptures, and tasted the flavors of life. After a lifetime of exploration, the knight realized that true happiness lies not in possessions or achievements, but in the simple moments of joy, love, and connection shared with others."  "Years later, the three guy returned to the guydom, presenting their findings to the GUY. The first GUY offered the most precious gemstone, the second GUY presented the rarest flower, and the third GUY shared his wisdom about the secret to eternal happiness."  "The GUY was pleased, but he couldn't help but feel that something was missing. He pondered for days until he finally realized that the true meaning of life lay not in seeking external treasures or ephemeral pleasures, but in living a life of purpose, compassion, and making a positive impact on the world."  "So, my dear GUY," the old man GUY concluded, "The meaning of life is a personal journey, filled with adventures, discoveries, and the pursuit of goodness. It is about finding your own purpose, embracing love and kindness, and leaving a lasting legacy that resonates with future generations."  GUY listened intently, absorbing the old man's words. A smile appeared on his face as he thanked the old man GUY for his wisdom. With a newfound understanding, he walked away, ready to embark on his own journey to uncover the meaning of life.  And so, the story continues, with GUY forging his own path, seeking answers, and making the most out of every precious moment of his existence.  Remember, my GUY, the meaning of life may be elusive, but it's in the journey itself that we find purpose, fulfillment, and true happiness. WHO?

Title: Grand Theft Auto V on Steam - A Masterpiece of Open-World Gaming  Introduction: Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) has long been hailed as a pinnacle in the open-world gaming genre, and its presence on Steam only solidifies its status as a timeless masterpiece. Developed by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games, this fifth installment in the iconic Grand Theft Auto series has captivated players worldwide since its initial release in 2013. Now, with its availability on Steam, players can experience the thrilling chaos of Los Santos with the added benefits of the Steam platform.  Graphics and Visuals: One of the first aspects that strike players upon launching GTA V is its breathtaking graphics. Even years after its release, the attention to detail in the game's design is commendable. The bustling city of Los Santos comes alive with stunning visuals, from the glimmering skyscrapers to the gritty streets. The character models are incredibly detailed, and the dynamic weather and lighting effects add a layer of realism that enhances the overall immersive experience.  Storyline and Characters: The narrative of GTA V is a triumph in storytelling within the gaming industry. The game weaves together the lives of three distinct protagonists – Michael, Franklin, and Trevor – each with their own compelling backstory and unique personality. The intersecting narratives provide players with a diverse range of missions and activities, ensuring that boredom is never a factor. The characters are well-written, bringing a mix of humor, drama, and intensity to the table. The engaging storyline is further complemented by top-notch voice acting, creating a cinematic feel throughout the game.  Open-World Exploration: GTA V sets the standard for open-world exploration. The sprawling city of Los Santos and its surrounding areas offer a vast and diverse landscape for players to explore. From the vibrant city center to the desolate desert, every corner of the map is filled with activities, secrets, and random encounters. Whether cruising the streets in a high-end sports car, skydiving from a plane, or engaging in adrenaline-pumping heists, the game offers unparalleled freedom, ensuring that every playthrough is a unique adventure.  Heists and Missions: The heist system in GTA V stands out as a gameplay highlight. Planning and executing elaborate heists with a crew add a strategic layer to the game, encouraging players to think critically and choose their approach carefully. The variety of missions keeps the gameplay experience fresh and exciting, ranging from high-speed chases to intense shootouts. The seamless transition between characters during missions enhances the overall sense of teamwork and coordination.  Multiplayer Experience (GTA Online): GTA Online, the multiplayer counterpart to the single-player campaign, is a dynamic and ever-evolving online world. The multiplayer mode introduces a plethora of activities, from races and heists to business ventures and criminal enterprises. The constant updates and additions by Rockstar ensure that GTA Online remains a vibrant community, fostering social interaction, competition, and cooperation among players.  Modding Community and Steam Workshop: One of the significant advantages of owning GTA V on Steam is the access to the extensive modding community. The Steam Workshop provides a convenient platform for players to discover and install mods, enhancing the game with new features, visual enhancements, and custom content. The modding community has played a crucial role in keeping the game relevant and exciting for years after its initial release.  Conclusion: Grand Theft Auto V on Steam is a testament to the enduring legacy of the game. With its unparalleled graphics, captivating storyline, open-world freedom, and a thriving online community, GTA V continues to stand as a benchmark for open-world gaming. Whether you're a veteran fan or a newcomer to the series, the Steam version offers a seamless and feature-rich experience, making it a must-have in any gamer's library. GTA V is not just a game; it's a living, breathing world waiting to be explored and conquered.  -chat gpt

Even at $14 I'm really regretting this purchase and most of that is because the absolute bullcrap you have to go through to play the game.  The launcher is a mess, the social club requirement is extremely irritating, and the forced internet access would throw up captchas for me constantly and then after completing over a dozen puzzles it would then say I got one of them wrong and make me start over with even more puzzles.  As for gameplay, I'm not at all a fan of that either.  I am a very casual gamer but I liked previous GTA games from years ago which sadly are no longer on Steam so I figured I'd give this one a shot thinking it would be similar but it feels completely different....  I'm not a fan of forced paths which story mode kind of locks you in to.  There were certainly moments that I enjoyed playing it but it always seemed to end up pushing me into a segment that I just found myself zoning out and just losing interest. Maybe I'm weird but if I'm playing a game, I like to play a game and if I'm watching TV, I like to watch TV -- I don't want to switch between the two constantly.  One other frustration is that the game makes a very weak attempt at trying to get you used to specific buttons and actions and many times pops up dialog telling you stuff while you're trying to complete something else (like racing down the road, etc).  I'll probably play around with it again in the future but honestly, game play aside, the launcher and social club stuff is absolutely something that makes me not want to recommend this.... had I realized that I was going to spend an hour downloading it and then over an hour trying to get things set up (launcher, configuration, irritating login set up, etc) I would have never started down this path.

First of all it is undeniably a great game which makes it so much worse when you want to enjoy the outstanding Online Mode but just can't because you'll get a stroke from being annoyed out of your mind from the Online mechanics.  Everything in the Online Mode is made to be as annoying and time wasting as possible.  Be it unskippable endless dialogue or your character being to stupid to walk in a straight line or just random events and dumb NPCs to make every mission as annoying and as time consuming as possible.  In combination with the outdated and super buggy movement mechanics you will die many times without it even being your fault.  And if you have the patience of a saint you will perhaps not rage quit after the sixtiest time you randomly explode with the slow ass delivery vehicle because an NPC wanted to sideswipe you for no  reason while going 250 on the highway. And sadly we all know why this is the case, so you are more inclined to skip the unplayayble and annoying grind for money and just buy shark cards.  It could be an outstanding game, but rockstar created a grindy, buggy and often unplayable mess to squeeze some more Shark Card buys out of their player base. Ok the rant is over, thank you for reading if you made it this far! And again for the Fanboys, i love GTA V, i love the online mode, otherwise i would'nt play it for hundreds of hours. But when you have to grind this much in a game where a million dollars barely gets you a used broken down PoS Car the grind should at least be fun and not punishing you at every step just for playing.

Honestly, GTA 5 is a fun game that includes multiplayer and single player. In multiplayer you can choose to play in online servers or with your friends! On the other hand, singleplayer is also fun for users who wanna play alone, explore, do missions And so on singleplayer has many storylines and sad/interesting lores behind it backing up both singleplayer and GTA 5. GTA 5 would honestly be a good game if it wasn't for the horrendous amounts of cheaters inside of every single online server. The game itself is a good game, emersive and open world. It sucks how it's filled with cheaters and people who'll kill you instantly after joining servers. I one time had to reinstall GTA 5 twice because one cheater crashed my game entirely. Multi-million dollar company? Come on now. I'm not saying there shouldn't be glitches or cheaters. They're always will be. I'm just shocked by the fact that a multi-million dollar company has this much cheaters. The game itself would get a 4.5/5 if it wasn't for how quick and easy you'd get bored without friends or missions entirely. I tried a quick time lapse to see how long it would take for me to get bored doing missions and one of me messing around. Doing missions got a 4 hour mark while doing nothing has gotten a 30 minute mark. I get the argument I'm making above is stupid but it should be common sense for a user who has nothing to do and doesn't want to do missions waste time in something fun. This game gets a 3/10. Many cheaters. And can only play with people with the same console as yours which is pretty stupid but it's fine. As someone with no friends online is shit, fivem is boring and the game is only fun with missions
i lopve this game

A complete money grab, the load times are terrible, and impossible to enjoy.  Absolute trash.

Great game story line is almost perfect and fun. Completed in about 66hr, or less i did a lot of random stuff like online not just the missions back to back. Honestly you could probably knock this game out in 2 or 3 weekends if you wanted to. I don't have any extra stuff just the game the over all game play was great the bots weren't to hard to kill. Police were fairly balanced if you wanted to fight them you could but it was just as easy to hide. But my main complaint would be the ending of the story mode i feel like they could have made it more harder to kill the leaders or at least made killing them each having a separate mission. They Likely could have gotten an extra 20 minutes or so out of it I just feel like with the base game theirs some thing that should have been added. It just feels like you were riled up for a bit finish with 3 big fights and it didn't happen. But I would still play and don't regret buying.

The ability to play any Rockstar games I purchased on Steam has been stripped away just as it has for many other people due to the ridiculous social club requirement attached.  Below is the support ticket. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3103521022  You have a single account (for a launcher!?), anything happens to it and Rockstar deems you not the owner despite obvious evidence, that’s it. Your games are now rendered unusable. The compromised account permanently tied to Steam with no option to unlink. The only option being to repurchase all Rockstar games once again somewhere else if you fancy playing them again (remind me why Rockstar have any incentive to adjust social clubs current implementation).  In GTA 4’s instance, it didn’t even have social club when I purchased. Rockstar added it in an update in 2020 (The same update which also removed content from the game due to licence expiry). In what way does the EULA or any other measure give the right to REMOVE no longer licenced content from copies purchased previous? Say you own a film on DVD / BluRay, it has a wicked car chase scene. Later down the line, the movie company loses the licence from the car manufacturer of one of the cars in the scene. Can the movie company then come and take away your film and hand you another copy with the car removed from the chase scene?

Grand Theft Auto V is an absolute masterpiece in the gaming world. From its stunningly detailed open-world environment to its gripping story line, this game sets a new standard for immersive gaming experiences. The level of detail in Los Santos is mind-blowing, making it feel like a living, breathing city ripe for exploration.  The game's narrative is incredibly engaging, weaving together the lives of three distinct protagonists, each with their own compelling story lines and personalities. The seamless switching between characters adds depth and variety to game play, keeping things fresh and exciting.

After 2200 hours of playing GTA Online, I can say this game is very timeless; no matter how old this game is, people will comeback and still play GTA Online. One key reason is that this game doesn't require a high-end gaming PC, so literally everyone can still play GTA online without any performance issues.  But, always remember that modders are still and always been an issue in this game, so I wouldn't recommend playing it on the public lobby; it would be better to play in an invite-only session or a friends session.

I don't really know how to review this game, the base game is still pretty solid, but gta online is pretty crap.  It seems like they've removed the ability to just purchase the base game from steam, so you've gotta get both the base game and criminal enterprise starter pack (it's the same price on their own store).  The single-player story is fairly decent, and the gameplay is fun enough, though it feels a little empty in side content.  While I've had quite a lot of fun with online it's only really because I've only really played it with friends in private lobbies, and as such I've avoided most if the BS that the online community has to offer, that does not excuse how horrendously grindy the online is, and it's only gotten worse over time.  Also, they force you to use their own launcher which is always bad, it'd be fine if it was an option or at least worked well, but it really doesn't.

Oh my stars and pixelated heavens! GTA 5 is not just a game, it's a euphoric rollercoaster of digital delight that catapults you into a neon-soaked wonderland of crime and chaos! From the adrenaline-pumping heists that make your heart race faster than a turbocharged sports car to the sprawling cityscape that sparkles like a million digital diamonds, GTA 5 is an absolute triumph of gaming brilliance. The characters are more charismatic than a puppy in a bowtie, the storyline is more gripping than a grandma's secret cookie recipe, and the open-world exploration is as liberating as a unicorn on a trampoline. It's a joyous explosion of pixels and possibilities that will leave you grinning like a Cheshire cat who just discovered the cheat codes to happiness. In the world of video games, GTA 5 isn't just a game; it's a virtual symphony of euphoria that'll have you dancing in your gaming chair with glee! If joy had a joystick, it would be GTA 5!

Grand Theft Auto Online has rampant hacking/modding issues, which Rockstar has done little to address. This includes, among other things, the ability for "modders" to tamper with and ban your online account, crash the game outright, obtain your IP address, and even maliciously modify files and execute code on your PC (the latter making the game malware). See the National Vulnerability Database report (https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-24059), which rates it 7.3 (high severity) and states, "Grand Theft Auto V for PC allows attackers to achieve partial remote code execution or modify files on a PC, as exploited in the wild in January 2023."   Rockstar's cyber security practices are laughable. They are aware of the exploits but simply do not care. Be aware that you are essentially downloading malware by purchasing this game and playing online. This game should be taken down until these issues are fully addressed. Feel free to copy the above if you choose to report the game on Steam as I have.

Played this game through various platforms. Started with ps3, moved to ps4, and then eventually wound up here on PC. Initially when I played this game way back when, it was still frustrating as all hell, but at some level playable. Online was very lacking and tedious, but it kept adding content every now and then. The apartments with ten car garages were the last thing I saw before taking a decade long break from this game. I eventually got it again while it was on sale and came bundled with a ten mil package for online. Cool, I thought, maybe this would help me catch up to what I missed after all these years. .... And today I'm officially rage quitting this nightmare hell hole of a game. I don't even want to touch single player at this point with how bad online has gotten. It may have lacked content back in the day, but now it is just an unbalanced nightmare of a mess. I've never seen the game cheat its way to victory the way I see constantly now. It's like it has a mind of its own and just knows how to irritate the ever living hell out of you. When you combine that factor with the onslaught of modders, it's just unplayable. Whats the point of online if you constantly have to go into a private session? How am I supposed to find friends to play with when everyone is running from the main lobby? My first play was fine, it even seemed better than what I saw on console; but it only took two to three days to see this nonstop pattern. The game itself is alright if you consider the single player aspect of it and how old it is. By all means, get it for that and do whatever. But online? Online just sucks. I don't know when they decided to do it, but the developers have made this game so freaking hard at this point that it's just not enjoyable. Maybe the vets of the game have no idea because they've adjusted to it, but if you haven't played in a long time, it is just not a friendly game at all and doesn't get any better with time. I can't tell you how many times I've been instantly killed with full armor and health, or had a helicopter spawn into mine just to kill me, but it's been enough. I'm done. I'm just done with this nonsense. Headshots hardly ever count anymore and I've literally seen NPCs actually die and then just stand back up and proceed to murder me. No matter how far away I am and at what ever angle, they always hit me. Maybe one shot misses, maybe. Meanwhile I see my shots go straight through them over and over again. The list goes on with this game. We all know what this game does to piss us all off, but now it's just ten times worse than it ever was. Not to mention the fact that I had a modder randomly appear next to me and suddenly my character level went from ten to 100 just like that. Online was never all that great to begin with, but now it is just horrible. I'm tired of getting pissed off whenever I play this game, so I'm done. Most of you are probably much more level headed than I am, so you'll probably be fine. But if you easily get frustrated like I do, then you may find yourself in the same boat as I am. Single player is same as it always was, but online is just a joke now.  P.S. Dear rockstar, when in the hell are you ever going to make these controls actually good? Maybe spend a little more time in that department. I'm not the only one blowing a gasket every time I try to go through a doorway or something similar. More than five games now and my character still feels like a crazed monkey with cement shoes that gains too little or too much momentum. Also, watching my character stand in place every time they open a safe in the nightclub was enough for me to blow a fuse too. EVERY TIME! Every damn one of your games has something like this and in more than one spot. Good God, it's a game. Lets get on with it! I'm dying of old age while my character is waiting for a repetitive task to get started.

Grand Theft Auto V, upon its initial release, set an unprecedented standard for open-world gaming that left an indelible mark on the industry. Rockstar's masterpiece, with its sprawling world, complex characters, and engaging narrative, was the pinnacle of gaming innovation at the time.  The vast and meticulously crafted city of Los Santos, coupled with the seamless transition between the three diverse protagonists, showcased a level of detail and immersion that was revolutionary. The heist missions, in particular, demonstrated Rockstar's ability to blend narrative and gameplay, setting a new bar for what could be achieved in the realm of interactive storytelling.  Graphically, GTA 5 was a marvel, pushing the boundaries of what was thought possible on the then-current generation of gaming consoles. The attention to detail, from the bustling city streets to the sun-soaked landscapes, was unparalleled and contributed to the game's lasting visual appeal.  However, as the years have passed, GTA 5's continued dominance in the gaming landscape feels both a testament to its enduring popularity and a double-edged sword. While the game's initial release undoubtedly deserves its status as a classic, the decision to keep it in circulation across multiple console generations begins to show signs of fatigue.  The game's mechanics, while solid, have started to show their age compared to more recent releases. The multiplayer component, GTA Online, while immensely successful and enjoyable for many, has also faced issues with rampant in-game inflation and a reliance on microtransactions that can hinder the experience for those who prefer a more traditional progression system.  Despite its flaws, GTA 5 still manages to captivate new audiences and entertain loyal fans. Rockstar's commitment to supporting the game with updates and new content is commendable. However, one can't help but wonder if the time has come for the gaming industry to look beyond the enduring shadow of GTA 5 and embrace the next wave of groundbreaking titles that push the boundaries even further.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V remains a landmark title that undeniably shaped the gaming landscape upon its release. While its continued presence is a testament to its enduring appeal, there's a sense that the gaming community, as well as Rockstar themselves, might benefit from turning their focus toward new horizons and fresh innovations rather than relying on the laurels of a classic that's been in circulation for perhaps a bit too long.

"Grand Theft Auto V: Where I Learn Crime Pays, But My Driving Skills Sure Don't" Howdy, carjackers and aspiring criminals! I recently dove into the wild, crime-infested world of Grand Theft Auto V, and let me tell you, my real-life law-abiding self is questioning some life choices right about now.  First things first, the driving in this game is so realistic that I'm considering sending Rockstar my real driver's license for a proper critique. Forget about following traffic rules; I drive through red lights and run over pedestrians like it's a requirement for the in-game DMV. My character must've learned to drive from a blindfolded squirrel with a lead foot.  Let's talk about the characters. Michael, Trevor, and Franklin – the Three Musketeers of crime. Michael's midlife crisis is so relatable; I'm considering taking up yoga and yelling at my therapist, too. Trevor, on the other hand, is so bat-crap crazy that the Joker would be like, "Dude, tone it down." And Franklin? He's just trying to make a name for himself in the criminal underworld while also avoiding traffic accidents caused by his idiotic boss (that's me).  The city of Los Santos is a masterpiece – it's like SimCity, but with more explosions and fewer city council meetings. The attention to detail is insane. You can buy clothes, get haircuts, and even play golf. Who knew that planning heists and improving my virtual golf swing would become my favorite pastimes?  The radio stations are gold. I find myself driving aimlessly just to catch the witty banter and questionable music choices. I never knew I needed a fictional talk show about aliens and government conspiracies in my life, but here we are.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is the perfect game for anyone who's ever dreamed of being a criminal mastermind with terrible driving skills. It's a wild ride, and my therapist says I should stop referring to it as my "crime therapy." But hey, at least my virtual criminal empire is thriving, even if my real-world parallel parking skills are not. Time to steal more cars and maybe invest in some driving lessons.

A Tale of Two Worlds - Story Shines, Online Stumbles  Rating : 3.5  Grand Theft Auto V is a game of contrasts, offering players a captivating story mode while also immersing them in the chaotic playground of GTA Online. Let's break it down:  Story Mode (5/5): GTA V's story mode isn't just a narrative; it's a cinematic masterpiece that seamlessly weaves together the lives of Michael, Trevor, and Franklin. The character development is stellar, with each protagonist offering a unique perspective on the criminal underbelly of Los Santos. The writing is sharp, filled with humor, satire, and moments of genuine emotion. The missions are not just tasks; they're elaborate heists that require meticulous planning, adding a strategic layer to the gameplay. The attention to detail in the open-world environment is astonishing, creating a living, breathing city that reacts to your actions. From adrenaline-pumping chase sequences to quiet moments of introspection, GTA V's story mode is a testament to Rockstar's storytelling prowess and their ability to craft an immersive, multi-faceted narrative.  Online Mode (2/5): The transition to GTA Online, however, is a mixed bag. On the positive side, the vast open world of Los Santos becomes an ever-evolving sandbox, with countless activities and missions to undertake. The customization options for characters and vehicles add a layer of personalization. However, the experience is marred by a significant issue - cheaters.  Cheater Infestation (1/5): GTA Online's biggest downfall is the rampant presence of cheaters. Whether it's invincibility, spawning unlimited resources, or outright disrupting the experience for others, cheaters can turn what should be a thrilling session into a frustrating ordeal. Rockstar's efforts to combat this issue have been inconsistent at best, leaving many players feeling helpless against the tide of unfair advantages.  Conclusion (3.5/5): Grand Theft Auto V is a tale of two worlds. The story mode is a masterpiece, offering a cinematic and immersive experience that stands the test of time. On the other hand, the online component falls victim to the prevalence of cheaters, detracting from what could be an equally compelling multiplayer experience. If you can look past the online frustrations, GTA V remains a must-play for its exceptional single-player narrative.

Grant Theft Auto is a great game, a very well designed, very well written, very well balanced game that mark the high point of current gen games in almost every aspect. It pains me to give it 4 stars instead of 5 because one obvious problem which I absolutely can not, and will not overlook no matter how great the game is. And that problem is the misogyny through out the game.  If you want to read about how great the game is, you can read any critic reviews from Polygon, gamespot or any other game sites. And I agree with all them, it's a great game. But I want to talk about women in GTA V, or more precisely, the lack of such.  Character development in GTA V is quite interesting. Every single one of characters you end up playing, meeting, working for, fighting with or against, eventually killing...are total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. They're selfish, obnoxious, arrogant, stupid, and completely insane. They rob banks and kill people without the slightest remorse, they use other people and set them up to killed while pretend to be peaceful and spiritual. They're the everyday morons you see exaggerated 100 times. People would argue that because everyone in Los Santos is horrible in their own way, it is acceptable to have annoying and despicable women character as well.  Here's the difference though. The main characters: Michael, Trevor and Franklin, as well as some of major supporting characters such as Leslie, Dave, or Lamar... They're horrible people indeed, but they all have some kind of redeeming quality, especially the 3 main characters. They're very well crafted extremely flawed characters with a lot of depth, people you despise yet can't help to sympathize. They're people you can relate to from a certain level. Not from being a psychopath (I hope), but realizing that they're facing the same problem we face everyday.  But the girls in Los Santos are annoying, shallow, pathetic, with no redeeming quality. They're there to be funny, or to create obstacles for the main character to overcome. Most of them have very thin back stories, aren't all that interesting, and overall, they're just very badly written. It's almost as if the writers are so taken away by the dynamics between the 3 main character (The bro-mance between Trevor and Michael, the father/son relationship between Michael and Franklin), they just don't care about add women into the game.  I have a half joking theory that Rockstar writers are probably closet women hating gay guys. They're willing to write a main character who's gay, yet unwilling to write a good female character. It's not that they can't, Bonnie in Red Dead Redemption is actually well written, so is Katie in GTA IV. They're real women with real personality, and strong in their own way. I was quite hopeful to see some real changes in GTA V, especially after all those outcry for better female characters in games over the past few years. Oh how was I bitterly disappointed. It would be so nice to have a strong (homicidal or not) girl in GTA universe.  Eventually, I think the writers just don't care. Why should they? The game is making insane amount of money even as misogyny as it is. There's no incentive for them to write good female character other than it would be nice to write good female characters as decent writers.  I guess I should talk a little bit about the actual game other than whine about misogyny. Like I said, GTA V is great. But what impressed me the most is how well balanced the game is. The world is huge, but never overwhelming; the missions are diverse and fun but never chaotic; the character switching is fun and exciting but never hectic even in the middle of the heated gun battle. All of the heists are very well designed, and very fun to play out (I wish there're more).  Michael is probably my most favorite characters in all Rockstar games. He's such a complex character and so different from your typical game protagonist. His psychotic and almost romantic attachment with Trevor, his mentor/fatherly attitude towards Franklin, while still remain a hard cold selfish killer.  Regardless how I think about their misogyny, GTA V is a great game. You should play it.

The game is a mixed bag. It has some beautiful environments and you can have a lot of fun with it. It does have some major downsides which prevent me from recommending it.  Game breaking bugs and other issues don't get fixed.  - Whenever you load into GTA online, you get the same spam calls before you get together enough money to make them stop by doing what they ask. These are things that require 3 million, 6 million.... It takes weeks if not months for a new player to get this amount of money. - Online takes 6 minutes to load, on an SSD. - Floating uncontrollable van on the Motorcycle Club resupply mission. - Ammo disappearing in online which requires you to re-buy which is incredibly expensive. - Rapid fire bug that makes NPCs insta-kill a player out of nowhere. Been in the game since launch.

Nearly a decade after release, Grand Theft Auto V remains an entertaining open world games thanks to its vibrant, densely-packed city of Los Santos and a seemingly endless variety of mayhem to unleash. The shooting, driving, and general gameplay still feels great, allowing both scripted antics in the campaign and emergent chaos in the streets. The story mode delivers an engaging criminal story full of the series’ trademark humor. Where GTA V falls short for some fans is in the map design and online experience. While beautiful, Los Santos lacks the scale, diversity, and exploration of previous games like San Andreas. The online component also feels soulless, with a frustrating grind for money and many aggressive microtransactions pushing "shark cards" for fast cash. Red Dead Redemption 2 shows how a more balanced and thoughtful online experience provides better fan service.

[h1] This city will eat you alive kid. [/h1]  If you let it. It's a big place, full of big dreamers. Optimistic artists, blind German fashion designers, kids fresh out of college trying to convince themselves that their acting degree is worth a f*ck... you name it. It's a cut-throat free-for-all. Every rat in the maze is gonna try to stab you in the back and clamber over your rotting corpse to reach the top of the pile.  When I rolled in, I was as hopeless as everyone else. I got off that plane with nothin' but a clean change of clothes and a half empty bottle of bourbon in my carry-on. Nothin' to drive, nowhere to stay, and not a dollar to my name. All I had was Lamar Davis' phone number. God bless that man... He taught me something very important: when you're in a maze full of rats, you find yourself a pack.  I signed on with an individual known simply as "The Kewn." He had merchandise to move, and I had a commercial driver's license. It was a match made in a crack den. To be honest, it was pretty degrading, but it put paper in my wallet. That paper put my name on a lease, a beautiful '72 Saber Turbo in the garage, and a God-blessed American firearm in my hand. It also bought a tiny little warehouse down on Elysian Island.  Every empire starts somewhere, amigo. Mine started when I was blackout drunk. I sunk the chopper carrying my first ever load of cargo into the harbor, and somehow managed to drag the crate through the door before the law showed up. My assistant found me the next morning passed out in a pool of my own urine.  Bit of a bumpy start, but that one crate laid the foundation for what I am today, baby. I clawed my way up to the one percent the old-fashioned way. I wasn't a hot girl who cozied up to some fat, bald Russian f*ck with a fifty foot yacht in Ibiza, full of ditzy, bikini-clad models. Nor was I a Harvard dropout who's daddy paid bail after I crashed my third Pegassi into a strip club, up to my eyebrows on marching powder.  Those Shark Card scum who inherit generational wealth all wind up the same. The hot girls get cosmetic surgery in their late forties when their looks start to fade, inevitably facing the fact that they're bland, vacant shells of a personalty with nothing but a pair of big, pouty lips and a sub-average IQ. The Harvard dropouts graduate when papa makes a generous donation to the board, and then they use their complimentary finance degree in an attempt to re-enact [i] The Wolf of Wall Street [/i] before they die speedballing.   Point is, unlike them, my hands are good and dirty. I'm out there every day flying the choppers, rippin' eighteen-wheelers down the highway, and having civilized, high-caliber discussions with Merryweather Security. Sure, I could kick back on my Aquarius and pop champagne corks at passing jet-skis every time my account jumps up six figures, but I'd run out of bottles pretty quick. Gets boring after a while.  You see, I don't [i] need [/i] to be bustin' my ass this hard. Anything I could ever want is just a phone call away. At this point, the only reason to keep playin' is for the love of the game.  But hey, that's what works for me. You've got your whole life ahead of you kiddo, and you can waste it however you want. Get into professional street racing. Skydive off of Mount Chiliad. Hunt people for sport. F*ck it, play Arena War if you're some sort of psychopath!  Point is, you can do whatever. You. Want.  Just don't forget that there's a million other little rats like you.  [b] And they're [i] all [/i] hungry. [/b]

After seeing this scene many times, I have realized that Lamar's roast is actually incredible. By acting as if he's in a hurry and talking quickly, he eliminates the opportunity for Franklin's counterargument, meaning that he can continue delivering his verbal critique.  The use of the phrase "yee-yee" is especially clever as it has very loose meanings and is utilized to further demean Franklin while not being necessarily rude, as well as fitting nicely into the rhythm of Lamar's "smack-talk" as the youth say. Since a person's hair is usually one of their most stand-out and noticeable features, by ridiculing his, Lamar makes Franklin's identity feel attacked and being shorter means that he's opened to the perspective of one taller than himself having to look down at it, making him especially self-conscious.  Furthermore, by berating Franklin's female partner, Lamar starts to get very personal with him which makes the insults even harsher, while also making Franklin feel inadequate in romantic relationships. As well as this, feigning uncertainty of her secret partner's occupation and referring to intelligent and respectable vocations such as "lawyer" and "brain surgeon" Lamar attacks Franklin's lack of a formal education.  Finally, the strange and belittling way that he calls him the funny n word further aims to make Franklin seems foolish and by slightly squatting to make eye contact, Lamar subtly roasts Franklin's stature again, as well as his status, making him feel like an insignificant child.  Truly, a genius in the art of "roasting" as the youth say.

Interested in the story or modded multiplayer? Go for it!  If you're looking to get into GTA Online, save your sanity. Compared to a decade ago, it's in a horrid state. First off, you're no longer playing GTA when you're in multiplayer... you're playing a sci-fi version of Just Cause 3 on an unholy amount of steroids as you prevent World War 3 essentially. Additionally, everything's gotten far more expensive to encourage micro-transactions if you don't want to deal with the abysmal grind and there's even a subscription service now. The anti-cheat is utterly terrible... can't even join a single session without someone or several people using cheat scripts for the sole purpose of ruining everyone's day. No IP address protection, either. Only time the game gets a "hotfix" is to patch money exploits, anything else hardly ever gets touched.  TL;DR: Single-player is good, online is awful.

"GTA V: The Loveable Old Grandpa Still Kickin' While We Wait for GTA 6"  Oh boy, where do I even start with this gem? GTA V is like that beloved old uncle who's been crashing on your couch for way too long—still stealing the spotlight, hogging the TV remote, and making you laugh despite overstaying its welcome.  Let's talk about the game. It's like the eternal loop of chaos and shenanigans. You've got Michael, Trevor, and Franklin—these dudes are like the dysfunctional family members you secretly wish were part of your squad in real life. Michael, the retired bank robber turned family man; Trevor, the dude you wouldn't want to be left alone with your snacks; and Franklin, the guy you'd trust to parallel park your car blindfolded.  The world of Los Santos is still more alive than my houseplants, and trust me, that says a lot. You can be a responsible citizen, driving obeying traffic lights... or you can hijack a blimp, fly over the city, and make a heartfelt speech to the seagulls. Your call.  But let's address the elephant in the room, or should I say the lack thereof? Hey, Rockstar, where's GTA 6? Did you misplace it under a pile of cash or something? We're here, twiddling our thumbs, waiting for the next big thing while you're probably brainstorming ways to make us rob casinos on Mars.  But back to GTA V—despite its age, it's holding up better than my attempts at adulting. The graphics might not be cutting edge anymore, but the storytelling? Still top-notch. The multiplayer? A haven for both chaos and camaraderie. And let's not forget the mods, because turning every car into a screaming flamingo or replacing the cops with angry chickens? Pure gold.  So, here we are, giving this game yet another thumbs-up while simultaneously side-eyeing Rockstar for keeping us in suspense about GTA 6. Come on, guys, spill the beans already! Until then, I'll be in Los Santos, probably doing yoga on top of a moving train or trying to make friends with a gang of wandering llamas.

I like how the other reviews sound like Wikipedia articles. Here's an actual review from an actual person. If you said that GTA V is the best game of all time, I wouldn't argue with you. What Rockstar did for gaming with this absolute masterpiece cannot be understated. We're still playing it religiously, 10 years after it came out. One decade. Let that sink in. The use of three protagonists was a great idea and really branched out this game in ways we've never seen before. Getting three different perspectives on the same story is extremely interesting. Each of the protagonists holds their own; Trevor is easily one of my favorite protagonists ever; I love the Al Pacino vibe that Michael gives off; and Franklin's journey is awesome to see. The gameplay is top-notch. I love the gunplay, and the driving is stellar; it's much better than the boat steering from GTA 4. The story is incredible; there isn't much of an emotional attachment, but it's still extremely compelling and can easily last for multiple playthroughs. I replay this game once a year because I love it so much. The map is one of the best out there, and there's a reason it's used when judging the maps of new games. Online is a completely different story; it's toxic and pay-to win. It's fun with friends, but random lobbies are awful. Overall, GTA V is a 5/5. There's really nothing that can bring down the score.

"Grand Theft Auto V" is the absolute kingpin of open-world gaming, and Rockstar Games has truly crafted a timeless epic that's still rocking it.  Los Santos is more than just a city; it's a sprawling playground where every neighborhood has its own story to tell. From the glitz of Vinewood to the streets of Grove, the attention to detail is mind-blowing, making every corner worth exploring.  The trio of main characters is a genius move. Michael, Franklin, and Trevor bring unique vibes to the story, and being able to switch between them seamlessly adds a layer of immersion that keeps things interesting.  The story itself is a wild ride of heists, twists, and Rockstar's trademark satire on society. The writing is sharp, the voice acting is spot-on, and the cinematic presentation gives the whole narrative a blockbuster feel.  And let's not forget GTA Online – it's a whole new world of criminal opportunities. Building your empire, pulling off heists with friends, or just causing chaos, there's always something to do. The regular updates keep the online experience feeling fresh and unpredictable.  The gameplay mechanics are top-notch. The driving feels responsive, the combat is satisfying, and the range of activities, from serious heists to absurd yoga sessions, adds that extra layer of GTA charm. The soundtrack is a mixtape of perfection that sets the mood just right.  Sure, the graphics show a bit of wear and tear considering the game's age, but the overall design and vibe of Los Santos still make it a visual treat.  In a nutshell, "Grand Theft Auto V" is a masterpiece of gaming. The massive world, memorable characters, and the freedom to dive into chaos or follow the story make it a must-play. Despite its years, the game's still got that magic touch, making it a timeless classic that stands tall in the gaming hall of fame.

I really enjoyed Grand Theft Auto V on release, and I still really like the graphics, soundtrack, and the overall gameplay. I find that the driving in particular is very enjoyable, and I don't normally care about driving in games. The story is weak, and focuses heavily on a funding war between two government agencies despite it being obvious that the interactions between the three main characters are far more interesting.   However, over time, it has become harder to recommend. Rockstar is clearly making an absolute fortune from the online mode, and thus has focused all post-release development on this mode instead of doing any single-player DLCs. Unfortunately, the online mode is predatory in the same way that many mobile games are, and deliberately drags out the progression with long wait timers, big money grinds, and other artificial barriers designed to encourage players to buy in-game money with real currency to speed the process up.   Many features in the online game, such as the ability to insure custom cars and have them delivered to you, are exclusive to online play when they almost feel like basic features which should be present in single-player mode. A lot of content, including literally hundreds of cars and weapons, are exclusive to online play as well. Even worse - as this has gone on, the file size of the install has increased to match it (and you cannot install single player only) - it was around 50GB when I first got it, and now sits at 110GB. This game could be amazing to play offline, but Rockstar are fixated on herding players into their online mode in order to milk them for cash.

The prices you've applied to Turkey seem like a joke. As a country, we didn't switch to the dollar; Steam switched to the dollar to keep prices stable in Turkey and prevent constant fluctuations. What you should have done was convert the price you applied to us into dollars. In other words, the price would have remained the same, and we would have purchased it in dollars. This was what Steam communicated to us. Despite knowing our low purchasing power, you would never make sales at these prices. You can't manipulate Turkish gamers in this way. Good luck. TLDR: Great game, worth it for $15.  -Graphics 8.2/10  -Story 8/10  -Freedom 9.6/10  -Capitalism 13/10  As always, it's GTA so of course it will be nearly perfect in the realm of RPG/Action/Adventure games. It's a huge AAA title, so it's going to have some bugs, even 10 years or more after release, but that doesn't detract from the perfection that is the GTA series. There's a reason it's one of the most well-known RPG games on the market.   I haven't experienced anything game breaking from playing it on Xbox 360, Xbox One, Series X and now PC. It's well worth it for $15 during the Autumn Steam Sale, but I don't see myself paying $30 or $50 for the game + DLC content/money shark cards. Just buy the "premium" edition for $15 and spend a day or two grinding in online mode if you want the $4m from the shark card, save that cash!

Hello, viewers! This is my review of Rockstar Games' [i] Grand Theft Auto V [/i]!  [h1] Table of Contents [/h1] This is the order in which I will go over certain aspects of the game: [list] [*]Story [*]GTA Online [*]Modding Community [*]Final Thoughts [/list]  [h1] Story [/h1] The story of [i] GTA V [/i] is so masterfully crafted, I don't know where to start! The story from start to finish is AMAZING, much like [i] Grand Theft Auto 4's [/i] story. The only thing that makes [i] GTA V's [/i] story a tiny bit better is the fact that the story never really gets repetitive, which was my only gripe with [i] GTA 4's [/i] story. The fact that there's 3 main characters, all with different backstories and fully fleshed out is amazing as well!  [h3] Endings [/h3] In this sub-chapter, I'm going to discuss the endings of the games, so if you don't want spoilers, the rest will be blacked out using the spoilers feature. [spoiler] The 3 endings of the game are all meaningful in their own right. 2 of the 3 endings involving Franklin killing one of the 2 other main characters, Michael or Trevor. The third ending, being the Deathwish ending, sees Franklin save both Michael and Trevor from being killed. The Deathwish ending is personally my favorite ending, as it is the most action-packed ending of the entire game. [/spoiler]  [h1] GTA Online [/h1] [i] GTA Online [/i] on PC is very dangerous to play at the moment due to hackers and IP grabbers, however the console version (Xbox One, PS4, Xbox Series X|S and PS5) is really fun to play with friends. However public lobbies are not worth going into, because in my experience, getting griefed every 10 seconds by a level 1000 gets annoying after a while.  [h1] Modding Community [/h1] The modding community for PC is amazing. There's many fun mods out there to play, my favorite being [i] LSPDFR [/i] which is one of the most popular [i] Grand Theft Auto V [/i] mods of all time. There's another mod named [i] FiveM [/i] which is also popular amongst Twitch streamers. There's multiple ways to mod and manipulate the game and I suggest doing that once you've beat the story mode.  [h1] Final Thoughts [/h1] This game, in my humble and honest opinion, is the SECOND best [i] Grand Theft Auto [/i] game, the first being [i] Grand Theft Auto 4 [/i] (if that wasn't obvious already). However if I were to rate the game on a scale from 1/10, I'd give it a 8.5/10 (due to the Online mode being unplayable on PC and somewhat unpleasant on console). Anyways, if you enjoyed reading this lengthy review, please leave a like saying the review was helpful! Also I hope this review helped you make your decision on whether or not you wanted to buy this game!

Grand Theft Auto is a series of action-adventure games created by David Jones and Mike Dailly.[2] Later titles were developed under the oversight of brothers Dan and Sam Houser, Leslie Benzies and Aaron Garbut. It is primarily developed by British development house Rockstar North (formerly DMA Design), and published by its American parent company, Rockstar Games. The name of the series is a term for motor vehicle theft in the United States.  Gameplay focuses on an open world where the player can complete missions to progress an overall story, as well as engage in various side activities. Most of the gameplay revolves around driving and shooting, with occasional role-playing and stealth elements. The series also has elements of the earlier beat 'em up games from the 16-bit era. The games in the Grand Theft Auto series are set in fictional locales modelled after real-life cities, at various points in time from the early 1960s to the 2010s. The original game's map encompassed three cities—Liberty City (based on New York City), San Andreas (based on San Francisco),[a] and Vice City (based on Miami)—but later titles tend to focus on a single setting and expand upon the original three locales. Each game in the series centres on different respective protagonist who attempts to rise through the criminal underworld due to various motives, often accompanying themes of betrayal. Several film and music veterans have voiced characters in the games, including Ray Liotta, Dennis Hopper, Samuel L. Jackson, William Fichtner, James Woods, Debbie Harry, Axl Rose and Peter Fonda.[3]  DMA Design began the series in 1997, with the release of the Grand Theft Auto. As of 2020, the series consists of seven standalone titles and four expansion packs. The third main title, Grand Theft Auto III, released in 2001, is considered a landmark game, and brought the series into a three-dimensional environment for the first time. Subsequent titles have followed and built upon the format established by Grand Theft Auto III, receiving significant acclaim. The games influenced other open-world games, and led to the label Grand Theft Auto clone on similar titles.[4]  The series has been critically acclaimed, with all the main 3D entries in the franchise frequently ranked among the greatest and best-selling video games;[5] it has shipped more than 405 million units, making it one of the best-selling video game franchises. In 2006, Grand Theft Auto was featured in a list of British design icons in the Great British Design Quest organised by the BBC and the Design Museum.[6] In 2013, The Telegraph ranked Grand Theft Auto among Britain's most successful exports.[7] The series has also been controversial for its adult nature and violent themes, as well as for cut content.

English:  Homemade Landjäger Sausage  Ingredients: - 500 g beef - 500 g pork - 20 g curing salt (nitrite curing salt) - 5 g coarse ground pepper - 5 g sweet paprika - 3 g garlic powder - 2 g ginger powder - 2 g dried marjoram - 1 g ground coriander - 1 g grated nutmeg - 1 g ground cardamom - Pork casings for stuffing - Kitchen twine  Instructions: 1. Cut the beef and pork into small pieces and pass them through a meat grinder with a coarse plate. 2. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add all the spices (curing salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, ginger powder, marjoram, coriander, nutmeg, and cardamom). Mix well until the spices are evenly distributed. 3. Cover the meat mixture and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours to allow the flavors to develop. 4. Thoroughly clean the pork casings and soak them in cold water to soften. 5. Remove the meat mixture from the refrigerator and knead it again to ensure proper blending. 6. Stuff the meat mixture into the prepared pork casings, ensuring there are no air pockets and that the casings are evenly filled. 7. Cut the filled casings into approximately 10 cm long pieces and tie the ends with kitchen twine. 8. Hang the Landjäger sausages in a cool place to dry for about 2-3 weeks. The ideal temperature is around 15-18 degrees Celsius. 9. After the drying period, the Landjäger sausages are ready to be consumed. They can be enjoyed raw or lightly pan-fried.  Note: When making sausage, it is important to maintain proper hygiene. Ensure all utensils are thoroughly cleaned, and use fresh meat. It is also recommended to familiarize yourself with basic sausage-making principles and consider employing specific sausage-making techniques.    German:  Selbstgemachte Landjäger Wurst  Zutaten: - 500 g Rindfleisch - 500 g Schweinefleisch - 20 g Nitritpökelsalz - 5 g Pfeffer, grob gemahlen - 5 g Paprika, edelsüß - 3 g Knoblauchpulver - 2 g Ingwerpulver - 2 g Majoran, getrocknet - 1 g Koriander, gemahlen - 1 g Muskatnuss, gerieben - 1 g Kardamom, gemahlen - Schweinedärme zum Abfüllen - Küchengarn  Zubereitung: 1. Das Rind- und Schweinefleisch in kleine Stücke schneiden und anschließend durch den Fleischwolf mit grober Scheibe drehen. 2. Das gewolfte Fleisch in eine große Schüssel geben und alle Gewürze (Nitritpökelsalz, Pfeffer, Paprika, Knoblauchpulver, Ingwerpulver, Majoran, Koriander, Muskatnuss und Kardamom) hinzufügen. Gut vermengen, bis die Gewürze gleichmäßig verteilt sind. 3. Die Fleischmasse abgedeckt für mindestens 24 Stunden im Kühlschrank ruhen lassen, damit sich die Aromen entfalten können. 4. Die Schweinedärme gründlich reinigen und in kaltem Wasser einweichen, um sie geschmeidig zu machen. 5. Die Fleischmasse aus dem Kühlschrank nehmen und erneut gut durchkneten. 6. Nun den Fleischteig in die vorbereiteten Schweinedärme füllen. Dabei darauf achten, dass keine Luftblasen entstehen und der Darm gut gefüllt ist. 7. Die gefüllten Därme in etwa 10 cm lange Stücke schneiden und die Enden mit Küchengarn verschließen. 8. Die Landjäger für ca. 2-3 Wochen an einem kühlen Ort zum Trocknen aufhängen. Die ideale Temperatur liegt bei etwa 15-18 Grad Celsius. 9. Nach der Trocknungszeit sind die Landjäger bereit zum Verzehr. Sie können roh gegessen werden oder kurz in einer Pfanne gebraten werden.  Hinweis: Bei der Herstellung von Wurst ist es wichtig, auf hygienische Standards zu achten. Sämtliche Utensilien sollten gründlich gereinigt und das Fleisch frisch sein. Es empfiehlt sich außerdem, sich mit den Grundlagen der Wurstherstellung vertraut zu machen und gegebenenfalls auf spezielle Wurstherstellungstechniken zurückzugreifen.   Chinese:  自制兰德亚格香肠  材料： - 500克牛肉 - 500克猪肉 - 20克食盐（亚硝酸盐食盐） - 5克粗磨黑胡椒 - 5克甜辣椒粉 - 3克大蒜粉 - 2克姜粉 - 2克干马郁兰 - 1克芫荽粉 - 1克磨碎肉豆蔻 - 1克磨碎草果 - 猪肠衣（用于填充） - 厨房绳  制作方法： 1. 将牛肉和猪肉切成小块，然后通过带有粗孔板的绞肉机绞碎。 2. 将绞碎的肉放入一个大碗中，加入所有的香料（食盐、黑胡椒、甜辣椒粉、大蒜粉、姜粉、马郁兰、芫荽粉、肉豆蔻和草果）。充分搅拌，使香料均匀分布。 3. 盖上碗，放入冰箱中静置至少24小时，使香味融合。 4. 彻底清洁猪肠衣，并将其浸泡在冷水中软化。 5. 从冰箱中取出肉馅，再次揉捏均匀。 6. 将肉馅填入准备好的猪肠衣中，确保没有气泡并且填充均匀。 7. 将填充好的猪肠衣切成约10厘米长的小段，用厨房绳扎紧两端。 8. 将兰德亚格香肠挂在凉爽的地方晾干约2-3周，理想温度为摄氏15-18度。 9. 干燥期结束后，兰德亚格香肠即可食用。可以生食或轻微煎炒。  注意：制作香肠时，保持良好的卫生非常重要。确保所有器具彻底清洁，并使用新鲜的肉类。还建议熟悉基本的制香肠原则，并考虑采用特定的制香肠技巧。

Grass is a type of plant with narrow leaves growing from the base. Their appearance as a common plant was in the mid-Cretaceous period. There are 12,000 species now.[3]  A common kind of grass is used to cover the ground in places such as lawns and parks. Grass is usually the color green. That is because they are wind-pollinated rather than insect-pollinated, so they do not have to attract insects. Green is the best colour for photosynthesis.  Grasslands such as savannah and prairie where grasses are dominant cover 40.5% of the land area of the Earth, except Greenland and Antarctica.[4]  Grasses are monocotyledon herbaceous plants. They include the "grass" of the family Poaceae, which are called grass by ordinary people. This family is also called the Gramineae, and includes some of the sedges (Cyperaceae) and the rushes (Juncaceae).[5] These three families are not very closely related, though all of them belong to clades in the order Poales. They are similar adaptations to a similar life-style.  With about 780 genera and about 12,000 species,[3] the Poaceae is the fifth-largest plant family. Only the Asteraceae, Orchidaceae, Fabaceae and Rubiaceae have more species.[6]  The true grasses include cereals, bamboo and the grasses of lawns (turf) and grassland. Uses for graminoids include food (as grain, shoots or rhizomes), drink (beer, whisky), pasture for livestock, thatch, paper, fuel, clothing, insulation, construction, sports turf, basket weaving and many others.  Many grasses are short, but some grasses can grow tall, such as bamboo. Plants from the grass family can grow in many places and make grasslands, including areas which are very arid or cold. There are several other plants that look similar to grass and are referred to as such, but are not members of the grass family. These plants include rushes, reeds, papyrus and water chestnut. Seagrass is a monocot in the order Alismatales.  Grasses are an important food for many animals, such as deer, buffalo, cattle, mice, grasshoppers, caterpillars and many other grazers. Unlike other plants, grasses grow from the bottom, so when animals eat grass they usually do not destroy the part that grows.[7] This is a part of why the plants are successful. Without grass, soil may wash away into rivers (erosion).

Really disappointed with GTA V on PC in 2023. It started as a console port where all the design elements were still focused around controlling the game with a console controller. Eight years later, none of the problems caused by the console port have been fixed. There are also still extremely long loading times for every load screen no matter the PC's performance. On top of this, multiplayer is near impossible because of the number of people who are able to run scripts and cheats in multiplayer without penalty. As I said these have been issues since the game's release on PC but never fixed. Instead they keep pumping out more and more boring missions and game modes and ever more ridiculous vehicles and weapons to try sell the game to new players or so existing players will buy RP. It's evident this company is not interested in retaining players long-term, it's just a pump-and-dump strategy. I'm done.

If you're thinking about picking this up to have some fun with GTA Online, DON'T. Get it for console, if you really have an itch to play. Online is currently next to unplayable for any normal gamer due to the rampant cheaters, which the community calls 'modders' for some stupid reason. What's worse is that Rockstar does next to nothing about it.   98% of the time you will run into a cheater in your server, or whatever game modes you like to play. The only question will be whether they just like to mess with server config stuff like making all NPC's aggressive, or making any nearby vehicles despawn, or more malicious stuff like insta killing you for no reason, teleporting you to an inescapable room, so they can kill you. One thing is for sure, even the good natured 'modders' will kill you if you try for an objective, or to do anything, really.  They use invincibility, fly around, can blow you up out of nowhere, pop the tires on your car repeatedly, spawn vehicles on top of you, bombard you with invisible semi trucks, send you to a menu that is only leavable by alt+f4'ing which tries to download god-knows-what.  I have not had a single session where I was able to just enjoy the game, get fair fights, or even have a chance to accomplish anything. If you do it is just by the good graces of the hackers that literally run the game, and most of the time they will ruin your experience just to be cancerous.   Also worth noting that almost all of my online achievements were forced on me by a hacker I upset, so he found all of the packages, movie probs, easter eggs etc on my account and instantly boosted me. Again... game ruined by hacking low-lifes that just want to ruin this game for people.   TLDR: Online is unplayable because Rockstar doesn't care about the PC community and let's cheaters run the game however they want. The cheaters main goal is to make the game entirely unplayable for any normal gamer (someone not using cheats).

GTA 5 is an unparalleled open-world experience that has absorbed me for over 2000 hours. Rockstar Games has created a masterpiece that continues to captivate players with its expansive world, diverse gameplay, and engaging narrative.  The sheer scale of Los Santos is mind-boggling; every corner brims with life, from bustling city streets to the serene countryside. The attention to detail is impeccable, making exploration a constant delight. Whether engaging in high-speed chases, completing intricate heists, or simply soaking in the vibrant environment, there's always something new to discover.  The trio of protagonists adds depth and variety to the gameplay, each with their own distinct personality and storyline. The missions are diverse, offering a perfect balance of action, strategy, and adrenaline-pumping moments.  The multiplayer mode, GTA Online, is a world in itself. The ever-expanding content, ranging from heists to races and businesses, ensures that boredom is a foreign concept. The community aspect, coupled with the constant updates, makes for an evolving and dynamic online experience.  However, despite its brilliance, GTA 5 isn't without flaws. Occasionally, certain missions might feel repetitive, and the online experience can be affected by occasional glitches or connectivity issues. Yet, these minor setbacks are overshadowed by the game's overall brilliance.  After thousands of hours, GTA 5 remains a pinnacle of gaming excellence. Its immersive world, engaging gameplay, and limitless possibilities make it a timeless classic that continues to draw me back for more.
