In the grandiose tapestry of interactive entertainment, one gem gleams with a brilliance that transcends mere virtual escapades – Grand Theft Auto V, a magnum opus that encapsulates the epitome of digital storytelling and open-world immersion. This opulent masterpiece, birthed from the creative crucible of Rockstar Games, is nothing short of a symphony of pixels, orchestrating an exquisite ballet of chaos and consequence in the sprawling, sun-kissed canvas of Los Santos.  From the very moment one steps into the ethereal realm of GTA V, the senses are immediately ensnared by a sensory feast of visual grandeur. The opulent sunsets that bathe the cityscape in hues so vivid they seem painted by the celestial brushstrokes of a digital deity. The meticulous attention to detail, a testament to the virtuosity of the game's artisans, crafts a metropolis that breathes with a life uncannily mirroring reality.  Yet, it is not merely the aesthetic allure that propels GTA V into the echelons of gaming grandeur; it is the opulent tapestry of narrative finesse that truly sets it apart. The trio of protagonists, Michael, Franklin, and Trevor, form a trinity of diverse tales intricately interwoven, each narrative strand a sublime sonnet in the cacophonous ballad of crime and consequence. The dialogue, a linguistic ballet, is a marriage of wit and grit, a melange that elevates the narrative to operatic heights.  The open-world dynamism of GTA V is nothing short of a technological marvel, an expansive sandbox where every alley conceals a clandestine narrative and every street corner harbors the potential for mayhem. The vehicular symphony, a cacophony of roaring engines and screeching tires, becomes a visceral heartbeat pulsating through the veins of Los Santos.  Amidst this digitized ballet of chaos, the satirical genius of Rockstar Games unfurls like a velvet cloak of wit. The radio stations, an eclectic mosaic of musical genres and comedic satire, mirror the vibrant tapestry of Los Angeles, seamlessly blending the surreal with the uncomfortably familiar.  In the annals of gaming history, GTA V stands as an impenetrable colossus, a testament to the boundless potential of interactive storytelling. It is not merely a game; it is a transcendent experience, a symphony of chaos, consequence, and digital virtuosity that resonates with an indelible imprint upon the soul of the gaming connoisseur. Grand Theft Auto V is not just a title; it is a magnum opus, an opulent crown jewel in the diadem of interactive artistry.  Bad game.

So, what to say? I LOVE THIS GAME, its like playing three games in one Game. First, there is GTA 5 online: You can chat with players and complete Heists, Missions and Robberies. You can play in an open World, big as two cities.  Then, there is Gta Story Mode. The varied Stories of the three different characters are breathtaking and adventurous. I have only got 38 hours in, but im excited to play more, as I am only at 19 percent. At last, there are different Events, like Haunted Halloween or In-Game-Events, like Junk-Energy Motorcycle Events. So you have like Racing, Shooting, Robbing, and multiplayer in just one game. I highly recommend this Game for people, who dont know where to spend their money next, and who cant decide on Ego-Shooter, Racing, and Action Heists or Robberies. So, feel free to buy it. THX

I personally like the single player story, but online is just a wasteland. Everything takes 2000 years to grind for and it is just a time sink. And there are SO many microtransactions. Also RDR2 made me realized how overrated this game is. That game has a far better developed story imo and it does not get a fraction of the attention that GTA V does. GTA V is not bad by any means and this game was a milestone at the time it was made, but I still feel that this game gets far too much praise. I will likely finish the story campaign but that is about all I will likely do in this game. The reason I am giving this a negative review is because most of the content in this game is on GTA online and you already know my opinion on that. Feel free to disagree with me on all of this, but this game is just not for me. I am not saying the game is bad, but online needs to seriously be fixed with all of the hacking, excessive grinding, etc.

Honestly, it's a fun game. I find GTA Online enjoyable. I've spent enough time to rack up millions and still have fun without getting bored, friends are fun to have and coordinate heists with. don't want to deal with griefers? just go into invite-only, Do need money and a new car? complete Dax's story hell you even get a business that you can start with the money you make. I'm honestly skimming over so much but that's just because of how much content there is to do and see, it might get boring after being poor but do not for the love of god spend real money on this game besides buying it just watch Rags To Riches from TGG. I hope this helped you make an educated purchase on the GTA Online aspect.  As far as story goes its a must play, like all Rockstar games stories the story is well crafted and made worth playing with multiple endings.

Graphics ❎ Poor: Extremely outdated or low-quality visuals. ❎ Fair: Basic graphics, but lack detail and polish. ❎ Good: Solid graphics with decent detail and design. ❎ Very Good: High-quality visuals, attention to detail. ☑️ Excellent: Cutting-edge graphics, top-notch design.  Gameplay ❎ Poor: Unresponsive controls, numerous bugs, or frustrating mechanics. ❎ Fair: Basic gameplay, lacks innovation, some issues. ❎ Good: Engaging gameplay, smooth controls, few minor issues. ❎ Very Good: Well-designed mechanics, enjoyable gameplay. ☑️ Excellent: Innovative, immersive, flawless gameplay.  Storyline ❎ No Storyline ❎ Poor: Incoherent, uninteresting, or poorly written plot. ❎ Fair: Basic storyline, lacks depth, or predictable. ❎ Good: Engaging plot, well-written characters. ❎ Very Good: Compelling story, well-developed characters. ☑️ Excellent: Gripping narrative, memorable characters.  Replayability ❎ Poor: Little to no incentive for replay, limited content. ❎ Fair: Some replay value, but lacks variety. ❎ Good: Multiple paths or modes, moderately replayable. ❎ Very Good: Diverse gameplay experiences, high replay value. ☑️ Excellent: Endless possibilities, constantly enjoyable.  Overall Enjoyment ❎ Poor: Unenjoyable, frustrating, or not fun. ❎ Fair: Some enjoyable moments, but overall lacking. ❎ Good: Enjoyable, but with room for improvement. ☑️ Very Good: Highly enjoyable, few flaws. ❎ Excellent: Pure joy, a masterpiece of entertainment.  System Requirements ❎ Poor: Extremely high requirements, not accessible. ❎ Fair: Moderate requirements, but may exclude some. ☑️ Good: Balanced requirements, accessible to most. ❎ Very Good: Low to moderate requirements, widely accessible. ❎ Excellent: Extremely low requirements, accessible to all.  Sound/Music ❎ Poor: Low-quality or repetitive sound/music, detracts from the experience. ❎ Fair: Basic sound/music, doesn't enhance the atmosphere. ❎ Good: Well-composed, fitting sound/music. ❎ Very Good: Immersive audio, enhances the gaming experience. ☑️ Excellent: Outstanding soundtrack, enhances every aspect.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken. ----------------------------------------------------------- Ingredients for 4 servings, 2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed salt, to taste pepper, to taste 2 teaspoons chili powder, divided ½ teaspoon turmeric 6 tablespoons butter, divided 1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced 3 teaspoons garam masala 1 teaspoon cumin 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper 1 tablespoon ginger, grated 3 cloves garlic, minced 1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick 14 oz tomato sauce (395 g) 1 cup water (240 mL) 1 cup heavy cream (240 mL) rice, for serving fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.  Preparation In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let sit for 15 minutes to marinate. Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot. Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder, the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant. Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer. Add the water and cream and return to a simmer. Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes. Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste. Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro. Enjoy!

Gta V is an amazing game. Excellent game to play with friends or family  However !!! -> Since day one peoples are cheating and still do on every online server there are alot of those players that use scripts & hacking tools and they don't get banned ( They use god mode, They can spawn random explosions around the map, teleporting into your car and out or teleporting you to places, they never get banned or kicked off the game, you can see them on every online session or a mission. they will ruin your missions and fun and cause you to get banned like they did to me and if "you" interrupt them in their stuff they just hack/mod your character to get banned.  So you can actually only play online in a closed session limited to so little content you can do but missions require most of the time 4 peoples so get your friends or don't enjoy any of that content or risk on getting banned.  It's not that the game is stable, it crashes every now and then to desktop when you try to do a mission or other activity than just roaming around doing the same things in the world.  So while going to lobby it pop you out of online mode sometimes you end in desktop for no reason, so let's accuse the lobbies :D but nope this is rockstar to be blamed for bad servicing...  Well logging in and out of sessions is taking like 2-4 min on a high speed broadband without using a proxy to improve connection issues... like what the hell this is not a dial up service ??? and eventualy you sometimes get an error message that you cannot join your friend or the session cannot be found. if you are lucky it just load forever - look at your screen for minutes and nothing happens. okey let's try again lol.  Well i'm not sad Rockstar is banning legit players, they already lost most of their playerbase. So i'm happy because they just save us a lot of time trying to play a broken game... It's hard to change bad habits of players and us the casual gamers - we are sick and tired of it.  Let's least hope GTA 6 does it different (Trailer in December)...  Rockstar i'm not blaming you but seriously after 10 years you could have made a change and done "us" players a better service and not this horrible mess!  It's a fact that there's hardly any mission running open on online sessions + all the spam messages coming in your "HOME" online service menu proves that YOU are the one that should be Frustrated and not US. So goodluck working on that and thanks for saving me time o/ see ya, probably not because All Decisions and Reviews are Final.

A True Masterpiece, but Player Behavior Can Be a Challenge  Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)  Grand Theft Auto V is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece. Rockstar has crafted an open-world experience like no other, with a sprawling, vibrant city to explore, an engaging story to follow, and endless opportunities for mayhem and adventure. The attention to detail and the sheer scale of the game world are truly remarkable.  However, the only downside I've encountered in my time with GTA V is the behavior of some players in the online mode. While the game itself is a work of art, the online community can sometimes be a bit challenging. You might encounter griefers, trolls, or hackers from time to time, which can be frustrating when you're trying to enjoy the game.  That being said, I don't think this issue should detract from the game's overall rating. It's more a reflection of the online gaming environment in general, rather than a fault of GTA V itself. Rockstar has implemented various measures to combat these issues, and there are many fantastic players and communities within the game as well.  If you can look past the occasional troublesome player and focus on the incredible content and experiences GTA V offers, you're in for an unforgettable gaming journey. Whether you're into the story mode or the vast online world, GTA V has something for everyone. It's a game that continues to stand the test of time, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an immersive, action-packed adventure.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)  Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) is nothing short of a modern gaming masterpiece. Released in 2013, it has continued to captivate players with its vast open world, immersive storyline, and an unprecedented level of detail that has set a benchmark for the industry.  The most striking aspect of GTA V is its sprawling, fictional city of Los Santos, a stunning and meticulously crafted representation of a modern metropolis. It's teeming with life, from the busy streets to the serene countryside, and you'll find yourself getting lost in the sheer size and detail of the game world. Whether it's a leisurely drive along the scenic coast, an adrenaline-pumping chase through downtown, or an unexpected encounter with the local wildlife in the wilderness, every moment in Los Santos feels like an adventure.  The game's narrative is equally compelling, with three distinct protagonists, Michael, Franklin, and Trevor, each offering a unique perspective and personality. The storytelling is top-notch, weaving a tale of crime, betrayal, and redemption, and it keeps you engaged from start to finish. The characters are well-developed, and the voice acting is superb, enhancing the overall experience.  GTA V's gameplay is a testament to Rockstar's commitment to excellence. It seamlessly blends action, exploration, and driving mechanics, offering a wide variety of activities, from heists to tennis matches, ensuring there's always something to do. The game's gunplay and driving mechanics are polished and satisfying, providing an enjoyable experience for both casual and hardcore gamers.  Moreover, GTA Online, the multiplayer component of the game, extends the fun beyond the single-player campaign. It allows you to explore Los Santos with friends, engage in various missions, or simply create chaos in the sandbox environment. The constant updates and additions have kept the online community engaged for years.  Graphically, GTA V was groundbreaking when it first came out, and it still holds up well today. The attention to detail in the world design, character models, and vehicle physics is outstanding. With the option to play in first-person view, you can immerse yourself even further into the world of Los Santos.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a timeless classic in the world of gaming. It's a game that's not just about entertainment; it's an experience. Even years after its release, it continues to attract new players and retains a dedicated fan base. If you haven't experienced the magic of Los Santos and the engaging narrative of GTA V, you're missing out on one of the most iconic and enjoyable gaming experiences of this generation. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the franchise, GTA V is a must-play title that will undoubtedly leave a lasting impression on you.

"Grand Theft Auto: Where Mayhem Meets Satirical Brilliance"  Introduction: Ah, Grand Theft Auto (GTA), the virtual playground where chaos and satire hold hands, skip down the street, and then promptly steal a car. This iconic video game series has been a source of endless entertainment and controversy, offering players a morally questionable, yet undeniably captivating sandbox to explore. So, let's take a joyride through the twisted streets of GTA and examine what makes it a modern gaming legend.  Graphics: The graphics in GTA are so realistic that if you stare at the screen long enough, you'll start to wonder if you should pay rent for your in-game apartment. From the meticulously detailed urban landscapes to the awe-inspiring sunsets, GTA's graphics are so beautiful that even Mother Nature would be a little envious. Just don't be surprised if you end up admiring the virtual world more than your actual surroundings.  Gameplay: GTA's gameplay is like a bizarre mix of a circus act and a Choose Your Own Adventure novel. You can drive a tank through a shopping mall, steal a jet, or just cruise around listening to some funky radio tunes while evading the police. The game's open-world environment is a never-ending amusement park, where you're free to choose your own wild ride. It's like Disney World, except with more guns and fewer mouse ears.  Storyline: While GTA's narrative isn't exactly Shakespearean in its depth, it's like a cheesy B-movie script that you can't help but love. You play as a character who is almost always morally ambiguous, and you'll find yourself embroiled in various criminal activities that would make even Tony Montana blush. The plot twists are often about as subtle as a sledgehammer, but they are so over-the-top that you can't help but be entertained. It's a bit like watching a soap opera, but with more explosions and fewer evil twins.  Characters: GTA has given us some of the most memorable characters in the gaming world. From the lovable psychopath Trevor Phillips to the suave and stylish Nico Bellic, you'll encounter a cast of characters who are as diverse as they are entertaining. The game excels at creating antiheroes you can't help but root for, despite their many, many flaws. It's like a gathering of your weirdest, wildest, and most unhinged friends at a never-ending house party.  Satire: One of the defining features of GTA is its biting social commentary and satirical humor. The in-game radio stations and commercials offer a hilarious, exaggerated take on American culture, politics, and consumerism. It's like a Saturday Night Live skit on steroids, and you'll find yourself laughing out loud at the absurdity of it all. GTA's satire doesn't just poke fun at society; it skewers it, roasts it, and serves it with a side of chaos.  Conclusion: Grand Theft Auto is not just a game; it's a cultural phenomenon. It's a virtual playground where you can unleash your inner anarchist, all while poking fun at the absurdities of the real world. Sure, it may not be everyone's cup of tea, but if you're looking for an irreverent, action-packed, and often hilarious gaming experience, GTA is the ride you've been waiting for. Just remember to leave your moral compass at the door and your inhibitions in the real world. In GTA, anything goes, and that's precisely what makes it so outrageously, addictively fun.

The cheating problem is completely out of hand to the point where I want a console just so I can play without someone ruining my game. It's obvious Rockstar doesn't care about PC GTA at all because any amount of effort would be an improvement over the current state of this game. Today I played for about 4 hours and got crashed or kicked on 14 different occasions, including 2 different times when I was selling special cargo, which resulted in almost 2 million GTA$ lost. I won't bother contacting Rockstar support again for reimbursement or reporting as they are completely clueless as to what their job is and copy-paste generic answers for every inquiry I've had with them over the past 8 or so years of playing GTA. The in-game report and vote-to-kick system is completely useless because the troublemakers are ALWAYS cheating, and they can just block reports and vote-kicks (not that they work in the first place.) The ratio of cheaters to normal players has to be somewhere around 1 in 4. On top of all this, the game very frequently refuses to load into Online the first, second, or maybe even third time, and I get infinite black screens or loading screens so often that even if I wasn't getting messed with constantly, I'd still have to reload the entire game about once an hour.  Now, onto the (intended) gameplay experience.  Earlier this year, Rockstar removed almost 200 vehicles from the in-game catalogue, under the guise of "streamlining the shopping experience" or some bullshit like that. On next-gen console, they added some sort of car club that you have to pay a monthly subscription for (yes, monthly) to get ONE free car a month and the mere opportunity to purchase some of those vehicles they took away for so-called simplicity. Of course, that hasn't been added to PC (because, again, Rockstar doesn't give a fuck about PC players) so our only option is to either cheat, which kind of ruins the game, or pray that in the next few years the car we want will finally pop up on the podium of the Diamond Casino AND we can somehow win it, or Simeon's dealership will at some point have it in stock.  Vehicle prices have also become outrageous. After modifications, I ended up paying almost 2 million dollars for some dogshit hatchback that doesn't even go fast in a straight line and doesn't turn without losing control. Most of the good affordable cars in the game of course got removed with Rockstar's cleansing efforts so unless you're willing to grind for hours upon hours for a single good car or cheat, you need to pay real money.  Shark cards are also priced the same as when they were released, and still give you the same amount of GTA$ as when they were released, which was way back in 2013. To put that in perspective, if you want the Oppressor Mk2, you'll need to shell out $100 for the bike alone. This doesn't include the price of the Nightclub AND Terrorbyte truck, the Terrorbyte vehicle workshop addon, and the price of all the modifications to the bike that make it worth using.  Solo grinding has become slightly easier over the past year or 2, especially with the addition to warehouse assistants that you pay to source things like cargo, but it's still a nightmare to make money solo, especially when you're first starting out. For things like special cargo and MC businesses, if you don't sell your stock while you have less, you'll be forced to make multiple trips in different delivery vehicles while the other ones play sitting duck and ping themselves on the map for everyone to destroy. Alternatively, you can hire associates or MC members, which sucks because as I said before, a majority of players cheat, and cheaters tend to entertain themselves with griefing. Or you'll hire someone that either leaves the session, destroys your cargo on purpose, or just doesn't help.  In short, my favorite game to absolutely fucking hate.

A great single player story.  I prefer GTA4's story, but not for lack of quality on GTA5.  Three protagonists were a pretty risky gamble on Rockstar's part, but it has a distinct immersion advantage over previous entries.  Trevor is right at home being the agent of chaos; feels great to rack up the wanted level as him.  Franklin embodies the entrepreneurial spirit of your typical early game and Michael acts as the unfulfilled have-it-all where all GTA protagonists end up (it's a lot like a player picking up an old save with a bunch of money, but no direction because most of the missions are done).  I had never really noticed how disjointed the main char of a GTA game was depending on my mood.  The heist structure took the best of the story missions of 4 and created fun variations of heists throughout.  Also, following a crew was a breath of fresh air in the franchise, even if in-crew relationships were not always golden throughout the story.  Weapons feel good and differentiate themselves from each other well.  Gunplay is the best it's been in the series.  Driving has the needle ever-so-slightly dialed back towards arcade-y from the weighty driving of GTA4; a good change, IMO.  Visuals have aged well.  The layout, size and diversity of San Andreas hasn't been matched in a game of this type since.  Tone is well-balanced between classic GTA absurdity, while not taking you out of the story at hand.  Money-making side content is ho-hum; par for the course.  I did enjoy the golf and tennis, which was a pleasant surprise.  I would not advise engaging meaningfully in online, even if you typically enjoy multiplayer.  It feels like it started as one big joke at the expense of pay-to-win "modern gaming" that became the most successful example of the same ever.  Convenient outcome for Rockstar stockholders, I'm sure.   It's a huge money sink and a quintessential griefer's paradise.  Don't pay for the privilege of being a puffer to some whale. </sermon>

The game world itself is fun. It's very entertaining to just drive around and shoot stuff and get into chases and crash frequently, you know, just regular old open world fun. The story itself is full of edgy adult content that doesn't really do anything enjoyable. And online is... well, it's just not that great. Hackers and MTX abound, the game doesn't respect your time, and the networking is god-awful. I mean, you want to fire it up and play a bit and it will make you wait. for. five. entire. minutes. just to load into a server. Once you're on it's mostly serviceable. I don't think it's worth your time investment. And heaven help you if you need anything from Rockstar Support, perhaps the most useless people in the whole industry. There's also a launcher, and it sucks.

Great concept terrible execution and exploitation of consumer. I've had the game for I don't know, a year or so. I've only been able to play it 50% of the time due to bugs and really long load times. Support really evasive. One-sided value system that benefits the company at the expense of consumer. For example, whatever the in-game currency is, people pay real money for that so in situations where a bug or crashed server cost you in-game money, one just loses that unless they're willing to submit to the evasive support program each time. However they are suspending, banning and etc,,, to yes customers for exploiting the third party mod-menus that may reward in-game money.  Let's just look at the subject of modders. I think it's safe to say all modders aren't alike. On one hand you have the griever who goes around heckling any and everybody. On the other hand you have the modder who became a modder to defend against the griever. lastly , the modder who only wants to experience his purchase in a re-imagined way that's not dictated by the game's producer. At any rate the producer should be concerned with what the consumer demand is not with a strict dictatorship of what they wanted the experience to be like. Let's keep it real. Software companies think total emersion is key, when in fact it isn't. All that is needed is just enough realism to fool the surface senses and then the fantasy. For example: Most people lives suck. They don't play video games to remind them how much their lives suck they play to escape. Each time Rockstar releases a version of GTA the public responds with they think the product should be instead of what is presented (mod-menus). Instead of Rockstar taking it as constructive criticism they look at it almost as if you stole or destroyed something. Remember modders are consumers too, and might arguably constitute the majority of Rockstar's clientele base. At the end of the day, it's not what you do but how you do it. Recently, my GTA V account was suspended and online character reset with no explanation. To treat a customer in such a way was shocking, so me knowing such companies live and die off the constant reinvestment of consumers I'm just bidding my time waiting for the release of CTA 6 and I'll pass. I'll pass on anything Rockstar. One for their hubris. Two for the disrespect of the money I invested into the company in comparison to what was gain in actual game play and time. And I'm sure I'm not the only one. I know this was written very poorly but it's early, I'm annoyed and really didn't want to have to write this in the first place, so please forgive my poor grammar.

Don't get me wrong, the game itself can be fun. I have a good number of hours into it over the years. The single player was also quite good. Truthfully there are quite a few reasons to recommend or buy this game if you never have, but given the company behind it and the way they treat their patrons and players, handle their business, communicate things, etc I just can't recommend anyone support this. I firmly believe that we vote with our wallets, and the only way to really impact the bottom line of these greedy corporations is to not buy the shit they are selling if we don't like it. That's how we make them wake up, and that's how we get the changes we want. At the time of release, we didn't know what we know now. The game is what, nearly a decade old at this point? No new game, no real new content, just rehashed things for online. Egregious actions such as removing items from the game that people paid for, and removing the anti-cheat system to prevent it from being a cesspool in public online lobbies. These are just core things that you should not do, and yet, they do them. The price of things use to be somewhat reasonable, it was a nice balance of grind vs reward upon launch. Now, everything is so overpriced its not worth it to grind for, and this was done solely with the malicious intentions to force players to buy shark cards for real money to acquire in game items. The only thing we are missing at this point is a battle pass, then we really will be at the peak of modern games. Anyway, if you already own this game, by all means enjoy it. I implore you not to buy their shark cards, and if you don't already own this game, just pass on this. Save your money or take it elsewhere, preferably to a company/developer that doesn't choose to do the most despicable things at every turn.

Replayability is not guaranteed though.  Thumbs up, because its fun.

This game, really cannot be well described in a review, but i'll try my best.   The Single-Player and Story are very good, lots of activities, quite a sizeable amount of overall variety interms of vehicles, weapons, businesses. However, for those coming from GTA IV, this is a more "light" sided story, rather than the grim from the GTA IV, so don't expect another emotional ride about how war is horrible and it screws people over.  This is more of a cynical reality of what USA is, and wants to be, dumb fun simply said.   Now, the Online section(which is controversial for many).  The Online pretty much is a whole seperate game, and i'd treat it as a MMORPG Sandbox than a open world, this is one of it's biggest flaws and upsides. For those that like to grind their games, this is one of the best mixed genres if you ask me, there is content suited for most likely anyone.   Concluding this whole jumbo-mumbo, buy it, you will definitely get your value from this game(especially on sale, 14 euros?!)

It boasts a vast and diverse world filled with activities and missions that keep players immersed for hours on end. The game's storyline is engaging and the characters are well-realized, allowing players to get emotionally invested in the game's plot. The graphics and sound are top-notch, and the game’s mechanics are intuitive and fun to learn. Despite some minor glitches and occasional frustrations, Grand Theft Auto V remains a classic and highly recommended game.

Mostly Positive. I didn't like the main story because I don't relate with psychopaths so I didn't finish it. But, there is enough to do in the online game for PVE with some friends in a closed session. I generally avoided PVP since there are too many hackers that have ruined open sessions. You can solo play most of the online game in a closed session and I tried that for a while but ultimately got bored quickly. If you buy a military vehicle, you generally can't use it in the heists (except the setup missions), but you can use them for cargo, nightclub and moto-club. The humor in newer updates (such as drug wars) has become more crass/annoying and less tongue-in-cheek. They still haven't fixed the slow player controls after all these years. The only reason I have so many hours in the game is because there was a time when I could go AFK while the nightclub accumulated, but they changed that. I recommend buying this on sale if you're looking for something different to play, but don't expect too much. Once you get to the endgame, there's nothing to do other than collect expensive useless vehicles. Don't hesitate to move on to a different game at that point.

Ah, Grand Theft Auto V, the game that proves crime can be a family affair! From the moment I first stepped into Los Santos, I knew I was in for one wild ride. You see, this game has it all - action, mayhem, and a touch of good ol' family drama.  The city itself is stunning, and it's like a virtual playground for chaos. I mean, I've stolen planes, jumped out of helicopters, and even robbed a few stores with my pals Franklin and Trevor. It's like a never-ending vacation, except with more gunfights and fewer piña coladas.  Franklin is the man when it comes to driving. He's got a need for speed that's just as crazy as mine, but with fewer traffic accidents. Trevor, on the other hand, is well... let's just say he's a unique character. He's the kind of guy you don't want to cross, but he's also the kind of guy you can't help but laugh at. His explosive personality matches the explosive action in the game.  And don't get me started on the missions! From heists to drug deals gone wrong, it's like a never-ending rollercoaster of adrenaline. There's something truly satisfying about pulling off a perfectly executed heist, and then escaping from the cops like a bunch of pros.  But it's not all about crime. You can play tennis, go for a round of golf, or just chill out by the beach. Los Santos is the perfect place for a getaway, as long as you don't mind the occasional gang shootout or police chase.  In a nutshell, GTA V is like a Hollywood blockbuster that you get to star in. So grab your virtual sunglasses, hop in a stolen car, and get ready for a wild ride. Just remember, crime doesn't pay...unless you're playing this game!

Its a thumbs up...  NB. I don't touch online, never will.  Characters are great, the story is nice enough, the heists make the missions a bit more meaningful and connected, the radio is interesting/funny and has some good atmospheric tracks, the open world is really nicely done.  I bought this game twice on Xbox but never finished it because first one disc got trashed, then when I got a second my xbox was trashed. So I picked this up in a sale on pc to finally finish it.  The bad points: - The open world is great, but,.... often meaningless. This was a criticism of mine for San Andreas (albeit one of the greatest games of all time). You can go somewhere and it looks nice, but is there any purpose, or meaning? If you want to shoot beachgoers yes but not a lot else. It reminded me of Fallout IV, where you can build a base with a pool table, but why, when no one interact with you? - They really need to put manual gearchanges in to their next GTA. I know lots of US vehicles are auto but the driving is boring, in that there is no satisfaction of dropping a gear to get up a hill or overtake. - the speed is restricted/unrealistic: watching the speedometer I think it goes up to 100mph for pretty much all cars,.. really, a Ferrari or whatever doing 100mph max? You should be able to push it to 155,... and be punished for doing so by wrapping yourself around a tree. It makes driving (half the game really) quite timid) - Most missions are still just drive,... bang,...shoot,...drive..... crash,... drive,... finish. Look I know it is 'GTA', but still, the missions are quite repetitive and feel quite dumb in the great environment that there is - Controls when walking are awkward. I think this is much better in RDR2, hopefully it will be for any future GTA because the number of missions I messed up because the controls are clanky is huge. I never finished GTA IV because the controls were clanky (and I got sick of being called for dates to go bowling etc.) - all the money houses, businesses, side games don't seem to matter as you can finish tthe story quite early. After the first couple of missions I never went to an Ammunation again... I tried to use the stock market but didn't have enough to invest, then when I did, it was pretty much the end of the game. The golf and tennis is nice, but after a while you think what is the point, might as well get a golf or tennis game! And I totally forgot until now there was hunting. - They spent WAY too much time on doing the whole strip club thing, - Collectables were a bit meh, the whole underwater thing, way too time consuming compared to tagging in San Andreas which was fun.  So many criticisms yet still a thumbs up?  Because if you play through the story, just have a laugh, it is great fun and recommended and ultimately I am glad I played it. I think years ago the side elements of GTA were as good as even full games, but now GTA feels a bit of a jack of all trades, master of none; refining the driving and nicely fluid foot/combat controls in future might help.  Love the characters though just wish there had been twice the story.

This game is a timeless gem that sets the bar high for open-world gaming. Its complete and unique world, diverse characters, and engaging narrative make it an unparalleled experience. From the bustling streets of Los Santos to the stunning landscapes of Blaine County, the game's immersion is unmatched. The ability to switch between protagonists adds depth, humor, and satire to the storytelling. GTA Online's endless activities and heists provide countless hours of fun, but the only drawback is the persistent issue of hackers. Despite this, GTA 5 remains a must-play, a game that no other in its genre has yet to surpass.

So, the story mode in this game? It's a real joy. You can just cruise around, have fun, and get lost in the game world. But let's talk about the online mode, where things take a frustrating turn due to those pesky modders.  Trying to get a simple Heist prep done becomes an ordeal when modders are lurking around. They can blow you up or take you out as soon as you're about to reach your destination. It feels like they're everywhere, on almost every server. Even if you try to report them, it's often futile because they can crash your game and erase any trace of your report from Rockstar's system, leaving them scot-free.  These modders aren't just satisfied with ruining gameplay; they also spam the in-game chat with ads, making it beyond annoying. What's worse, their activities can make the servers lag due to the sheer volume of their antics. Today, I ran into a modder who, at first, seemed like a savior by freeing me from a submarine another modder had trapped me in. But then, they turned the tables by making my character no-clip, sending me soaring into the sky, and then plummeting me to my death. They also teleported me away from my destination just when I was about to reach it. All in all, the online experience on these servers is nothing short of a disaster.  To sum it up, while the story mode is all fun and games, the online mode is marred by these modders who take the fun out of it and create a pretty frustrating environment for players.

An actual amazing game lying beneath a thick coat of broken gameplay and horrible updates.  This game is like the most abusive partner you could ever have.  And though i still have an unexplainable fondness of the game. I seriously cant stomach how unplayable every session has become. Plagued with the same issues repeating themselves, everytime you load up the game. From the horribly laced servers, terrible game stability/crashes, Horrible framerate/peformance drops, Graphical Glitches, and last but not least, getting stuck in a fucking loading screen. And even if you manage to fight through all that, with you sanity left. Then comes the Recycled content/Removal Of Beloved Content, Uninspiring Updates, Constant Phone Calls, and last but not least, modders.  I really love this game. But it definetly has much to come back for, and so much enjoyability. But with all the issues stated above, its simply impossibly for me to have fun playing this game. I just feel iritated.   I recommend you buy this game, because it is with no do doubt a classic, and the story mode is phenomenal (and actually pretty replayable imo) But beaware of the journey of Love, and Rage ahead of you.

HEY! I KNOW YOUR KINDA HUNGRY BUT DO I GOT A GOOD TAMALES GUIDE FOR YOU!  step by step so you cant miss it  INGREDIENTS FOR THE FILLING: 1 pound boneless pork shoulder 1/2 large white onion 2 cloves garlic, divided 1 bay leaf 1 pound tomatillos 4 serrano peppers 1 tablespoon canola oil 1 tablespoon kosher salt, plus more for seasoning 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1 teaspoon Mexican oregano 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, plus more for seasoning  FOR THE DOUGH: 1 large package dried corn husks (about 1 pound) 2 pounds fresh masa for tamales (purchased from a tortillería; not masa preparada), or 3 cups masa harina for tamales 1/2 to 3 cups salted chicken broth (not low-sodium) 1 1/4 cups canola oil 2 teaspoons kosher salt 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder  EQUIPMENT: Steamer pot Large pot or bowl Medium saucepan Stand mixer or electric hand mixer Tongs Blender Strainer Slotted spoon Chef’s knife or paring knife, and cutting board Measuring cups and spoons  INSTRUCTIONS STEP 1: Soak the corn husks. Place 1 package corn husks in a large pot or bowl and add enough hot tap water to cover. Make sure the husks are submerged by weighing them down with a few coffee mugs.  STEP 2: Cook the pork. Cut 1 pound pork shoulder into 2-inch chunks. Season with kosher salt and black pepper. Place in a large saucepan. Cut 1/2 large white onion into 2 pieces, and add 1 piece to the pan. Add 1 of the garlic cloves, 1 bay leaf, and 2 1/2 cups water. Bring to a simmer over high heat, about 7 minutes. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and cook until the pork is fork tender and falling apart, stirring every 20 minutes to prevent the bottom of the pot from burning, 1 to 1 1/2 hours total. Meanwhile, start the chile sauce.  STEP 3: Cook the chile sauce ingredients. Husk and rinse 1 pound tomatillos. Place in a medium saucepan. Add the remaining onion piece, remaining garlic clove, and 4 serrano peppers, and cover with 1 inch of cold water. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to medium. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until the items have softened, about 8 minutes for the tomatillos and peppers, and 12 minutes for the onion and garlic. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the items to a bowl as they are ready. Let cool slightly, then coarsely chop the peppers (discarding any tough stems), onion, and garlic.  STEP 4: Cool the meat. When the pork is ready, use a slotted spoon and transfer it to a bowl. Remove 1/4 cup of the broth for the sauce. Let the pork cool slightly, then shred with your fingers or two forks.  STEP 5: Blend the sauce. Place the tomatillos, chopped chiles, onion, garlic, and 1/4 cup broth in a blender and blend until smooth.  STEP 6: Combine the sauce and meat. Heat 1 tablespoon canola oil in a medium saucepan over high heat until shimmering. Add the sauce in one quick pour. Stir in the shredded pork. Add 1 tablespoon kosher salt, 1 teaspoon ground cumin, 1 teaspoon Mexican oregano, and 1/2 teaspoon black pepper. Bring to a boil and cook for 3 to 4 minutes to let the flavors meld. The filling should taste salty—it needs to be saltier than you’d think, to stand out inside the tamales. Remove from the heat and set aside.  STEP 7: Knead the dough. If using masa harina for your dough, place 3 cups masa harina in a deep mixing bowl and pour in 2 1/4 cups chicken broth. Mix with your hands until the dough is moist and soft. If using fresh masa, knead 1/2 cup chicken broth into 2 pounds masa with your hands until a firm dough forms.  STEP 8: Mix the dough. Pour 1 1/4 cups canola oil into a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. (Alternatively, use an electric hand mixer and large bowl.) With the mixer on low speed — and don’t wear your best clothing, because it will splatter — add the masa in golf-ball-sized pieces one at a time. The dough may look rather lumpy and unattractive here, but it will eventually transform. Stop the mixer and sprinkle in 2 teaspoons kosher salt and 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder. If using masa harina, stir in an extra 1/2 cup chicken broth. Mix on high speed until the dough is very light and fluffy, about 10 minutes more.  STEP 9: Spread the dough inside the husks. Remove 1 corn husk from the water and wipe off any extra water with a towel. Use a rubber spatula to spread about 1/4 to 1/2 cup of dough (the amount depends on the size of the corn husk) in a large rectangle. Leave a few inches of space at the top so the dough doesn’t burst out once it’s cooking, and leave about 3 inches of space at the narrower end of the leaf so you have room to fold it.  STEP 10: Add the homemade filling. Add a small amount of the pork filling (about 2 tablespoons) in a line down the center of the tamal. Don’t add too much, or else it will spill out of the husk when you’re folding it.  STEP 11: Fold the tamales closed. To close the tamale, bring one side of the tamal toward the other, like an empanada or a taco, and press lightly to seal. Then tuck the leaves of the husk over each other into a tube-shape. Press down on the narrower end to seal, then fold up toward the wider end. Set aside folded side down and repeat with the remaining tamales.  STEP 12: Steam the tamales for 35 minutes. Add water to a steamer pot and line the insert with a layer of corn husks. (This helps keep the steam trapped inside and adds a bit of flavor.) Bring the water to a light boil. Place the tamales vertically, open-side up in the steamer, but don’t pack them too tightly or they won’t have room to expand. Cover with some extra corn husks. Cover and steam until the corn husk easily pulls away from the tamal, about 35 minutes.  STEP 13: Let the tamales cool 10 to 15 minutes. Don’t eat the tamales immediately after you remove them from the pot, as they’ll be too soft still. Let the tamales cool for 10 to 15 minutes — they’ll firm up quite a bit and be ready to eat.  AND THERE YOU GO ENJOY!

GTA 5 is brilliant, i love it too bits and everything about the game is perfect... almost. you see even though i am leaving a positive review on this game due to how great it actually is, there is an issue. One single issue that makes the game a little worse than it can be. The cop system in this game isn't great. There is no real way of putting it but it really does kinda suck just a little bit in my opinion. At the time of writing this i have roughly around 20 hours of game play and i think i can say with all honesty that the cops in this game are not the best. it makes a game about committing crimes no longer really feel like it as you constantly have  to worry about the whole system. I think the star system is great, it makes sense and it's easy to understand but just because of how the cops are in this game, it makes it feel more like just an annoyance. please don't take this as a `don't buy this game` kind of review. the game is terrific and i really mean that, it's nearly perfect. i just think the cops could be worked on a little bit and thinking about how a game based around crime can be so easily shadowed upon by the police system within the game. Really do buy the game anyway. It is outstanding, just good it really is but be warned about how the police works in this game, Its very... different to say it lightly.

A wonderful game, full of endless things to do and it's really hard to get bored if you keep an open mind. I personally love the game modes, Arena was one of the best updates to ever come out for a video game, even if it was a massive investment with little return.   Unfortunately, no amount of role playing or amazing updates could ever rid the modders, no amount of vast cash cards could save us. For modders, they always win, children can mod, they don't die, they have infinite money. I don't see how they can play longer than 5 minutes and get bored, but, every lobby has at least one, usually 5.  The only saving hope is that the first 6 months of GTA6 will be clear of modders, maybe it can feel like a real game again without being bombed into San Andres just for saying a modder had a flare up of tiny pp syndrome.

I had a lot of fun initially until I realized that the only thing worth doing are the main missions. The driving and combat feel great.  The game is full of side activities that I didn't find worth doing after a while. I miss the gang wars and dynamism that older games like GTA San Andreas had. It kind of feels like there's nothing to do outside of the main story which is a shame considering the size and scope of the game. Even when I bought new properties, it kind of felt pointless and underwhelming. They also seem to tease a heist system that I never could engage with outside of the main missions.  The humor and tone is ridiculous and entertaining. At least it has that going for it!  6/10

Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) is the quintessential open-world game, and even years after its initial release, it stands as a testament to the sheer brilliance of Rockstar Games. The game's arrival on Steam marks an opportunity for gamers old and new to immerse themselves in the sprawling, chaotic, and endlessly captivating world of Los Santos.  Set in the fictional state of San Andreas, GTA V tells the intertwining tales of three complex characters: Michael, a retired bank robber seeking a life of luxury; Franklin, a skilled repo man eager to escape the streets; and Trevor, a maniacal force of nature with an insatiable appetite for chaos. The storytelling is nothing short of cinematic, drawing players into a world of high-stakes heists, betrayals, and a satirical take on modern American culture.  The first thing that hits you when you enter Los Santos is the sheer scope of the world. The city is a living, breathing entity, with its inhabitants going about their daily lives, contributing to the feeling that you're part of something much larger. The attention to detail is staggering, from the sparkling skyscrapers to the gritty, crime-infested neighborhoods. The game world is a playground that oozes authenticity.  GTA V is not just about the story; it's about the freedom it offers. You can jump into countless side activities, from racing and sports to skydiving and base-jumping. The world is your oyster, and the depth of content is astounding. The heists, in particular, are standout moments that showcase the game's strategic depth and cinematic flair.  Gameplay is a perfect blend of shooting, driving, and general mayhem. The controls are tight, and the variety of vehicles at your disposal makes exploration enjoyable. The shooting mechanics are top-notch, and the cover system is a godsend during intense gunfights. Whether you're evading the police, chasing down criminals, or just cruising through the city, the gameplay is endlessly engaging.  Online multiplayer is where GTA V truly shines. GTA Online takes everything great about the single-player experience and lets you share it with friends or compete against other players in a massive, ever-evolving world. From heists to races, free roam activities, and ambitious player-created content, GTA Online provides a seemingly limitless array of experiences, all while allowing you to build your criminal empire.  Visually, GTA V still impresses, even years after its release. The PC version on Steam offers the best graphics, with support for high resolutions, detailed textures, and customizable settings that make the game look even more breathtaking. The attention to detail extends to the dynamic weather and day-night cycle, which contribute to the immersive experience.  While GTA V is a masterpiece, it's not without its controversy, particularly due to its mature themes, violence, and satirical commentary. However, for those who can appreciate the game for what it is—an open-world work of art—it offers a thrilling and unforgettable experience.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V on Steam is a must-have for any gaming enthusiast. It's a testament to the boundless creativity and ambition of Rockstar Games, offering a world that's a playground for chaos, storytelling, and exploration. If you haven't yet experienced the brilliance of Los Santos, there's never been a better time to dive in and see what all the hype is about.

GTA V was apart of many childhoods including mine. Before it got butchered with online updates.  Pros:  - Graphics, especially it being first released on Old Gen consoles, that have less then a GB of RAM by the way. (The PS3 had 512MB and The Xbox 360 also had 512 MB)  - Physics, despite it being a downgrade compared to GTA IV, its still very great and way ahead of its time.  - Open World, to this day, GTA V is probably the greatest free roam of all time in an open world. The cars, movies, buying clothing, robberies, really anything you can think of honestly.  - Story, its just iconic. Three main characters, living the American Dream.  - RAGE Engine, now this is somewhat apart of the Graphics section I mentioned, but I have to talk about the fact that this Engine got made 10+ years ago. And still holds up to this particular day and age. Absolutely amazing.  - Map Design, Los Santos is a really great map, just a very well made replica of LA.  - The Modding capabilites, I to this day. Play this game Modded, FiveM, the VR Mod, Steering wheel support, Trainers, it really blows out the competition in different games that dont come with modding support.  - AtD (Attention to Detail) R* has added alot of AtD to GTA V, like the flip flops that Michael can wear, literally flip flop!  - The Radio, the music catalogue in GTA V is very fitting and well thought of R* to increase the immersion and make it really feel like a Radio Station, the announcers, the music, the licenses, its pretty great honestly.  Cons:  - Alot parts of the map, are "Wasteland" what do I mean by saying this? well... despite the map being pretty large. Theres alot of spots that are just hills, sand, and it just gets repititive like "Oh hey, I have been here before?"  - All side-characters are in my opinion, very irritating. Despite for example people like "Debra" while Trevor lived at Vespucci. Even though we only get to really see her once in a cutscene before she got killed by Trevor, you really could tell how much of an annoyance she would have been if she didnt die.  - GTAO, back then it was more about being a criminal in online and really playing like it was meant to be. Nowadays its filled with Jets, MK2, and shark cards that get bought with moms credit cards... lovely.  Overall:  If your looking for a great SP game, good Graphics even nowadays, and modding capabilites. Then you should definetly buy this! However, the online is at an all time low. Its not necessarily great and as mentioned, its filled with people who just blow you up, so if you really want to play online. Just go into Passive Mode.

Grand Theft Auto V is an absolute masterpiece that immerses players in a sprawling, dynamic open-world filled with endless possibilities. With its gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and revolutionary gameplay, it is a game that demands both your attention and support.  First and foremost, Grand Theft Auto V offers a captivating and cinematic storyline that rivals the best Hollywood blockbusters. The narrative follows the lives of three distinct protagonists, each with their own motivations and personalities. The engaging and complex characters, combined with exceptional voice acting and writing, create a truly immersive experience that keeps you invested from start to finish.  The game's world, the fictional city of Los Santos, is a vibrant and meticulously designed playground that feels alive and bustling with activity. The attention to detail is astonishing, from the bustling city streets to the sprawling countryside and everything in between. Exploring the vast map is an adventure in itself, with countless hidden secrets, side missions, and random encounters that add depth and richness to the experience.  The gameplay of Grand Theft Auto V is revolutionary and incredibly diverse. Whether you're engaging in thrilling heists, participating in intense gunfights, or simply enjoying the freedom of causing chaos in the open world, the game offers an unparalleled level of immersion and player agency. The seamless transition between the three protagonists adds a unique twist, allowing you to switch between characters and witness the events from different perspectives.  Furthermore, Grand Theft Auto Online expands the game's already massive world, offering a robust multiplayer experience. Whether you're teaming up with friends to tackle missions or engaging in adrenaline-fueled competitive modes, the online component extends the game's longevity and provides endless entertainment. The constant updates and additions from the developers ensure that there's always something new to discover and enjoy with friends.  The developers of Grand Theft Auto V have demonstrated their commitment to delivering an exceptional gaming experience through continuous support and updates. The addition of new content, including vehicles, weapons, and missions, keeps the game fresh and engaging. The dedication to maintaining a thriving online community and the introduction of player-created content showcase the developers' commitment to fostering a vibrant and creative player base.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a groundbreaking and immersive gaming experience that combines a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and revolutionary gameplay. Its vast open-world, diverse gameplay mechanics, and robust multiplayer component make it a game worth supporting and investing in. Prepare to be captivated by the world of Los Santos and embark on an unforgettable journey of crime, chaos, and camaraderie. Your adventure awaits in Grand Theft Auto V.

I am a 35 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is one of the funniest outrageous games ever.  Humor in most everything.  A parody of life in Los Angeles. The story is great fun. You can play any one of the three main characters at any time (after you play through some of the story), and for a short time, a dog.  Listen to the many funny non-playable characters voices. The missions are challenging. And even when you don't feel like following the story, you can experiment as much as you want, explore the sandbox that is its open world.  I have played numerous hours every so often since  the game was released. I find it a good stress relief from a tough day at work, forget about things for a while.  If you have never played this masterpiece, I highly recommend you try it!

No overarching plot leads to events feeling very disconnected. It's got a very inconsistent tone, it both doesn't take itself seriously and takes itself too seriously.   Let's compare this to GTA IV. GTA IV had a dark, gritty tone and serious story. Despite this, it was still able to crack jokes at times and be lighthearted. Most of all, the jokes didn't suck and weren't dropped every 5 minutes. GTA IV's missions also all connected together and interwove a tight plot that was entertaining.  I suppose it plays fine, but it's just really meh otherwise.

It's GTAV. I don't care for the online aspect of it, but the Single Player offerings have been more than enough to   to bring me back to Los Santos time and again through the years. Some missions are a slog, specially the ones where you need to cross the map on a truck or some other slow vehicle, but there are widely available quality of life mods that make these kinds of activities much more bearable, such as the autodrive options in something like ENT — a must have for me personally.

When I first payed it I was not impressed. But ten years later, after a decade going backward in terms of games quality, I can say this game is a masterpiece.   Still worth it in 2023, the graphics are still surprisingly good, the scenario is all you can expect from this type of game, and the city is just amazing.   Also, if you like this game, please try "Sleeping Dogs", still also worth it in 2023, with better hand to hand combats and amazing car chases.

Rockstar has somehow kept this alive for 50,000 years. GTA VI will have an extremely high standard to live up to. Is mostly fun with friends to do missions or heists. The grind to get money is crazy hard but once you have stuff the game gets kind of boring. Servers are riddled with hackers and Oppressor Mk II's that make anyone who isn't a participant miserable. Occasionally you will come across lobbies where everyone is wholesome and those moments make it so worth it.  Car meets, chases, just messing around having fun with strangers and good vibes. 8/10 overall. Curious for GTA6.

A LOT OF BUGS AND CHEATERS, THESE FACTORS RUIN THE IMPRESSION OF THE GAME MAXIMUM. WHEN I TRY TO PASS THE SAME THING 4 TIMES, AT FIRST BECAUSE OF A BUG THE PHOTOS DO NOT COUNT AT ALL, I HAVE TO WAIT A DAY, THEN THE CHEATER TELEPORTS TO THE OTHER END OF THE MAP INTO THE SKY AND ALL AGAIN. I'M REALLY SICK OF THIS. THIS GAME HAS HUGE PROBLEMS WITH BUGS AND CHEATERS, THIS IS THE FIRST TIME I'M WRITING SUCH A REVIEW. HAVING ALMOST 1000 HOURS OF PLAYING, I CAN CONFIDENTLY SAY THAT SOME UPDATES DO NOT INTERACT WITH EACH OTHER, THE DEVELOPMENT TEAMS APPEAR TO WORK SEPARATELY. EVERYTHING IS RELEASED ONLY AS WELL AS IT WORKS MORE OR LESS, THEN IT IS DISCOVERED A LOT OF BUGS. CHEATERS CAN DO ANYTHING IN EACH SESSION, GIVE YOU MONEY, PLAY YOU THE INTRODUCTORY FILM OF GTA ONLINE, TELEPORT YOU ANYWHERE, ETC. I WOULD GIVE THE GAME 8/10 BUT BECAUSE OF BUGS AND CHEATERS THE GAME DOESN'T DESERVE HIGHER THAN 4/10

I've owned this game a long time and now I can't play it. When I bought it my teenage daughter was sharing my account and the game is tied to one of her old rockstar accounts apparently. She's now an adult and not living with us but before she moved out we created her own steam account and I bought her her own copy of this game. Up until now, none of this was a problem. It was just logged in.  But I made this simple mistake of upgrading one of my hard drives. I cloned it to a larger, faster SSD but in the process Windwows gave it a different letter. It suddenly was looking for the launcher/social club on a drive letter that didn't exist and it said I didn't have space to install it. A little googling shows a consensus that this is a know issue and the only way to solve it is to use a 3rd party uninstaller to remove every trace of the old program.   I did that and it let me reinstall it. Finally. But now it wants me to log in with an account that was set up with my daughter close to a decade ago. There's no way around it. I can't log in with a new account, or with my own rockstar account that is tied to other games I own on this same steam account. I would buy another copy just to not have to deal with this BS but I can't do that in Steam with my existing account, and even my daughter isn't able to help me. So do I have to create a new steam account to play this game? Rockstar sucks.

Grand Theft Auto V is a highly acclaimed video game that has captivated millions of players worldwide. With its immersive open-world setting and engaging gameplay, it has undoubtedly become one of the most popular games of all time.  One of the aspects that sets Grand Theft Auto V apart is its stunning graphics. The visuals are incredibly detailed and realistic, bringing the game's world to life. Whether you're cruising through the bustling streets of Los Santos or exploring the picturesque countryside, the attention to detail is truly impressive.  Furthermore, the gameplay mechanics in Grand Theft Auto V are incredibly robust and varied. From high-speed car chases to intense shootouts, the game offers a wide range of thrilling activities to keep players entertained. The ability to switch between three different protagonists adds an extra layer of depth and excitement to the gameplay experience.  The storyline in Grand Theft Auto V is also praiseworthy. It follows the lives of three main characters, each with their own unique personalities and motivations. The narrative is filled with unexpected twists and turns, ensuring that players are constantly engaged and eager to see what happens next.  In addition to its captivating gameplay and storyline, Grand Theft Auto V also boasts a vast open-world environment. Los Santos is a sprawling city filled with countless activities and hidden secrets. Whether you want to participate in adrenaline-pumping heists, engage in side missions, or simply explore the city's nooks and crannies, there's always something to do in this expansive virtual world.  Furthermore, Grand Theft Auto V has a thriving online multiplayer mode, allowing players to connect with friends and strangers alike. Whether you want to team up for cooperative missions or engage in competitive multiplayer battles, the online component adds a whole new dimension to the game and ensures that players keep coming back for more.  Overall, Grand Theft Auto V is a masterpiece in the gaming industry. Its stunning graphics, immersive gameplay, captivating storyline, and expansive open-world environment make it a must-play for any video game enthusiast. It's no wonder that it continues to be widely praised and loved by gamers around the world.

GTA V : Online is a load of fun, if you have friends that will play in a private session with you. I cannot attest to the public sessions, as I avoid them actively. But, if you don't have friends, you can still solo, it will just take you longer to achieve the same ends. Example: Caya Pericho has a 2.5 hour cooldown solo, and ~45 min cooldown with a partner or group.   With that said, I keep coming back for more, as I am a social gamer.  Highly recommend for other social gamers!

Has become pay to cheat in so many levels. Delivery Missions are so repetitive, it gets old really quick. Rockstar decreased rewards from Missions, maybe to incentive Hacks - more likely. There are a lot of bugs, I can't even number them all. But for instance, you spend a lot of money to get a fully upgraded Nightclub, then it just stops working properly and you have to buy another one because that one bugged your products productions. You ask for a vehicle and it spawn miles away for no apparent reason. Something you wont get the rewards after spending 30 minutes of a pointless mission because of Transaction Bug. Enemies will spawn on weird places killing you after you made sure the coast was clear. Enemies wont stop spawning until you follow the script - which most of the time is annoying. If you go into a business, you have a 2% chance of blackscreen. Endless miles on slow trucks delivering stuff that could easily placed on top of a V8 Truck and speed the crap out of the sale, instead of wasting time driving 10mph. Everything is expensive and mission rewards are low. That's why there's so many cheaters, hacks and modders online. Rockstar bans people for cheating at the Casino, but keeps GodMode morons teleporting about ruining Open Activities.  Overall, better downloading a F2P wannabe GTA than paying and paying for cards to be outclassed by any random guy with access to a hacks forum.

Introduction: Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) is not just a video game; it's an interactive crime saga that continues to captivate players across multiple platforms. Developed by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games, GTA V has become a cultural phenomenon since its initial release in 2013. With a vast open-world setting, compelling characters, and a narrative that weaves together crime, humor, and drama, the game has earned its place as one of the most iconic titles in the gaming industry.  Graphics and Presentation (5/5): GTA V's sprawling landscape of Los Santos and Blaine County is a visual marvel. The attention to detail is staggering, with realistic character models, dynamic weather systems, and a day-night cycle that adds depth to the immersive environment. The game seamlessly transitions between the urban chaos of the city to the serene beauty of the countryside, creating a living, breathing world that feels authentic and alive.  Character Development and Narrative (4.5/5): The heart of GTA V lies in its three protagonists—Michael, Franklin, and Trevor—each with their own distinct personalities, motivations, and story arcs. The narrative weaves their tales together in a way that keeps players invested in the lives of these morally ambiguous characters. The writing is sharp, and the dialogue is filled with humor and social commentary, creating a narrative that feels both entertaining and thought-provoking.  Gameplay and Open World (5/5): GTA V's open-world design is a testament to Rockstar's mastery of game development. The map is vast and diverse, offering a mix of urban landscapes, suburban neighborhoods, and expansive countryside. The ability to seamlessly switch between the three protagonists adds a unique layer to the gameplay, allowing players to experience different perspectives and playstyles.  The game's missions are varied and offer a mix of action-packed heists, intense shootouts, and entertaining side activities. From high-speed chases to leisurely rounds of golf, the open-world freedom is one of GTA V's greatest strengths. The addition of GTA Online further extends the gameplay, providing a massive multiplayer sandbox for players to explore and engage in criminal enterprises with friends.  Soundtrack and Sound Design (5/5): GTA V boasts a soundtrack that complements the game's atmosphere perfectly. The radio stations feature a diverse range of music genres, providing a dynamic and immersive audio experience. The voice acting is top-notch, with memorable performances that bring the characters to life. The ambient sounds of the city, from the bustling streets to the distant sounds of police sirens, contribute to the game's overall realism.  Conclusion: Grand Theft Auto V stands as a landmark achievement in the gaming industry. Its combination of stunning graphics, engaging narrative, diverse gameplay, and a meticulously crafted open world sets a standard that few games can match. Despite its age, GTA V continues to draw players into its criminal underworld, proving that it's not just a game; it's an enduring masterpiece that transcends generations. Whether you're a newcomer or a returning player, GTA V remains a must-play title that showcases the immense potential of interactive storytelling in gaming.  Rating 10/10

[h1] Grand Theft Auto V [/h1]  [h2] Review Date: [/h2] October 7, 2023  [h2] Reviewer Name: [/h2] Schqrk Reviews  [h2] Overall Rating: [/h2] 8/10 ⭐  [hr][/hr]  [h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]  [✔️] 🎮 Graphics quality and detail: The game's graphics have come a long way since 2013, and they continue to impress. [✔️] 🖼️ Art style and design: The open-world of Los Santos is meticulously designed, creating a vibrant and immersive environment. [✔️] ⚙️ Performance and optimization: The game runs smoothly on a mid-range PC, and the transition from console to PC was seamless. [h2] Gameplay [/h2]  [✔️] 🎮 Controls and responsiveness: The controls are intuitive, allowing for seamless navigation and action-packed gameplay. [✔️] ⚙️ Mechanics and gameplay depth: GTA V offers a wide range of activities and missions, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging. [✔️] ⏩ Pacing and balance: The pacing is excellent, offering both thrilling action and moments of relaxation. [h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]  [✔️] 📜 Plot and storytelling: The game's storyline is a standout, offering compelling characters and memorable moments. [✔️] 👤 Character development: The characters, especially the three protagonists, are well-developed and add depth to the narrative. [✔️] 🌟 Immersion and engagement: GTA V's immersive world keeps you coming back for more, even after years of play. [h2] Audio and Sound [/h2]  [✔️] 🎵 Soundtrack and music: The game's intense soundtrack sets the mood for high-stakes action. 🎵 [✔️] 🔊 Sound effects: Realistic sound effects play a critical role in gameplay. 🔊 [✔️] 🗣️ Voice acting: "You Forget A Thousand Things Every Day, Pal. Make Sure This Is One Of 'Em." - Iconic line from the game's voice acting. Memes like this have become legendary in the gaming community. 🗣️ [h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]  [✔️] 🕒 Game length: GTA V's story mode is substantial, and the online mode adds endless hours of gameplay. [✔️] 🔁 Replay value: The game's replay value is exceptional, with every match offering a unique challenge. 🔁 [✔️] 🎁 Unlockables and collectibles: Unlocking new operators and skins adds to the excitement. 🎁 [h2] Multiplayer (if applicable) [/h2]  [✔️] 🌐 Multiplayer functionality: Multiplayer is the heart of GTA Online, but it's important to note that there are no more DLC updates coming to the game. [✔️] 👥 Online community and matchmaking: The online community is thriving, with players sharing strategies and memes. However, it's important to mention that future developments for GTA Online might be limited due to the possible release of GTA 6 in the coming years. 🌐 [✔️] 📶 Stability and connection quality: Connection quality is generally stable. 📶 [h2] Bugs and Technical Issues [/h2]  [❌] 🐞 Game-breaking bugs: While there have been occasional bugs, the development team is usually quick to address them. [❌] 🐛 Minor glitches: Minor issues do pop up, but they often lead to funny moments. 🐛 [✔️] 🔄 Patch and update history: Regular updates and patches keep the game fresh and balanced. 🔄 [h2] Community and Support [/h2]  [✔️] 🤝 Developer responsiveness: The developers actively engage with the community, listening to feedback and making improvements. 🤝 [✔️] 🧩 Modding support: Modding isn't officially supported, but the community's creative content is impressive. 🧩 [✔️] 💬 Community forums and discussions: The GTA V community forums and discussions can be both a valuable resource and a place of toxicity and rudeness. It's a mixed bag where you'll occasionally encounter both friendly and unsavory players. 💬 [h2] Final Thoughts [/h2]  [✔️] 🌟 Pros and highlights: Tactical gameplay, depth of strategy, vibrant community, and unforgettable moments. [✔️] 🚫 Cons and drawbacks: The game can be difficult for new players due to its grind and the hours needed to be put in, and the community's occasional toxicity can be discouraging. Playing with friends can significantly enhance the experience. [✔️] 🤔 Would you recommend this game? Absolutely, especially if you enjoy intense tactical shooters and appreciate a community that embraces humor and memes. Be prepared for a steep learning curve and occasional encounters with unfriendly players. And you might encounter cheaters and hackers on PC. Also, keep in mind that there are no more DLC updates planned for GTA Online, and the possible release of GTA 6 in the coming years could change the landscape. Nevertheless, it's a game that never loses its charm, and you'll find yourself saying, "You Forget A Thousand Things Every Day, Pal. Make Sure This Is One Of 'Em." just for fun. [h2] Additional comments [/h2] Having played GTA V since 2013, I can confidently say it's a game that never gets old. The transition to PC was smooth, and even though hackers can occasionally disrupt the experience, playing with friends makes up for it. The storyline remains a standout, and while a powerful PC isn't required, a mid-range modern PC handles the game well. Keep in mind that the online mode can be grindy, but there's no shortage of activities to keep you entertained in Los Santos. With the possibility of GTA 6 on the horizon, it's an exciting time to be a GTA fan.  [hr][/hr]  [h1] Overall Summary [/h1] Grand Theft Auto V continues to shine in 2023 as a tactical masterpiece with an engaging storyline and a vibrant online community. While newcomers may find the game's complexity challenging, playing with friends enhances the experience. However, it's important to note that there are no more DLC updates planned for GTA Online, and the possible release of GTA 6 in the coming years could change the landscape of the series. Despite these considerations, GTA V remains a timeless classic that offers countless hours of enjoyment in the sprawling world of Los Santos, where even iconic lines like "You Forget A Thousand Things Every Day, Pal. Make Sure This Is One Of 'Em." have become legendary memes in the gaming community.

It's an addicting game, but still super buggy. It's even worse if you want to actually play online with other players, as the load times are horrendous, and they get even worse when there is an inevitable modder in the server. If you haven't started playing GTA online, dont bother, unless you want to spend half of your session on your phone during the loading screens.  And don't even get me started on Rockstar's greedy practices. Removing around 200 vehicles that can be bought back easier with GTA plus, nerfing Cayo Perico heist again and again, holding some ten year anniversary items behind a paywall (GTA plus).... that's just what's on the tip of my tongue.   I kinda wish I never started playing, because now I can't stop, which subjects me to hours of frustration when I want to play with other players. I strongly suggest finding another game to get addicted to.  EDIT: I somehow failed to mention that if the load times in public lobbies weren't bad enough, the modders will make things worse. You are GUARANTEED to run into a modder who will do anything they can to ruin your experience, from constantly blowing you up, to destroying your product, and sometimes spawning you elsewhere out of the blue. It's an absolute s h i t show.
