I wish there was a way to review the single player and multiplayer separately. The single player is missing lots of things that you expect from a modern title, mostly because the single player is about 10 years old at this point (literally 9 days away from a 10 year anniversary as I write this). But otherwise, the single player game is about everything you've come to expect from a great developer like Rockstar. The multiplayer game is about everything you expect from an absolutely scumbag horrible publisher like TakeTwo Interactive. The multiplayer is bugged as shit, has almost no incentive to play, filled with griefers and hackers (oh sorry, 'modders'), is 10 years old and TakeTwo have literally said they don't want you playing their game if you don't buy shark cards. I'm just going to go ahead and say: don't buy this game. Even for the single player, its a bit old and there are better single player games out these days (i.e. Witcher 3, Fallout, etc). The multiplayer is a horrendous piece of dog shit that is so obviously tacked on by TakeTwo as a way to try to milk this game for all the money they can get so they don't have to fund a new GTA game for as long as possible.  The real takeaway from GTA5 should really be that you should be extremely wary of GTA6. I'm sure Rockstar will do an absolutely amazing job on developing the game and the single player campaign, but TakeTwo is going to ruin it like they do everything else. Hell, look at the state of KSP2 - that is TakeTwo really pushing that game into early access before it's ready.  And remember TakeTwo wanted to shut down ALL mods for KSP1. TakeTwo is a horrendous piece of shit publisher right up there with the likes of Electronic Arts, but doesn't get quite the flak that Electronic Arts gets because TakeTwo mostly works on things that aren't quite as mainstream for PC, or for things that are mostly console titles like GTA.  Avoid GTA5, and I'd avoid buying GTA6 until well after release when it starts going on sale (maybe not even then - let's see the reviews first...)

Rockstar has done nothing to address the modder problems that are well known on PC (Almost every GTAO lobby).   - You can have your account banned remotely by a modder - You can have funds removed from your account by a modder - Invite only lobbies / closed lobbies don't help you as they are even able to kill you in SINGLEPLAYER! - They can teleport you / everyone around the map at will and kill you at will - They can make you stumble in an endless loop so that you aren't able to move - The mods that they are using potentially go further than GTA and can be used to penetrate your PC  A firewall is a potential way to protect yourself but it doesn't make you invulnerable to these exploits This game has been out for 10 years and these problems still persist if you choose to play GTAV you're doing so at your own risk as this has spawn an environment for people to exploit without consequences.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BXuLZ5tvQlY&ab_channel=TheProfessional

Updated review:  I think they're letting the game sink by choking new players from most profits. You'll probably need at least 100 hours of grind as a new player to get to a "barely good" enough state IF you put all your money into businesses. It's going to be a really tedious grind cause you will need 2 heists just to buy ONE CAR. The best profit avenue has been ridiculously nerfed and considering it takes about 1hr to set up and $100k in-game currency just to start setting up, I can no longer justify baring with the tediousness of the best profit avenue on the game.  R* probably just want players to move on to GTA 6 when it comes at this point, so I suggest saving up both your time,and your money and wait for it to come out.  Old review:  "Ironically enough, the "Grand Theft Auto" part fades the longer you play the game cause you'll end up using cars you own and worked hard to pay for anyway. Or not use a car at all."

I bought the retail version of this game when it first launched. It worked fine with no issue at all for years. Then one day, Rockstar decided to launch their own launcher. All my Rockstar games stopped working, even the ones I had on steam. Since then, I've periodically tried to fix the issue and play GTA V. Tired of not having it work, I decided to buy it on Steam and see if anything changed, although I knew it wouldn't. I've got every error code in the book, I've tried every fix, all the official ones, all the Reddit ones, nothing. This garbage company decided to release their trash garbage launcher and I can't play the games I've payed for. At least I can refund this one. Rockstar, fix your garbage trash launcher no one wants or get rid of it. I only want to play singleplayer, why can't I bypass your garbage trash launcher? I finally decided to let the game run with the error code so I could write a review. This review is all I can do, the quiet echo of my voice will fade into nothingness, while this garbage trash company run by donkeys continues to profit. GTA IV and GTA V, two of my all time favorite games, now forever taken from me because the donkeys running this company wanted to gather more power. Maybe one day it won't be garbage trash anymore. Maybe, one can dream.

[table]       [tr]       [th]Category[/th]       [th]Score[/th]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Overall Rating[/td]       [td]★★★★☆[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Story[/td]       [td]★★★★★[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Gameplay[/td]       [td]★★★★☆[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Graphics[/td]       [td]★★★★☆[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Sound Design[/td]       [td]★★★★★[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Replay Value[/td]       [td]★★★☆☆[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Difficulty[/td]       [td]★★☆☆☆[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Bug free?[/td]       [td]★★★★★[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] PC Requirements[/td]       [td]★★☆☆☆[/td]       [/tr]       [tr]       [td] Game Length[/td]       [td]▰▰▰▰▰▰▱▱▱▱       [/td]       [/tr]       [/table]  A solid well-written game; you start out as a heist member, where in a suddenly turn of events things go wrong, and you and your buddy Brad are sniped.  Fast forward a decade later, you play as a ex-Families Gang member named Franklin Clinton, repoing a car for Simeon Yeterian.  You are eventually tasked to repo a car from a kid named Jimmy De Santa, and sure enough you get a handgun pointed to your dome.  Turns out that man you played as Michael Townley is now Michael De Santa,  who faked his death during the heist to enter a Witness Protection Program.  Smash into the car shop window, Michael pays you for a job well done.  The games event’s then spontaneously kick off from that and propels the plot.        There is a variety of activists to do in Los Santos or Blaine County; such as events, Strangers and Freaks, Activities, and some events get your new heist members for future heists. The gunplay in the game is linear, but smooth and intuitive.  The special abilities the trio have are unique and engaging.  It helps you to have an edge over the various enemies in the world such as the Los Santos Police Department,  the Ballas, etc.  Activities are somewhat repetitive, and boring after a while.  The Strangers and Freaks mission is a mixed bag, some of the characters are fun and engaging;  while others are monotone and annoying.  Tasked with different tasks based on the Stranger you are dealing with and what they want.  The game in my playthrough which is somewhat rushed, but also doing all the events and a quarter of the Strangers and Freaks missions; the entire length of the game took me about 39.2 hours to beat. A felt like a real ride, with a sense of achievement based on the 1 of 3 endings you choose. That will be something you will have to find out in your playthrough.   8.5/10 would strongly recommend this game for it’s single-player experience alone, not so much for online because of the rampant hackers in lobbies.

I recommend the game for the story mode, which is the quintessential GTA V experience that we've all known for the last 10 years.   This game is probably the most fun driving experience I've had outside of dedicated racing games, and every other game falls short when compared to this one.  HOWEVER ONLINE MODE  As a new player you should be super aware that modders in lobbies are very common. And most have a superiority complex. About 60% of the time it's fine unless you try to get in a fight with one, in which case you will have a bad time, being stuck in a death loop. Best way to avoid that is to just type in chat that you're going to go AFK and stop giving them the satisfaction- they give up super quickly. (or just move to a new lobby of course).  Even ignoring modders- as a new player it's pretty hard to get to the good content- which is all the expensive stuff in the game- this truly is the American dream which Rockstar has made millions from over the last 10 years. I used to play the game on console so I've had an easier time getting used to it however- 90% of modders are selfish, but occasionally you'll get random modders who'll just give you a tonne of XP and money which can help you skip a lot of grinding.  If you ever reach the point you get a lot of items- good cars, guns, apartment etc- it's pretty satisfying.  Online mode is full of modders- usually fine until they decide to grief you- in which case you move to a new lobby. you can still have fun in the game though- there's a lot to do, and sometimes its kinda overwhelming as a new player. if you're lucky a nice modder will just give u money and levels, and then you can actually enjoy the game- it's a slick experience when you have a lot of the stuff- otherwise it's a pain to grind.

Forget about what percentage of reviews are positive . . . look at the NUMBER of reviews here. This is a milestone in gaming, and anyone who "likes video games" should play it. It's a really good story, and it doesn't get boring at any point. The worst thing about this game is that I can't let my kids play it yet.

Would not let me adjust my brightness to be able to see the game to play in online mode.  You can do this in story mode though?  That's dumb enough for me to not want to play anymore after coming back from a long break.  There is no way to change this in online mode to make the game playable while it is nighttime.  I would have to quit mission, load into story mode, turn it up or down and have to wait for time of day to change to make sure I can SEE???  That is the most asinine thing I have ever had to do to change a setting.  After another hundred hours I've grown tired of the time/money walls.  I cannot complete sell missions without running out of time if I solo.  The rest of the time is spent solely on resupplies.  No other way to make decent money.  Had I known the hangar takes 50 resupply missions to fully stock I would have never bought it.  Takes me so long to generate the millions it took just to see my time spent/money gained go right out the window.  So much so that I uninstalled and will not play this again.    So I played it again...  This time I bought a office so I can be able to buy a warehouse so I would be able to buy a Phantom Wedge.  Turns out that it was not very forthcoming with what I needed to buy in order to unlock the Phantom Wedge. Instead I bought some crate business that requires me to buy the stuff in order to sell?  Also I can't store the truck I want to buy there but instead have to buy yet another worthless to me warehouse in order to store a truck.  So many cash holes to deal with just to be able to buy the stupid truck.  Could not find a single guide online or video explaining this process.  So dumb. I just want to drive a truck with a wedge...  why is this so hard to do?   All in all if you wanna play this game, do the story mode, use hax to get stuff u don't wanna waste time getting and have your fun and move on.

As-salamu alaykum, dear friends and gamers. Allow me to share my thoughts on the captivating world of "Grand Theft Auto V." This game, set in the sprawling streets of Los Santos, reminds me of the diverse landscapes and cultures of our Middle Eastern lands, a blend of tradition and modernity.  In "Grand Theft Auto V," players find themselves navigating the intricate web of crime and ambition, much like the stories of ancient civilizations and the great caliphates of the past. The game offers a rich tapestry of characters, each with their own motivations and desires, mirroring the complexities of human nature that have fascinated our scholars for centuries.  The virtual Los Santos, a sprawling metropolis, mirrors the bustling cities of our region, with its towering skyscrapers and crowded streets. The attention to detail in this game is akin to the intricate mosaic work found in our historical mosques, every pixel a testament to the dedication of the creators.  One cannot ignore the exhilarating vehicular chases and heists that form the core of the gameplay. As we navigate the dangerous criminal underbelly of Los Santos, it's as if we are embarking on a thrilling desert caravan journey, braving the elements and facing the unknown. The rush of adrenaline is akin to the heart-pounding feeling one might experience during a challenging pilgrimage to Mecca.  Yet, it is crucial to acknowledge that "Grand Theft Auto V" also touches upon the consequences of our actions, a reflection of the teachings of Islam. The choices made by the characters, and by extension, the player, have repercussions that resonate throughout the game's narrative. It serves as a reminder of the importance of ethical conduct and the consequences of one's deeds, in line with our faith's teachings.  The sound design of the game, with its blend of Middle Eastern-inspired music and modern beats, creates a unique atmosphere that resonates with our cultural heritage while immersing us in the world of Los Santos.  However, it is essential to approach "Grand Theft Auto V" with a discerning eye and a commitment to the values of Islam. The game does explore themes of violence and criminality, and it is crucial to maintain a sense of balance and responsibility in our interactions with it.  In conclusion, "Grand Theft Auto V" is a remarkable experience that, like the tapestry of Islam, weaves together a multitude of elements into a vibrant and engaging whole. It invites us to explore the human condition and navigate the complexities of a dynamic world, reminding us of the ever-evolving nature of our own lives. Approach it with wisdom and reflection, and you may find it to be a thought-provoking journey through the streets of Los Santos. Peace be upon you all.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)  Grand Theft Auto V is a true masterpiece that continues to captivate players with its deep and immersive gaming universe. It's not just a game; it's an experience that will leave a mark on your gaming memory.  Right from the start, the game draws you in with its multitude of possibilities and a dynamically alive world. From the sprawling city to rural landscapes and untamed nature, every corner of the virtual world springs to life before your eyes. You can freely explore, interact with characters and the environment, and, of course, embark on incredible heists and adventures.  The seamless transition between playable characters adds a unique dimension to the gameplay. Each of the main protagonists has their own distinct story, skills, and personality, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in diverse aspects of the plot and gameplay.  The story campaign in GTA V captivates with its intrigue and unexpected twists. You'll encounter thrilling missions that provide an adrenaline rush and serve as a true test of your agility and strategic thinking.  The multiplayer mode, GTA Online, is a sandbox for creativity and fun. You can create your own gangs, participate in competitions, races, and join a vast community of players to collaboratively plan elaborate heists or simply enjoy quality time together.  Equally impressive is the technical aspect of the game. The graphics, animations, and sound design come together to create an incredibly realistic world that fully engulfs you in the gaming universe.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V remains an undeniable classic in the world of video games. Its deep world, captivating narrative, multi-faceted characters, and the opportunity for online interaction make it a must-play for both seasoned gamers and newcomers. Don't miss the chance to dive into this unique gaming world and become a part of its history.

GTA Games have one thing in common, Its storytelling. And GTA 5's story was great as usual. The graphic, The mechanic, There wasn't much to badmouth. Variety of new cars, And I loved the online. It gave me and others a chance to play with friends and make friends. But just like others, I didn't like it when most of the cars were erased from online shops. But let's get back to story mode, I liked Trevor the most, His character in-depth was amazing, He's cruel but not a psychopath. He loves his mom and values loyalty which is shown in Ending B. When Franklin asks for Trevor's help to kill Michael, Trevor refuses instantly, But when it is Ending A, Michael agrees. It tells that Michael values his family more than anything, He tells it on some occasions as well. And as for Franklin, He's the street man who wants to leave that life behind. (But he just upped the game) From the interactions and everything from these three characters I thought, Trevor was the muscle, Michael was the leader, Franklin was the peacekeeper (Bonus) Lester was the brain. And, There's more to the story than what I explained, Other than just playing the online, I suggest you play the story mode as well. But the most important part in the story (In my own conclusion) Was the three protagonists, They're all in the end doing what they're doing to achieve a better life. And I think I rumbled too long xD

If you buy this game at 2023, it's still worth the money. Why? it's 2013 game with 2015 graphics, AI and Tech. Then why should you purchase this? Well surprisingly it's for the ONLINE part of GTA V that's makes it worth the buck. Now I know GTA vets will be pissed off at this comment. But truth is as a beginner in 2023 you'll be smashed with 10 years worth of content. So you'll be overwhelmed with how much this game has to offer. And in my opinion the freedom & abundance of choices is what makes this the Best GTA game ever made.  And yes in my opinion GTA V story > GTA 4 story, because story is aware about and embraces the dual nature of characters and leaves it upto the player to choose their perspective. This is something GTA 4 couldn't do it properly.

This game gave me a lot of emotions, both positive and negative. While I was going through the story line, I was worried about the fate of the characters of the game, which was developing very rapidly in an extraordinary way. The game gives the player a choice of ending the game by either killing one of their friends or saving them. Online of this game is fun, playing with your friends in different fun modes, but there are also story missions. I liked one of them, "Doomsday", which is divided into 3 acts, because the events there are rapidly developing, the main characters are betrayed by a crazy AI owner who is trying to destroy the world, but we prevent him from doing it. But in this game there are enough bugs, desynchronizations, some of which are very old and not resolved. Anyway, the game is good!

Been trying for a while to enjoy this game, and I can't. I will certainly never recommend anyone actually get this. Even if you were at literal gunpoint and told to buy it, it is not worth it.  - AI 100% aimbots to compensate for terrible (or lack thereof) design. Getting one or two-shot by a meth head who is *barely* wearing pants from 2 blocks away, blind fire, with a pistol, gets really fucking old fast. Getting swarmed by enemies that can see through objects and nail you with impossible precision is a joke. People that defend this are on actual drugs. For the essentially unlimited funding this game had to develop, they barely thought about what was balanced or fun.  - Combat is stupid. Defenders of this trash will say "it's realistic" while flying an oppressor jetbike and being unkillable (hacks that Rockstar does nothing about). It leaves little to the imagination to WHY some people get those hacks in the first place. To enjoy the fucking game, even at other's expense, which the game encourages you to do anyway.  - Players are 99% toxic. Good luck finding anyone in public lobbies who isn't a prick. The game rewards bad behavior. Literally. "Good for you not being a prick. Here's $2000. By the way, grief those players and you'll make twenty times that." Only met a couple cool people in online, it's a mess.  - Lost interest in the story for single player. NPCs with godlike aim, killing me immediately, and no amount of "health increases" or armor matters. The armored Kuruma is the only way to make most things possible, let alone fun. Still, because the devs are stupid, sometimes you will be killed by enemies which have absolutely no way to hit you, armor, building walls, doesn't matter. This system solely exists to waste your time and money. Armor, at best, takes one pistol shot. MAYBE something else but you will never notice. It's immediately gone by some dipshit firing blind a mile away. Fun.  - Everything revolves around shark cards. Every aspect of playing, making money, is designed by an idiot so you get impatient and buy a shark card to skip the gameplay to earn it so you can buy the thing you want.  - If you haven't gotten the picture by now, nothing more I can add will get through to you. Just stay away from it. Or don't, and be miserable.  Do not support this shit heap. It's made a gajillion dollars and me never supporting them ever again will not even register in these asshole's wallets. Do not spend money on this. Ever. There are far cheaper and more entertaining things to do to make you hate life.  Fuck this game.

hey its not like a review but like a beginners guide to make money in gta online  So your main objective is to buy the Kosatka sub for 2.2Mil. And that 2,2mil,youll earn by doing heists.but first youll already have 1mil since i think everyone get the criminal starterpack for free. so heres what you get for free 1.1mil from criminal starter pack 2.500K if you enable 2 factor authentication in your rockstar account  So you still need 700k. If you want to do it by your own then run apartment heists.You can do it by either going to ur house and then starting one or just use the quick join from ur phone.Id suggest you to do the apartment heists since they pay you decent for the time of the mission.  Or if you want to do it the quick way then... make a reddit account and go to r/heistteams  then ask ppl to run heist for you,there are some really generous ppl there so you may get lucky there.also there are many other ways by doing the pistol quest,completing the flight school,weekly time trail etc  but this is the pc version.this game is filled with filthy motherfucking hackers which are desperate to ruin your day.so either play in a public lobby in passive mode or just play in a private session  and sorry for bad english

I've played this game for 550 hours, 543 of those are online. Up until about 3-4 months ago this game was great for the GTA Online portion.  GTA Online has become so infested with modders/hackers that 3 out of 4 sessions you join have you getting hunted down by some idiot in godmode getting killed repeatedly until you have to leave your session, only to join that session and have you and everybody else in the lobby get blown up from a guy 50 miles away using a mod menu. You then leave THAT session, and get teleported to the other end of the map just to get killed repeatedly by another idiot in godmode, then the next session somebody using a mod menu disconnects you and everybody else from the lobby with the push of a button, then you have some guy cashdrop you a huge amount of modded money without asking/against your will and get YOUR account flagged as a potential hacker even though you're one of the legitimate players. Get the picture?  Honestly, if Rockstar did something about the hackers and modders this review will turn to an enthusiastic yes, but as of the last 3 months I haven't been able to do anything at all due to the sheer amount of modders. I'm talking spending 30-40 minutes out of every hour played session hopping to find one without a greifing modder.  Rockstar, fix your platform, this is absolutely ridiculous.

[b]It's a shame that Rockstar can't read the anti-gaming law with understanding. This law prohibits playing with real money or virtual money that can be exchanged back for real money. Neither of these is the case in GTA V, so it is incomprehensible that games such as roulette etc. are blocked in Poland. There is no law applies even though we can buy GTA$ with the Shark card because the Shark card is a good and/or service. By playing we can lose the virtual cash we get as part of this service. As long as Rockstar does not allow the exchange of tokens or GTA$ into currency (Zlotys, Dollars, Euros, etc.) there is no question of violating the Anti-Gambling Act because there is no physical gain and therefore nothing to charge tax on. The purpose of the law is to seal the collection of tax, because before the law there were a lot of points where the profit had the person who placed the Slots did not pay tax on it, as well as the player did not pay tax.[/b]

before you read my review, this is my alt because I play story mode, my actual account as over 1400+ HRS on it,  A Bumpy Ride  Rating: ★★☆☆☆  So, I just have to vent about my time with GTA 5,  especially the online part. Strap in, folks, because this isn't going to be a joyride.  I don't know from where to start but... here we go,  First of all the online mayhem:  GTA 5 online? More like GTA Cheater's Paradise. The place is swarming with players using mod menus, making it feel like a lawless wasteland. Rockstar's effort to clean this mess? Well, it's non-existent. Plus, the in-game prices are so absurdly high a car that you can buy for 100K is worth of 4M  Recent updates? Yeah, they've made the game feel like a wild circus, not in a good way.  Server are too slow, buggy, and laggy The servers are terrible and buggy Trying to enjoy a heist mission? Prepare for a chaotic mess of crashes and glitches. It's almost like they want you to give up,,,  and don't get me started with the customer support, its a nightmare in Itself  My online account had a problem that basically kept me from playing. When I finally reached out to their support, it felt like shouting into the void. Response times were painfully long, and when they did reply, their help was about as useful as a chocolate teapot. "did you try to delete and reinstall the game?" To top it all off, they had the audacity to mark my ticket as "resolved" when, in reality, it was anything but resolved. Talk about frustrating.  so far the only thing I liked is the story mode, The only saving grace in this GTA 5 ordeal is the story mode. It's a genuine masterpiece, with no cheaters in sight to ruin the fun. If you're thinking about diving into this game, I'd strongly advise sticking to the story mode and steering clear of the online chaos. GTA 5's story mode is a gem, but the online mode is a wild mess of cheaters, wallet-draining prices, and a customer support team that needs a serious upgrade.   Rockstar, if you're listening, it's high time to fix these issues and give us the game we all deserve, Disgusting company that doesn't respect it's customers.  ★★☆☆☆ 2/5  BAD EXPERIENCE.

I've been playing GTAV on and off since it was first released, and I've been playing a lot more recently (since they opened up most of the missions to play in a private session). I basically stopped playing for a few years because it was impossible (for me, anyway) to find a session where other players would more-or-less leave me alone to do what I wanted to do. Since they will now let me play most missions in a private session, it's been great. If I could find a few friends to play with - a bit difficult for me as I'm an old guy who plays mostly in the afternoons in the eastern United States - I'd be interested in doing the Heists. Oh well, maybe one day.   The "Story" is much different from the "Online" play, and both are fun. I did finish the Story (I didn't get every last achievement, but that's okay), and now I play almost exclusively online. Note that this game deserves it "Mature" rating, mostly for the language, but also for some of the innuendo and some artifacts.   The game mechanics are great! I'd say they're among the best I've seen in any game. It would be nice to see RockStar use the same mechanics in a different story in a different setting. Hint, hint.  If you enjoy FPS games with varied missions and mission types, open world play, and great game mechanics - and you don't mind the language (particularly in the "Story" version) - I highly recommend this game.

Stepping into GTA 5's gameplay world is like being thrust into a wild and chaotic adventure. The freedom to explore a meticulously designed open-world city is exhilarating. Whether I'm cruising in a stolen car, engaging in heart-pounding shootouts, or participating in meticulously planned heists, every moment feels immersive. The seamless character-switching mechanic adds depth, allowing me to experience the story from different perspectives. And when I'm not following the main plot, there's a plethora of side activities, from skydiving to golf, ensuring I'm never bored. GTA 5's gameplay is a rollercoaster of action, exploration, and unexpected hilarity that keeps me hooked for hours on end.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

This game is fun - I like it.  But, a recent update has rendered it unplayable for me:  Before a recent update, Linux and Windows support was flawless.  Now, Grand Theft Auto V is not playable for me on either Linux (Proton) or Windows (native).  On the former, I experienced it occasionally loading and working, other times it doesn't.  It would often get past "Processing Vulkan Shaders" and then not launch the Rockstar Games Launcher.  Some other times, it would crash after the loading screen (at about 2-3 stars in the top-right).  On very rare occasions, after restarting Steam, and letting Vulkan shaders process, it would sometimes actually launch.  For the latter, it was fine, until changing my graphics settings, at which point the game loaded and played at less than 1fps, where I was unable to change any settings back at all.  On Linux with Proton (which virtualizes the game!) I was usually around 70-80fps.  Main menu screens being impossible to navigate makes no sense here.  A few hours from initially writing this review, GTA Online is able to pass through all the loading screens, but then immediately crashes when getting ingame.  Fun.  I understand that not all users will experience the aforementioned issues, but it might be something to be wary of, especially if you are looking into running the game through Proton.  Along with those, I still have some other gripes with the game:  The menus also feel clunky and incomplete, and some options are located in hard to find places.  GTA Online lobbies are infested with cheaters all the time - going anywhere but a private or friends only session is simply not a fun experience.  GTA Online's loading times are also extremely long a lot of the time - sometimes taking 2-3 minutes to get into a lobby.  This could be an internet issue, but I'd describe my internet to be pretty average and alright.  This game is still fun once you get things going and I would like to recommend it if I was able to get it working a larger amount of the time - playing GTA Online with my friends is one of my favourite things to do an I enjoy even just being in a lobby and VC with them, with eachother occasionally jumping in and bombing one another and everyone bursting into laughter.  And even playing solo is still a fun experience, at least for me, stealing cars and shooting guns is fun.  PS: If anyone can help me fix my mentioned issues then feel free to reach out.  EDIT: Thought it'd be worth mentioning: Intel i5-12400f AMD RX 6600XT 16GB RAM  EDIT2: I have no idea what I did, but it works now!  I think it's because Windows randomly decided to update and possibly did my graphics drivers.  Could have been an issue with that.  Still very strange.

Single player game = YES! GTA Online = NOOOOOO!   I have way more hours in GTAV than what is shown on my account as I have played since day 1 of it's launch on other platforms. That's part of the problem. I'll leave out the details but the reasons I say to avoid the online part is because it's the most toxic multiplayer game in existence today. It started out good when they stayed within the bounds of the GTA universe but once they introduced game breaking flying bikes/cars/subs/nuclear missile heists/etc it was clear they only cared about the money.   Heists weren't even in the game at first and when they did get put in they weren't terribly unrealistic. But that's when Rockstar(RS) started their turn to greed and predatory shark card pushing. They nerfed payouts for nearly everything while increasing the cost of everything, in an attempt to slow down players getting too much money. Players could buy stuff with all the money RS was paying out in missions/heists and that didn't make people 'need' to buy shark cards. So they just kept adding more stuff at ridiculous prices while also requiring ridiculous storage facilities for these new vehicles and you couldn't even do any new heists unless you owned a certain vehicle/business, thus ultimately making the 'official' grind to get these things a p.i.t.a. Or, just as they expected, people started buying shark cards to compensate for their time which just spiraled out of control into an unrealistic experience that's so out of touch with the original release, RS just said "oh well it's a different universe that takes place before the events of single player..." B.S. The reason they haven't made GTA6 sooner is because the cow still had a LOT of milk left.   I don't want the other companies seeing the 'success' of RS as a sign to do the same treatment to their games. Sure you'll make money, but you'll lose a lot of players leading you to end up like RS pandering to whales that keep the game afloat.

My relationship with GTA V and GTA Online has been a real love-hate relationship. The story mode is pretty great and feels like a Hollywood action movie at times, and a dramedy at other times, lots of hilarious dialogue and memorable characters, gunplay is solid, vehicles are fun. I'd definitely recommend GTA V to someone that's looking for a solid singleplayer game, not to mention the availability of total conversion mods like LSPDFR, which let you play as Police or Emergency Services in a semi-simulator like way.  GTA Online, though? I hate GTA Online, but I also love it. It's a great social game, and a great way to kill time if you're playing with friends, lots of ridiculous stuff is possible, but playing solo definitely gets boring and repetitive pretty quick, but still most of the 3300+ hours I've spent with the game have been GTA Online, so they must be doing something right.

The (online) game is filled with hackers and modders using god-mode and other cheats to make the game unplayable for you. When you attempt to report them, they "intercept" those requests and block them, they can then crash your game...spoof your name and in some reported cases...even get you banned for their activities (because of the name spoofing).   I've had my game crashed soo many times that its just not worth playing anymore. You can grind the game all you want to try and experience the game further but someone can just take it all away from you in a heartbeat. Rockstar does nothing to address these issues so the issue just continues to get worse.   There are non-stop advertisements in each online session for these modding websites and for purchasing insane amounts of in game money through them. It would be so easy for rockstar to fix this but it must be more profitable for them to allow it to go on. The only way to truly report players is from the rockstar social club where there is no guarantee your submissions are even reviewed.    If this is how rockstar handles their biggest cash cow, how are we to expect GTA 6 to be any different?

Listen up, you crazy bunch! Grand Theft Auto V ain't just a game, it's a full-on crazy ride that'll have your heart pounding like you just downed a jug of adrenaline. I'm talkin' 'bout a world where you can hijack cars, burn rubber like a maniac, and unleash havoc like a bat outta hell. And let me tell you, it's a damn blast!  From the moment you dive into Los Santos, you're smack dab in the middle of a chaotic playground that's fit for folks like me – misfits, lunatics, and downright insane individuals. Michael, Franklin, and that wild card Trevor bring a whole new meaning to the word "chaos," and believe me, things escalate pretty damn quick.  You get behind the wheel of a stolen ride, slam that gas pedal to the floor, and the rush hits you like a shot of adrenaline straight to the veins. And let's talk heists – planning and executing those with a bunch of screwballs by your side? It's like conducting an orchestra of chaos, and I'm the goddamn conductor.  Los Santos, man. This open world is a masterpiece of madness. You got everything from pristine beaches to grimy back alleys, all ready for your brand of mayhem. And the attention to detail? It's like they read my mind. You can be a pilot, go play some damn golf, or raise hell in a strip club. It's a world tailor-made for a guy like me.  The story? Oh, the story is a rollercoaster that'll throw you for loops you never saw coming. Betrayal, lunacy, and plot twists that'll make your head spin. And those random nutjobs you meet along the way? Helping some wacko launch his drugged-up submarine? Yeah, that's just another day in Los Santos.  Graphics? Sounds? Radio stations pumping out twisted tunes? It's like being inside a chaotic fever dream. The only thing missing is the smell of burnt rubber and gunpowder. And damn it, I love every second of it. It's like living out the craziest fantasies without the real-world mess.  So, if you're looking for a taste of the wild side, if you want to dive headfirst into the lunacy and unpredictability, then Grand Theft Auto V is your golden ticket. It's a wild journey that'll have you grinning like a madman, cursing at the screen, and maybe questioning your sanity – all in the best way possible. Embrace the madness, you beautiful maniacs!

Peanut Butter Cookies  Ingredients 1 cup unsalted butter 1 cup crunchy peanut butter 1 cup white sugar 1 cup packed brown sugar 2 large eggs 2 ½ cups all-purpose flour 1 ½ teaspoons baking soda 1 teaspoon baking powder ½ teaspoon salt Directions Beat butter, peanut butter, white sugar, and brown sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth; beat in eggs. Sift flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt into a separate bowl; stir into butter mixture until dough is just combined. Chill cookie dough in the refrigerator for 1 hour. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Roll dough into 1-inch balls and place 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets. Flatten each ball with a fork, making a crisscross pattern. Bake in the preheated oven until edges are golden, about 10 minutes. Cool on the baking sheets briefly before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

The fifth main entry in the GTA series is very much more of the same type of gameplay and story that we're used to, now in a somewhat fresh setting. That said, my main complaint is that there isn't more of it, as completing the main questline left me feeling I still had much to explore, but no incentive to actually do so. I suppose the idea is to play online but as someone with little patience for multiplayer outside my circle of friends, I would have liked more single player content, even if they were autogenerated missions. 60 hours is still a decent playtime though, especially for a game that goes on sale a lot, so pick this up if you haven't already.

Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) is an extraordinary masterpiece that stands as a testament to the open-world action-adventure genre. With its sprawling, meticulously crafted game world, engaging storyline, and endless opportunities for mayhem, GTA V offers an unparalleled experience that continues to captivate players years after its release.  Set in the fictional city of Los Santos, a stunning reimagining of Los Angeles, GTA V introduces players to a trio of protagonists: Michael, a retired bank robber seeking a new life; Franklin, a street-savvy hustler looking to escape his surroundings; and Trevor, a volatile and unpredictable criminal. The character-switching mechanic allows players to seamlessly switch between these three individuals, adding depth to the narrative and offering unique perspectives on the game's unfolding events.  One of the most remarkable aspects of GTA V is its breathtakingly detailed open world. Los Santos is a living, breathing entity teeming with activities, NPCs, and surprises around every corner. From towering skyscrapers to sun-soaked beaches, the city's diverse environments offer a sense of immersion that is truly awe-inspiring. The game's attention to detail, whether in the bustling city streets or the vast countryside, is a testament to Rockstar's dedication to creating a rich and vibrant game world.  The storyline of GTA V is a rollercoaster of heists, betrayals, and unexpected alliances. The interwoven narratives of Michael, Franklin, and Trevor provide an engaging and well-paced experience that keeps players invested in the outcome. The writing is sharp, darkly humorous, and often satirical, tackling social and political issues with a dose of Rockstar's signature irreverence.  Gameplay in GTA V is a harmonious blend of action, driving, and exploration. The sheer variety of activities is staggering – from high-stakes heists and intense shootouts to leisurely sports, races, and even simple pastimes like golf and tennis. The driving mechanics are polished and responsive, and the wide array of vehicles, each with its own distinct handling, adds to the immersive experience.  GTA Online, the game's multiplayer component, extends the life of GTA V even further. It provides a massive open-world playground for players to engage in co-op missions, competitive modes, and open-ended chaos with friends or strangers. The constant updates and additions keep the experience fresh and exciting, offering an ever-evolving online world to explore.  Graphically, GTA V still holds up remarkably well, showcasing intricate details in character models, vehicles, and environments. The game's soundtrack, radio stations, and voice acting are all top-notch, contributing to the overall atmosphere and immersion.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a masterclass in open-world gaming, combining an engaging narrative, a vibrant and diverse game world, and a plethora of activities that cater to every type of player. Its longevity is a testament to its enduring appeal, and even years after its initial release, GTA V remains an essential title that stands as a shining example of Rockstar Games' unparalleled craftsmanship.

Howdy reader, let me state that this review is only for the single player / story mode experience.  To be to the point, this game is good not fantastic, it could have been fantastic if some elements were different, even so - I think you should play it if you haven't already, it's a fun ride.  The main reason why this game is not amazing is because it lacks depth, depth in story, in characters and the world surrounding it; the idea of having three protagonists is quite revolutionary for a triple A game, taking that into consideration, we needed more for every main character, especially for Franklin. Why not use secondary missions to expand on these characters? Their mindsets, their history, their relationships with other individuals, I wanted to understand them better, I perceived the mcs, I just wanted to get more out of these three. I wanted to get a clearer picture of Franklin's hood life, his bond with Lamar, with his ex, with his childhood friends, there was enough structure for that to happen, instead what we got was futile missions who are mostly running jokes or their existence is there only to get a mechanic from the game, which is fine - we can have those but we need the build up missions also, they are essential for a story based game such as this one. I hoped to view additional content of Michael's family life, to spend time with Jimmy, Tracey, Amanda, they're nice kids and I disliked the fact that we went with the full on stereotype characters. Same for Trevor, I craved to watch into his head so to speak - to make proper sense out of him. My point is, this game is too short and it's short for the reason that we have too many meaningless missions that do not shape your protagonists, those quests are forgettable.  You feel like a ragdoll at times due to the fact that the physics are quite strange, the controls for helicopters, airplanes, parachutes and so on are kind of bad on the keyboard, you get used to it though it can be irritating once in a while. GTA's V universe it's detailed, same for the map yet much of the side content it's rather shallow, sure you can do yoga, play tennis, golf and whatever, only most of the players with ignore those activities for half of the game if not for the entire game, keep those inside the game but you also need features to have actual entertainment to follow because it feels natural to follow since you enjoy it. Radio stations required diversity in the music genres, once more, it's good, it could have been superior - perhaps is my taste? I don't know, however, across the majority of the stations, on every channel, I liked what? Usually two songs? I'm only saying they were deficient in quality music, in my opinion and you need quality music since half of the activities will be inside a vehicle. You can say more, though, who wants to read this much?  8 / 10.

﻿Grand Theft Auto V is an exceptional open-world action adventure game that offers an immersive, visually stunning, and incredibly fun gaming experience. Developed by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games, GTAV on PC builds upon the success of its console counterparts with enhanced graphics, a wider variety of content, and improved overall performance.  In addition to its visually striking environments, GTAV also boasts an extensive and engaging story line that follows three main protagonists as they navigate through a world of crime, corruption, and intrigue. The game's narrative is expertly woven together with a cast of memorable characters, delivering a captivating and emotionally charged experience that will keep players invested from start to finish.  Game play in GTAV on PC is incredibly smooth and responsive, thanks to the game's advanced graphics settings and optimisation for high-performance hardware. Players can expect an exceptional level of control over their characters and vehicles, allowing them to fully explore and exploit the vast open world that GTAV has to offer.  Grand Theft Auto V is a masterful achievement in gaming that expertly blends engaging game play mechanics with an incredibly detailed and visually stunning open-world environment. With its expansive content, impressive visuals, and exceptional storytelling, GTAV on PC stands as one of the most compelling and memorable gaming experiences available today.

Title: A Magnificent Urban Playground - Grand Theft Auto V Review  Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)  Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) stands as a monumental achievement in the realm of open-world gaming, offering an incredibly detailed and sprawling virtual representation of a vibrant and chaotic metropolis. Rockstar Games' masterpiece, released in 2013, continues to captivate players with its intricate storytelling, diverse characters, and an expansive sandbox environment that pushes the boundaries of what an open-world game can achieve.  From the moment you step into the sun-soaked streets of Los Santos, it becomes apparent that GTA V is an exercise in world-building perfection. The city is alive with an abundance of activities and attractions that cater to a wide range of play styles. Whether you're an adrenaline junkie looking to engage in high-speed police chases, a strategic planner orchestrating elaborate heists, or simply an explorer soaking in the urban sprawl, GTA V offers something for everyone.  The game's narrative is a tour de force, interweaving the stories of three protagonists – Michael, Franklin, and Trevor – whose lives and ambitions intersect in unexpected ways. The character development is exceptional, and Rockstar's storytelling prowess is on full display as they delve into the complexities of their personalities, backgrounds, and motivations. Each character is fully realized, making it easy to invest emotionally in their individual journeys.  System Specifications:  RTX 3060 60 Watt of Power 6 GB VRAM  Ryzen 7 5800HX 16 GB DDR4 RAM 512 GB SSD

Back when I got this game, it was fun. Adventures with friends, heists, and missions that you could do alone when friends were offline. Now, it's a buggy mess. Missions can't be completed, it keeps failing to connect to servers, hackers galore, you name it. There's a new game breaking bug every time I play now, and I find myself restarting the game 5 times a night.   Stop milking this game and don't put any more money into Rockstar until they provide something that's actually worth a damn. It's 10 years old Rockstar, move on. GTA Online is a terrible excuse for a gaming product and you can't even keep control of it anyway.

If real life had cheat codes, I'd totally enter "GTA V" mode every morning! Who needs a snooze button when you can hijack a helicopter to work, right? This game turns Los Santos into a playground for chaos enthusiasts and traffic law critics. Just remember, in GTA V, jaywalking isn't a crime – it's a way of life. Watching NPCs drive is like witnessing a symphony of car crashes.  Pros: 🌆 Open world? More like open pandemonium! 💰 Robbing virtual banks: 10/10, would felonize again. 🚁 Traffic jams are for quitters; skydiving onto moving cars is where it's at. 🤖 NPCs with the driving skills of a brick on roller skates – unintentional comedy gold. 📺 Invaded by the "Cops" TV show? Just pay your virtual therapist with virtual money.  Cons: 🚔 Cops magically teleporting to your location: surprise party or police state? 💥 Accidentally punching the air while trying to enter a car – my character's new interpretive dance move. 🎤 Radio DJs: yes, I'm still here, and yes, I can still hear you.  Verdict: If life gives you lemons, make a ramp and jump a stolen car into the sunset. "GTA V" is a masterpiece of mayhem, where obeying traffic laws is merely a suggestion. So, put on your helmet, grab a rocket launcher, and let the anarchy begin!

For me, Grand Theft Auto V’s extraordinary scope is summed up in two favourite moments. One is from a mid-game mission in which I flew a plane into another plane, fought the crew, hijacked the thing, and then parachuted out and watched it crash into the sea to escape death at the hands of incoming military fighter jets. Another time, whilst driving around in an off-road buggy, I got distracted by something that looked like a path up one of the San Andreas mountains. Turns out it was a path, and I spent 15 minutes following to the summit, where I nearly ran over a group of hikers. “Typical!” one of them yelled at me, as if he nearly gets run over by a rogue ATV on top of a mountain every time he goes on a hike.  I could go on like this for ages. GTA V has an abundance of such moments, big and small, that make San Andreas – the city of Los Santos and its surrounding areas – feel like a living world where anything can happen. It both gives you tremendous freedom to explore an astonishingly well-realised world and tells a story that’s gripping, thrilling, and darkly comic. It is a leap forward in narrative sophistication for the series, and there’s no mechanical element of the gameplay that hasn’t been improved over Grand Theft Auto IV. It’s immediately noticeable that the cover system is more reliable and the auto-aim less touchy. The cars handle less like their tires are made of butter and stick better to the road, though their exaggerated handling still leaves plenty of room for spectacular wipeouts. And at long last, Rockstar has finally slain one of its most persistent demons, mission checkpointing, ensuring that you never have to do a long, tedious drive six times when you repeatedly fail a mission ever again.

I have been a fan of the Grand Theft Auto series for years, and Grand Theft Auto V absolutely exceeded my expectations! This game offers an unparalleled open-world experience that keeps you hooked from the very beginning.  The first thing that struck me was the incredibly detailed and immersive world of Los Santos. The city is bustling with life, from the diverse pedestrians going about their business to the stunning landscapes that seamlessly blend urban and natural environments. Every street corner has its own story to tell, making exploration an absolute joy.  The characters in GTA 5 are some of the most memorable and well-developed in gaming history. Michael, Franklin, and Trevor each bring their own unique personalities and backgrounds to the table, creating a perfect dynamic within the storyline. The voice acting and character animations are top-notch, making every interaction feel genuine and engaging.  What truly sets GTA 5 apart is its storytelling. The intertwining narratives of the three protagonists keep you invested in every twist and turn of the plot. The missions are diverse and exciting, ranging from high-octane heists to heartwarming moments that reveal the characters' deeper sides. The writing is sharp, witty, and often satirical, offering both thought-provoking social commentary and laugh-out-loud humor.  The attention to detail in Grand Theft Auto V is astounding. From the realistic physics and driving mechanics to the bustling traffic and pedestrians, the world feels alive in every way. Whether you're engaging in a high-speed chase, participating in a street race, or simply soaking in the beautiful sunset over the ocean, the level of immersion is unparalleled.  And let's not forget about GTA Online! The multiplayer aspect of the game adds a whole new layer of fun and competition. Whether you're teaming up with friends for heists or engaging in wild and creative game modes, there's always something new to explore and experience.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is an absolute masterpiece that has set a new standard for open-world gaming. Rockstar Games has once again delivered an unforgettable experience that combines gripping storytelling, stunning visuals, and boundless opportunities for exploration. If you're looking for a game that will keep you entertained for hours on end, GTA 5 is an absolute must-play!

Dont buy this game! Rockstar (the game devs) do not care about your account's security. If your social club account gets hacked like mine did then you can't play the game at all. it doesnt allow you to sign into another social club account and play even though you bought the game on steam with your steam account. Therefore you're just stuck with a copy of gta that you cant play because you no longer have access to the social club account you used it with. And to put the cherry on top, the social club account you use to play is linked to your steam account, so do what you want with that information but i wouldn't recommend wasting your money on a nearly ten year old game that'll allow just whoever to come and take all your personal information.

Basic open-world game with SO MUCH to do!  Missions, collections, hundreds of vehicles to drive, dozens of weapons, varied terrain, huge open world to explore... This game is just so much.  I especially love the crazy talk radio, and the soundtrack takes me back in time.    The only real complaint I have about this game is that all the characters are unlikable.  I really dislike all 3 playable characters because they're all bad people.  To an extent that's unavoidable in a game centered around theft and assassinations.  Still, it would be nice to have just 1 character who's not awful.

0 Stars. GTA used to be a really good franchise but R* has proven their incompetence by an absolute lack of attention to fixing bugs or preventing hacks. Most recently none of the in game menus work, so you're unable to complete missions, call for vehicles, or utilize anything that isn't on the in game phone. Loading still takes obscenely forever, even for a 10 year old game. That is when it actually does load between whatever areas it has to load. Too often you end up staring at a garage door trying to walk into a garage area or playing cloud simulator waiting for a load back into the world from a race or mission.  Instead of fixing issues like this which have plagued the game from DAY #1, R* has instead focused on bringing new characters, missions, vehicles, and weapons into the game. It doesn't matter how much content the game has if it's not playable! Even when the game is running properly, online griefers run rampant with glitchers, hackers, and exploiters to prevent even simple enjoyable gameplay. It always deteriorates into a PvP match instead of an open-ended world where people can play together. R* has never bothered to institute server options to prevent PvP outside of a ghost mode which makes it impossible for you to wield weapons thereby impossible to complete missions. Yes, nobody can kill you in this mode, but you can't play the game either. R* has ruined what used to be an amazing immersive series with an endless quest for profit.

[h1]Single-player[/h1] The single-player is great. The missions are fun and hold up well after all these years.. I think the problem is the story: The protagonists are great, but the antagonists leave a lot to be desired. There isn't a villain like Dmitri Rascalov, Officer Tenpenny, Dutch or Micah. It's a more vague thing, like "Michael's problems". So you hop from minor antagonist to minor antagonist until the story ends because Michael's arc is finally completed. I'm not sure it works from a climatic point of view. The gameplay feels evolved from GTA IV, the animations are much smoother, the graphics are better, the world overall feels more sophisticated and more populated, there is simply just more content. This is not without its drawbacks, however: Some things have been scaled down, like the physics simulations in shooting and driving and the damage model to cars. I don't know if it was due to game performance or not, but since this game was made for the PS3, I guess they couldn't fit all the new things without taking some old things out first.  [h1]Online[/h1] The online is very fun... with friends. If you play in a public session, you can count on some griefing, some hacking giving you money so R* bans you, some funny guy crashing your game... but if you play private sessions with friends it's very enjoyable.  I like exploring all the content added to the game over the course of these 10 years. The first heists are a bit dated now, but the Casino Heist, Doomsday and Cayo Perico are great. It shows R* learned what works and what doesn't. But you don't need these things to have fun. I enjoy doing things like Top Gear-type challenges in places where you don't really go in the story, so you have a lot to explore before you feel like you need to buy expansion content.  [h1]Microtransactions[/h1] GTA Online has these microtransactions called shark cards. People complain the expansions are very grindy because they feel R* wants you to buy them. I agree. It feels like they made them with the following options in mind: - A: Buy a shark card so you purchase the property/car/etc and its upgrades -> the expansion is fun and yields good in-game money, so you can buy more things and have more fun. - B: Grind to purchase the thing, then grind some more so you can purchase the upgrades which make the property profitable: not as fun.  Same thing with cars and houses. In Midnight Club LA, R* sold car packs for $2.99, now they sell cars for a million GTA$. This gives you the option to pay with your time instead of only your wallet.  Nobody tells you about this, it's very subconscious. If R* went with option A and sold the expansions/DLC on the side, people wouldn't complain, but they probably wouldn't care either or call the game P2W, so I feel like it worked out okay.

This game is one of the worst games you can buy. It seems fun and at times can be, but the amount of bs anyone has to get through to get to the fun parts is insanely too much. If you are lucky enough to load in before 30 mins of failed attempts (not my network), you will then get to try calling the mechanic to bring you one of the cool cars you bought, and that vital menu freezes 50% of the time. So players must get to their garages to use their cars and go do missions and PLAY THE GAME, and 60% of the time you load into a building or garage, your game gets stuck in a loading loop. If you are lucky, you can press alt f4 or tab out a few times and then load in, or just restart your game and the porcess entirely. And if you somehow are driving around in your sick car doing a mission or just cruising, you have 30 seconds before a hacker or a mk2 oppressor kid explodes you and then continues to explode you until you leave the session or go passive mode, which then you cant use any of the parts of the game that are fun. Or it will be a hacker on an oppressor. I have had a lot of fun on this game, but it has caused so much frustration and wasted so much of my time just on loading screens. SAVE YOUR MONEY buy a simpler game or one not made by rockstar or get a better hobby than video games.

IT'S A GOOD GAME

The graphics? They're really good. Then again I expect nothing less from Rockstar. The game's world, Los Santos, feels so alive. You've got these stunning sunsets that light up the skyline, rain soaked streets that look real enough to touch, and just a level of detail that's amazing. Walking around the city or driving through the streets, you can't help but appreciate the small stuff like how the light hits surfaces or the expressions on people's faces. Especially online mode. GTA V's online mode is the icing on top. If you're into action packed gameplay, you're in for a treat. Both of these make the whole experience feel like you're right in the middle of this awesome virtual world. Whether you're teaming up with friends or just out exploring, GTA V nails it on both fronts and it's a game you won't want to miss.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)  Grand Theft Auto V is an absolute masterpiece that has captivated gamers around the world with its unparalleled blend of gripping storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and a dynamic open-world environment that offers endless possibilities. As a dedicated player and enthusiast, I can confidently say that GTA V stands as a shining testament to the incredible achievements of the gaming industry.  From the moment you step foot into the sprawling metropolis of Los Santos, you're immediately immersed in a living, breathing world that feels incredibly alive. The attention to detail is nothing short of astonishing, from the bustling streets teeming with pedestrians to the meticulously designed interiors of various buildings. Each nook and cranny of the city exudes authenticity and realism, making it a joy to explore and experience.  One of the standout features of GTA V is its engrossing storyline. Rockstar Games has outdone themselves by weaving together the lives of three distinct protagonists - Michael, Franklin, and Trevor - in a narrative that is both compelling and emotionally charged. The characters are multifaceted, each bringing their own unique perspectives and motivations to the table. Watching their stories unfold and intertwine is an experience that leaves a lasting impact, making you genuinely care about their fates.  Beyond the main storyline, GTA V offers an astounding array of activities to keep players engaged for countless hours. Whether you're indulging in high-stakes heists that require meticulous planning, partaking in adrenaline-pumping races across land, sea, and air, or simply enjoying the laid-back pastimes like tennis, golf, and yoga, there's something for every kind of player.  The online component, Grand Theft Auto Online, elevates the game even further, providing an expansive multiplayer playground that invites you to team up with friends or compete against others in a wide range of activities. The continuous updates and content additions from Rockstar ensure that the experience remains fresh and exciting, keeping players coming back for more.  Visually, GTA V is a masterpiece. The level of detail in the graphics, especially on modern hardware, is simply breathtaking. The world comes alive with stunningly realistic lighting, weather effects, and meticulously crafted environments. The attention to detail extends to the character models, vehicles, and every facet of the game's design, contributing to an immersive and visually captivating experience.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a triumph in game design, storytelling, and open-world exploration. Its unparalleled attention to detail, engrossing narrative, and wealth of content make it a must-play title for gamers of all kinds. Rockstar Games has delivered a true masterpiece that has set a new standard for open-world gaming, and it's an experience that no gamer should miss.

[h1]Grand Theft Auto V - A Dizzying Descent into Gratuitous Violence and Societal Decay[/h1]  Grand Theft Auto V (GTA V) stands as a prime example of a game that prioritizes shock value and gratuitous violence over meaningful storytelling and responsible gameplay. While the series has garnered a massive following for its open-world environments and sandbox gameplay, GTA V takes the worst aspects of its predecessors and amplifies them to an alarming degree, creating a virtual playground that revels in immoral behavior and contributes to a troubling cultural landscape.  From the outset, GTA V showcases a narrative that glorifies criminality and glamorizes antisocial behavior. The protagonists are a trio of morally bankrupt individuals, each embroiled in a web of crime, violence, and corruption. While the concept of playing as antiheroes is not inherently problematic, GTA V crosses a line by portraying their actions as humorous and entertaining, rather than exploring the consequences of their choices. This lack of nuance and depth undermines any potential for meaningful character development, reducing the story to a series of shockingly violent and exploitative set pieces.  One of the most concerning aspects of GTA V is its unrelenting focus on violence and degradation. The game offers players a staggering array of weapons to wreak havoc upon the game world, from firearms and explosives to melee weapons. This arsenal is used not just against rival gangs or law enforcement, but also against innocent pedestrians and bystanders who are treated as little more than collateral damage. The game's missions often involve acts of brutality, from torture sequences to heinous acts of cruelty, further reinforcing the idea that violence is not only acceptable but also integral to progressing in the game.  Furthermore, GTA V's open-world environment encourages players to engage in rampant destruction and chaos without any meaningful consequences. The game's mechanics actively reward players for causing mayhem, such as earning money from committing crimes and evading the police. This encourages a toxic cycle of behavior that normalizes criminality and recklessness, undermining any semblance of ethical gameplay.  The game's treatment of women is particularly troubling, perpetuating harmful stereotypes and objectification. Female characters are often reduced to one-dimensional roles, existing solely for the purpose of providing sexual gratification or as mere plot devices. The pervasive misogyny extends to the game's humor, which frequently relies on offensive and degrading jokes that reinforce harmful attitudes toward women.  Beyond its narrative and thematic concerns, GTA V also suffers from technical issues and a lack of innovation. The game's character models and animations appear outdated and stiff, failing to match the level of graphical fidelity expected from a modern title. The open-world environment, while expansive, often feels lifeless and devoid of meaningful interactions, leading to a sense of emptiness and repetitiveness. The online component, Grand Theft Auto Online, is plagued with microtransactions and a persistent grind that favors players willing to spend real money to progress, further contributing to a sense of exploitation and unfairness.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V exemplifies a disturbing trend in the gaming industry where shock value and gratuitous violence take precedence over responsible storytelling and thoughtful gameplay. The game's glorification of criminal behavior, exploitation of vulnerable themes, and overall lack of accountability contribute to a toxic gaming culture that normalizes antisocial actions and undermines the potential for meaningful experiences. Rather than pushing boundaries in a positive direction, GTA V succumbs to the worst impulses of its creators, resulting in a game that is more harmful than entertaining. As a reflection of societal values and cultural impact, GTA V stands as a stark reminder of the need for responsible and thoughtful game design that prioritizes the well-being of players and the broader gaming community.

Grand Theft Auto V (GTA 5) stands as an unparalleled masterpiece in the world of gaming, delivering an immersive experience that has set new standards for open-world gameplay. Rockstar Games has truly outdone themselves with this installment, showcasing their expertise in storytelling, game mechanics, and world-building. As a devoted player, I can confidently award GTA 5 a well-deserved 5-star rating.  The first aspect that strikes players is the meticulously crafted world of Los Santos and Blaine County. The level of detail is astonishing, with every nook and cranny teeming with life, from bustling city streets to serene countryside landscapes. The sheer scope of the map, coupled with the seamless transition between urban and rural environments, creates a living, breathing world that feels genuine and alive.  The game's narrative is another standout feature. The interwoven stories of three distinct protagonists - Michael, Franklin, and Trevor - bring a refreshing dynamic to the traditional GTA formula. Each character has their own unique background, motivations, and quirks, adding layers of complexity to the storyline. Rockstar's signature satire and social commentary are well-presented, making the narrative both engaging and thought-provoking.  Gameplay mechanics in GTA 5 are nothing short of exceptional. The driving mechanics strike a perfect balance between realism and fun, ensuring that vehicular mayhem remains as entertaining as ever. Shooting mechanics are smooth and responsive, enhancing the action-packed sequences that the series is renowned for. The addition of heists adds an extra layer of strategy and excitement, enabling players to meticulously plan and execute high-stakes robberies with their chosen crew.  What truly sets GTA 5 apart is the online multiplayer mode, Grand Theft Auto Online. It's a sprawling universe in its own right, offering players the chance to explore Los Santos with their friends, engage in various activities, and even create their own content. The consistent updates and additions by Rockstar have kept the online community vibrant and ever-evolving.  Graphically, GTA 5 continues to amaze even years after its initial release. The attention to detail, realistic lighting, and meticulous character animations create an immersive experience that stands the test of time. The level of optimization on various platforms is commendable, ensuring that players across different systems can enjoy the game without compromising on visual quality.  In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is a magnum opus in the gaming world. Its combination of a richly detailed open world, engaging characters, gripping narrative, and diverse gameplay mechanics make it a landmark achievement. Whether you're a fan of action, storytelling, exploration, or simply causing virtual chaos, GTA 5 offers an unforgettable experience. Without a doubt, it deserves a perfect 5-star rating for its lasting impact on the gaming industry.

When I was growing up I couldn't really play these kinds of video games in my mother's household. I never bothered to play this game at a friend's house either. I just never got around to it. That was until I turned 20 years old and moved out of my parents' house and into my own apartment. I found this game on sale and I figured why not get it. After 80 hours into this game (barely touched the multiplayer mind you) I'm in love with the single player campaign. I'm glad I never played this game until I turned 20 because not only am I free from having to look over my shoulder when I'm at the strip club, but I understand jokes and references 14 year old me would've never understood. The campaign is hilarious and really fun to play and I know i'm 10 years behind on all of this but I waited long enough to finally play this game that my parents banned with extreme predjudice.

Oh, Grand Theft Auto V, you wild, sussy, and absolutely ridiculous masterpiece. Buckle up, babes, 'cause we're about to dive into the zaniest world this side of Ohio! Lemme tell ya, when I first loaded up this game, I was like "nahhhhh, they didn't just go there!" But they did, and I forgor all my worries 'cause I was bout to come on this epic adventure, gang gang!  The moment I stepped into Los Santos, I felt like an amogus in a world full of swaggy chaos. I mean, seriously, where else can you casually jack a car, chase a train, and rob a convenience store in one go? It's like a real-life favorite meme compilation, except you're in control of the madness. Yummers!  But let's talk about them characters, fam. Michael, Trevor, and Franklin – what a trio! Michael's like that older femboy in the hood, tryna keep it lowkey but ending up in the wildest heists. Trevor? Oh my days, that man is pure chaotic energy. Every time he's on screen, it's an "ermm yoinks!" moment, and you just can't help but love the crazy mofo.  And speaking of NPCs, oh boy, they're a whole mood. You'll find 'em bing chilling on the streets, saying some of the most random stuff. It's like they're all part of a secret Ohio club or something. You'll be walking along, and some dude just hits you with a "scrumptious!" line outta nowhere. Only in GTA V, I tell ya.  The city itself, Los Santos, is a work of art, so vibrant and full of life. From the posh neighborhoods to the gritty back alleys, it's a melting pot of weird and wonderful. You can even switch between characters, which is like being in multiple places at once, being your own femboy army – zesty times indeed!  But let's be real, sometimes the game's humor can be a bit "NPC" level, like they're trying too hard to be funny. And those loading screens, ugh, they're longer than a cross-country road trip from Ohio to California. But hey, nothing's perfect, right?  In the end, Grand Theft Auto V is a sussy rollercoaster of chaos and adventure, a game that leaves you laughing, scratching your head, and yelling "when the impostor is sus!" all in one sitting. It's a classic that's imprinted its mark on gaming culture, and you can't deny its impact. So, if you haven't played it yet, what are you waiting for? Hop in, fam, and let's go on a wild, goofy ahh ride through the crazy streets of Los Santos!
